SPEECH.SPEAKER: RYAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 11 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Whereas before Europeans settled in Australia, the Aboriginal peoples of Australia had lived on their traditional lands from time immemorial and had in Aboriginal law and customs a clear title to those lands; and

Whereas Europeans and other non-Aboriginal people have occupied and used most of the traditional lands of the Aboriginal peoples against their will and without negotiation, compensation or treaty; and
Whereas it has been the practice of nations established in territories previously occupied by indigenous inhabitants to reach a negotiated settlement with those inhabitants; and

Whereas that occupation has seriously damaged the traditional way of life of Aboriginal Australians and has caused poverty and hardship to be the fate of the great majority of their surviving descendants; and

Whereas the surviving descendants of the Aboriginal peoples have expressed a wish to have their rights to land acknowledged, to preserve their link with their Aboriginal ancestors and to maintain their distinctive identity with its own cultural heritage; and
Whereas the people of Australia in 1967 voted overwhelmingly that the Commonwealth Parliament should have responsibility for laws relating to Aboriginal Australians; and

Whereas it is accepted internationally by the United Nations organisation, that each country should work to establish the rights of indigenous peoples to self-determination, non-discrimination and the enjoyment of their own culture; and
Whereas the Woodward Commission in 1974 established principles by which Aboriginal rights to land should be acknowledged and realised; and

Whereas the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament in February 1975 resolved that Aboriginal Australians should be compensated for the loss of their traditional lands and for the damage to their way of life; and
Whereas the National Aboriginal Conference unanimously resolved in April 1979 in Canberra to ask the Commonwealth Government to negotiate a Treaty with Aboriginal Australians.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government should invite the Aboriginal people of Australia to negotiate a Treaty with the Commonwealth of Australia, and any Treaty should contain provisions relating to the following matters: (i) The protection of Aboriginal identity, languages, law and culture, (ii) The recognition and restoration of rights to land by applying, throughout Australia, the recommendations of the Woodward Commission, (iii) The conditions governing mining and exploitation of other natural resources on Aboriginal land, (iv) Compensation to Aboriginal Australians for the loss of traditional lands and for damage to those lands and to their traditional way of life, (v) The right of Aboriginal Australians to control their own affairs and to establish their own associations for this purpose.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 195 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the electors and residents within the City of Wollongong (State of NSW) respectfully showeth that:
(1) despite promises from the Government, Radio 2 EA did not begin transmission in Wollongong until 1979.
(2) Wollongong has one of the largest migrant populations in Australia in that over half the population are born overseas or have one or more parents born overseas.
(3) we cannot receive Channel 0.
(4) the cost of privately installing UHF aerials is prohibitive for many migrants in the City.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate use its powers to ensure that a repeater transmitter be opened in Wollongong on both UHF and VHF bands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Women's Advisory Council
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the National Women's Advisory Council has not been democratically elected by the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is not representative of the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is a discriminatory and sexist imposition on Australian women as Australian men do not have a National Men's Advisory Council imposed on them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the National Women's Advisory Council be abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal opportunity with Australian men of having issues of concern to them considered, debated and voted on by their Parliamentary representatives without intervention and interference by an unrepresentative ''Advisory Council''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Service of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as ''Australian Soldiers'' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required, and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Air Force could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to an answer he gave to a question from Senator Tate on 14 May in which the Minister said, in relation to the Australian Wool Testing Authority:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . this Government is one which believes in private and not public enterprise. We believe if a function can be performed by the private sector it should be performed by it.

I ask the Minister whether he was aware at the time he gave that answer to the question on Thursday, 14 May, of a Government decision to be announced on 15 May that it was no longer the Government's intention to sell the Wool Testing Authority to private enterprise. If the Minister was not aware of the decision at that time, by whom are these important decisions relating to the fundamental philosophy of the Liberal Party made and at what stage are other Ministers in the Government, apart from those who make the decisions, informed of those decisions? I further ask whether the Minister still shares his very strong commitment, expressed on 14 May, to the Wool Testing Authority being appropriately in the hands of private enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just had another look at the answer which I gave on 14 May and I certainly do not step back from what I said at that time. I believe it is one of the important differences-indeed, one of the fundamental differences-between those on this side of the chamber and those on the other side of the chamber that we do believe that wherever a function can be performed other than by government it ought to be performed other than by government. At the time when I answered that question the Government had announced a decision about the Australian Wool Testing Authority. Further statements were made subsequent to my answering that question and my present advice is that the final decision on the sale of the Authority will be made by the relevant Minister in conjunction with the Australian Wool Corporation. Consultations are currently in progress with the Australian Wool Corporation and the industry on the various options which are open to the Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Will consideration be given to difficulties alleged by the Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police in Queensland as a consequence of the Commonwealth's requirement that tenders be called for all construction works on national roads? The two main alleged difficulties are, firstly, that this decision could affect the capacity to handle emergency works, particularly in western Queensland, and that flexibility between construction and maintenance could disappear; and, secondly, that the continued existence of some departmental regional offices and other establishments may be questioned and the viability of repair and store operations could be jeopardised. Further, will the Government give consideration to the request that any requirement for a major shift to contract works allow a basic day labour presence and provide three years for practical implementation, thus avoiding major retrenchments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has provided me with some information with regard to this matter. I believe it has become a matter of public concern in the last few days. The Minister is aware that a letter from Mr Hinze, with the usual belly-ache, opposing the Government's introduction of the tender and contract system, has arrived. Mr Hinze, in his letter, makes extravagant suggestions about massive retrenchments and redundance of the large departmental plant fleet and, not surprisingly, suggests that the Commonwealth should leave such matters with the States.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently the Minister for Transport introduced the Roads Grants Bill 1981 into Parliament. This Bill provides that Commonwealth grants for construction works on national roads will be conditional upon the tenders being called and dealt with in accordance with approved arrangements. The Government's objective is to ensure that maximum value is obtained from its very substantial outlays on national roads, which, of course, are eligible for full Commonwealth funding. The Government will not exclude State road authorities and local authorities from carrying out national road construction works. State and local government authorities will be free to bid for the works in competition with private contractors. Given the road construction experience which these authorities have gained over the years and the financial and other advantages they enjoy, they ought to be in a very good position to compete for such works. Quite clearly, this puts them in a strong position in order to deal with the kinds of emergency works to which I think Senator Martin was referring.

Mr Hinze chooses to ignore the fact that the Commonwealth requirement for tenders to be called for construction works on national roads applies to only 10 per cent of road works in Queensland. The other 90 per cent will continue to be carried out under present arrangements. Accordingly, it is again hard to understand the proposition which is mentioned by Senator Martin, that this in fact will affect repairs and stores operations in the various areas which she mentioned. Even if Mr Hinze's pessimism about the chances of the Main Roads Department being able to compete with private contractors turns out to be justified, a reduction in work loads of 10 per cent will hardly destroy the viability of any of the operations carried out by his Department. The Minister does not accept the suggestion that the Commonwealth will in any way endanger the capacity of the Main Roads Department to handle emergency works. Such works on national highways will continue to be funded by the Commonwealth as they are now. Once again Mr Hinze has deliberately misrepresented the Commonwealth's intention regarding a new tender system for the national road construction system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle as a member of the ministerial committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions and as Minister for Finance. When presenting the ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Prime Minister stated that the interest subsidy to the Australian Wheat Board 'is to be reduced by one percentage point'. The Minister for Primary Industry has since claimed that the statement referred only to a one per cent increase in the rate charged by the Reserve Bank Rural Credits Department. Did the Government instruct the Bank to increase the rate? If so, when will the Government table the instruction as required by section 11 of the Reserve Bank Act? If not-that is, if it was an autonomous Reserve Bank decision-why was it misrepresented by the Prime Minister as a razor gang decision? Why did the Prime Minister refer only to the Wheat Board when several other statutory bodies, including the Australian Dairy Corporation, would be affected by Rural Credits Department interest rates? Finally, why did the Prime Minister use the future tense-that is, he said 'is to be'-when the Rural Credits Department rate was raised by one per cent a month before he spoke and by one-half per cent a fortnight after he spoke?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of matters were raised by Senator Walsh in his question. The Treasurer today answered a question which included some of the matters raised by Senator Walsh. The important part of the Treasurer's response was that, because of the significant policy implications, particularly to Australian primary industry, of variations in the interest rate charged on Rural Credits Department advances, it has been a long-standing practice for there to be close consultation between the Government, normally through the Treasurer of the day, and the Reserve Bank of Australia regarding the level of interest. The Treasurer went on to say that, as the questioner in the other place implied, the final decision on the level of Rural Credits Department advances is a matter for the Reserve Bank to determine. The Treasurer added:

ANSWER.PARA: There has been no section 11 notice, letter or whatever one likes to call it written nor indeed is that in contemplation. I have written a letter to the Governor of the Reserve Bank informing him formally of the decision that was the subject of the Prime Minister's announcement.
The Treasurer went on to say that already, over the past few months, there had been changes in the rate of interest charged on Rural Credits Department advances. He added:

There was one in March and there was one, I think, on 15 May. Also there have been some fluctuations in the market rate of interest charged on borrowings by the Australian Wheat Board to the extent that it is borrowing on the commercial market. The intent of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee decision and the intent of the Prime Minister's announcement was to indicate a view on the part of the Government that the differential ought to be less by reason of a further rise. The question of any additional increase which would at some time be needed to give full effect to the intent of the Government's decision, a further increase of one per cent, is something that the Reserve Bank itself must determine, taking into account a variety of factors, some of which have been canvassed in the honourable gentleman's question.

The Treasurer did write to the Governor of the Reserve Bank and draw to his attention the decision of the review committee and the announcement by the Prime Minister at the time that statement was made to the Parliament. If any further matters are involved in Senator Walsh's question I will see that additional advice is given to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that the question was directed to her, not in her capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer but in her capacity as Minister for Finance and as a member of the committee concerned. The Treasurer did not answer the question in the House of Representatives, and neither has she. Specifically, since she was a member of the committee, can she tell us whether the Government had decided that the interest rate would be increased by one per cent, and if the Government did not make that decision-if, as the Treasurer claimed and she now claims, it was a decision of the Reserve Bank-why it was misrepresented in the report as a decision of the ministerial committee? If, as her answer given just now implies, the interest rate is to be increased by one per cent subsequent to the Prime Minister's statement of 30 April, can we anticipate another one-half per cent increase in the Rural Credits Department rate, irrespective of whether the Rural Credits Department chooses to make that decision autonomously? I remind the Minister that she is being asked the question as a member of the review committee and should know. She should not seek to take refuge behind what the Treasurer said, or do as she usually does and state that she will refer it to the Treasurer for his comments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I speak both as the Minister for Finance and as the Minister representing the Treasurer in this place in referring to the answer that was given by the Treasurer. I do so because the Treasurer is the Minister who has a close relationship with the Reserve Bank. I have referred to the communication from the Treasurer to the Reserve Bank on this matter and at this stage I have nothing to add to what I have said. If additional aspects of the many sections of Senator Walsh's question require further information, I will see that he is advised accordingly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: SALE OF GOVERNMENT FACILITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory aware of local media reports this morning which refer to a document apparently mentioned in the House of Assembly last night in which it is alleged that the Government is planning to sell the Erindale Centre, the Albert Hall, the merry-go-round and the East Basin pavilion? Can the Minister tell us whether the Government is planning to sell these things?

—The Minister has prepared for me some information on this matter. He has indicated that there has been no public identification of any document referred to by Mr Whalan in the House of Assembly. He is able to say quite categorically that there is no proposal to sell the merry-go-round or any of the other facilities.
—The merry-go-round man.

—There is certainly a merry-go-round in this place. No recommendation has been brought forward by the Minister or his Department to sell any of the things mentioned by Mr Whalan. The Minister is categorically opposed to the sale of the merry-go-round which, apart from providing much enjoyment to the children of Canberra, is an integral part of Civic and has very substantial historical benefits.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Defence been drawn to reports of a recent defence seminar in Darwin at which leading citizens, including the Police Commissioner, claimed that northern coastal surveillance was inadequate? Has he been told that illegal landings, drug running and illegal fishing were claimed to be the major problems and that the introduction of pastoral and agricultural diseases was a real threat? What action does the Government intend to take? Will the Minister not accept that defence of our country in peacetime is a proper role for his Department and not a civilian or coastguard activity?

—I am not aware of the actual seminar to which Senator Robertson referred. If the honourable senator can give some particulars of the specific complaints, I will take note of them and ask the Minister for Defence to comment on them as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that no one yet knows what revenue the States will be able to raise from charging fees in public hospitals because no one yet knows what proportion of the patients will be pensioners and the disadvantaged to whom the States have promised to provide free treatment in public hospitals? Will the review of the income that States receive from the imposition of hospital charges, to be carried out early next year, establish the actual income from reasonable effort as the basis of the 60-40 proportional division of the proceeds between the Commonwealth and the States concerned? Will the Commonwealth hospital grants be adjusted in the light of that review? Will all States be treated on the same basis as regards the assessment of what constitutes reasonable effort? Finally, will the $16m advance to Queensland be treated as part of Queensland's 40 per cent share of what it raises by charging fees in its hospitals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that considerable discussion has taken place between Commonwealth and State Health Ministers on the Commonwealth's decisions in respect of health funding to the States in the next financial year and subsequent years. In the next financial year the health funding grant to be paid within general revenue grants for health services is to be based upon the same level of funds as paid in the present financial year for public hospitals, for the general community health program and for the school dental health programs, plus a factor to cover inflation, and, as the honourable senator pointed out in his question, less 60 per cent of a State's assessed revenue raising capacity.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the Health Ministers conference on 8 May and consideration of the views put forward by States and the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth reviewed the question of the assessment of the additional revenue capacity of the States. Arising from these considerations, the Commonwealth has decided that a review will be made towards the end of 1981-82 of its assessment of States' capacity to increase revenue in the light of experience. The manner in which it was to proceed and the nature of the proposed review was the subject of discussion at the Health Ministers conference in Canberra yesterday.

It was considered important that States be aware as early as possible of the factors in the assessment as a means of establishing their charging policies and the levels of charges. It was agreed that Commonwealth and State officers would meet as soon as possible to finalise the factors to be taken into account in the review, as well as assessment procedures and mechanisms. This approach will ensure that the review will take into account any special factors which may exist in a particular State. Any necessary adjustments to funding will be made after the results of the review have been considered. The special grant to Queensland for 1981-82 will be a cushioning adjustment of $16m for 1981-82 only. The 60 per cent of Queensland's assessed capacity to increase revenue will be reduced accordingly. The residual 40 per cent of assessed revenue available to the State is not affected by the allowance of $16m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister, through his office, last night strongly imply that the Minister for Communications was responsible for trips to the United States of America organised by the Myer Emporium Ltd for the chairman and secretary of the Government communications committee for a conference on cable television? Did the Minister, Mr Sinclair, also last night imply that the first approach to him about the trips had come from Mr Jull, the honourable member for Bowman? Did the honourable member for Bowman, Mr Jull, last night say that he had been selected for the trip by Mr Sinclair's office? Did Senator Collard yesterday say that the first approach had been made by the Myer Emporium Ltd to the Prime Minister, who had given his approval? Did the general manager of the Myer Emporium, in a telex to the Leader of the Opposition, today made public, say that the offer of the trips was made to the Minister for Communications on 1 May? Would the Minister ascertain who he thinks is telling the truth about these trips?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no knowledge of any comment by the Prime Minister last night on this matter. I will refer that part of the question to the Prime Minister and get him to respond to that section. My understanding of this matter is that the Myer Emporium wrote to the Minister for Communications indicating that a major convention was to be held overseas involving cable television, that it would be desirable that members of parliament should be informed and that the financing of the actual trip there and back could be arranged if members so desired.

ANSWER.PARA: My understanding is that the Minister for Communications referred the matter to the chairman of the committee who, I understand, is Mr Jull, and that Mr Jull and Senator Collard agreed that they would go to the conference. My understanding is that this was basically a matter for the individuals to decide, by their own choice, whether they should go.

I have seen a copy of the telex-with, I think, yesterday's date over it-that was sent to the Leader of the Opposition. It seems to me to be a pity that the same invitation was not issued at the same time to both sides of the Parliament. I think that would have been a fairer approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would have made it right, would it?
—The judgment is for the individual.
—No, it is not. What the judgment should be is in the Bowen report.

—I am getting an interjection that what the judgment should be is in the Bowen report. As I understand the Bowen report, it has no particular relation to this matter, but we will be in fact implementing the Bowen report. The Bowen report is a creature of this Government. It would have been competent upon the Australian Labor Party when in government to have brought down guidelines. Apparently now it suddenly has discovered that it has some guidelines on ethics on this matter. My understanding is that the Bowen report has no such guidelines to cover this matter, but if it has we will look at them and see.

ANSWER.PARA: My understanding also is that members from both sides of the chamber have accepted invitations over the years at their own judgment. For example, it is common for them to receive invitations to have free trips on inaugural flights on airlines. Members on both sides of the chamber have accepted invitations from governments. The question of whether any interest is implied is a matter for the judgment of the individual and the overall integrity of the individual. Any member of parliament is constantly coming under pressure to receive information on a variety of matters and is subjected to particular interests day after day. It is for the member of parliament to get to understand the issues and make value judgments objectively. The real test of integrity comes when the judgment is made on issues, when the member speaks or votes on the issues. There is a precedent for what has happened. I will refer the earlier part of the question to the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Arising from the Minister's answer, in which he described the Bowen report as a creation of the Fraser Government and said that the previous Labor Government could have introduced guidelines on these matters, I ask: Is it not a fact that the Labor Government established a joint party committee of this Parliament which made unanimous recommendations about the guidelines which should apply to members of parliament in relation to these matters? Is it not also a fact that the guidelines unanimously suggested by that committee were too tough for the Fraser Government and for that reason the Bowen committee of inquiry was established? When is a debate on the Bowen report-promised two years ago-to be brought forward by the Government?

—To respond to a new question-it was not a supplementary question because it dealt with other matters-I am not aware of the existence of the Whitlam Government's document. I will look at it. Certainly, I do not believe that the guidelines were too tough. I think the Bowen committee report is a report that has been acknowledged as being very pertinent to the conditions of Parliament. The Government, from the moment that the report was received and studied, agreed that it should apply instantaneously to Ministers. Discussions are taking place to make it pertain also to private senators and members. I will see when that can be done. I will also study the document that Senator Button has drawn to my attention.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALT AND SUGAR CONTENT IN FOODS

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health to an article appearing in the current issue of Choice, the magazine of the Australian Consumers Association, warning mothers not to give rusks to their babies because they contain either too much sugar or too much salt. Will the Minister comment on the results of the tests conducted by the Consumers Association and, in particular, its claim that one major brand of rusks contained 38 per cent sugar and another brand contained more than six times the maximum amount of salt recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council? Whilst I recognise that food industry bodies in Australia have been made aware of the Department of Health's policy of recommending a reduction in sugar intake by the community, I ask: Does the Minister agree that the use of sugar in foodstuffs, particularly those consumed by young children, must be more carefully controlled to ensure that correct eating habits are fostered in the Australian community? Will action be taken by the Government to place more stringent controls on the high concentration of sugar and salt in foodstuffs produced for consumption by babies and young children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article which appeared in the April 1981 issue of Choice. I thank the honourable senator for drawing this matter to the attention of the Senate. I am aware that that article advised mothers not to give rusks to their infants because the rusks contain excessive amounts of sugar or salt. The honourable senator's question contains particular and general questions. The Minister for Health is aware that the reported levels of sugar and salt in some of the rusks are significantly higher than the upper limits presently listed in a National Health and Medical Research Council draft standard for cereal-based foods for infants and children. This matter is of nutritional concern. The Department of Health's food and nutrition policy recommends a reduction in the community's intake of sugar and salt.

ANSWER.PARA: On average, Australians consume about one kilogram of sugar per head per week, two-thirds of which is obtained from processed foods. It is estimated that nearly one-fifth of the food energy in the Australian diet comes from sugar. Australians also consume excessive amounts of salt in relation to their needs and there is concern about the link between salt intake and the later development of hypertension.

The Minister for Health agrees that it is important to limit the amount of sugar and salt in foods for infants and young children, both to promote their nutritional health and to foster good food habits, a matter about which the honourable senator asked. Information on feeding young children, provided in nutritional publications of the Department of Health, recommends that foods with a high sugar or salt content should be used sparingly. I am sure that Senator Missen will be interested to know that a joint departmental and food industry working party has been set up by the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop the food standard that I referred to earlier. This standard will establish upper limits for the amounts of sugar and salt in cereal-based foods for infants and children. The Minister for Health has advised me that the working party has been asked to expedite work on this standard. When finalised the standard will be recommended to the States and Territories for adoption in food legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. The Assistant Director of the Victorian Public Health Commission has stated that germs causing legionnaires disease are probably more widespread than is generally known. I ask the Minister: What research is being done in Australia into this disease or are we, as usual, depending on overseas studies to save money on research? Is the matter being left to State health authorities, which are already hampered in their work because of lack of adequate Federal funding? Will the Federal Government provide the necessary funding for an overall examination of airconditioning in public places in Australia and for carrying out the necessary research, thus showing the same concern for the Australian people as the Prime Minister received when his airconditioning was contaminated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable senator would agree that we have to distinguish the research needs in relation to our handling of the legionnaires organism from the public health aspects. I have no doubt that the States are able to carry out effectively the public health role which properly falls to them. The honourable senator asked first whether I was aware of a statement of the Assistant Director of the Victorian Public Health Commission that the germ, the pneumophila, causing legionnaires disease is widely spread in nature. I am aware of that. I am also aware that it can cause two separate illnesses. One is an illness which occurs quite commonly, which is called Pontiac fever. The other is an illness which occurs infrequently, which is called legionnaires disease. Legionnaires disease is less frequent and more serious. Pontiac fever, as I am sure Senator Elstob will be interested to know, is very frequent but is not serious and has some elements of la grippe, if I may use a French term.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been very dependent upon overseas research to identify the presence of this organism. I think Australians are very grateful for the chance to share in the results of research which has identified the organism and given us something of its epidemiology. I come back to my starting point in relation to the public health responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States. I have no doubt that these are being undertaken properly and adequately at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, follows a question which I asked recently about tourist facilities for the disabled. He advised me that that had been a matter for discussion and that there was a very high level of enthusiasm for the work which had been done with respect to the disabled. He gave me to understand that that work was being extended. —My question, which is to the Leader of the Govenment in the Senate, concerns last Thursday's announcement by the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs that the European Economic Community has concluded a nuclear safeguards agreement with Australia and that this agreement permits Australian uranium to be sent to the Soviet Union for enrichment. Under the terms of the agreement, EEC countries must receive back from the Soviet Union the same quantity of uranium as is sent for enrichment, and these transfers will be monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency. I ask the Minister whether he thinks for one second that the Soviet Union would consider processing our uranium unless it was in its own best interests to do so? Can he categorically assure the Senate that the monitoring to be carried out by the IAEA is completely fail-safe and that every kilogram of Australian uranium will be meticulously accounted for? What is to stop the Soviet Union, in an emergency situation, from unilaterally impounding Australian uranium and enriching it to nuclear weapons grade? What possible sanctions could be imposed against the Soviet Union if it chose to do this? Finally, in what way will selling our uranium to the Soviets, and the five-fold increase in our sales of wool, wheat and other materials to them in the last 12 months, encourage the Soviet Union to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first premise that I invite Senator Chipp to address himself to, and which he will accept, is that the use of uranium for warlike purposes involves the derivation of plutonium from it. Also I would like him to accept the melancholy fact that Russia has such an abundance of plutonium in its own stocks that it is many, many times the volume that it could ever possibly need for any kind of warlike purposes. So the thought that Russia will look towards acquiring uranium from some part of the world to process, enrich, upgrade and reprocess to get plutonium in order to help its weapon stocks is not soundly based. In the first place, on that ground one would not expect, even if one mistrusted the Soviet's motives as well one may reasonably do, that it would look towards Australian uranium or uranium from any other country as a source of plutonium. It so happens that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has an abundant source of uranium for its own purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: The International Atomic Energy Agency is a monitoring body which has world respect and world trust. It is the belief of this Government, and the belief of governments of the world, that the Agency is capable of so monitoring the movement of all uranium products around the world that it can detect whether there is any appreciable loss in weight in processing or reprocessing the product. Yes, we do believe that the IAEA can do this job. Indeed we have our Australian Safeguards Office as a strong auditing body working closely with the international body. If Senator Chipp is worried that it would be Russia's aim to secure plutonium, I have to say that Russia has more than abundant sources of both uranium and plutonium. I do not find any joy in that at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the article in today's Australian Financial Review which relates to the Ziedler Committee of Inquiry into Electricity Generating and the Sharing of Power Resources, which is inquiring into the establishment of an integrated electricity supply grid for south-eastern Australia which will bring obvious savings in costs for all electricity commissions that are involved. Is the Minister aware that the Institution of Engineers of Australia submitted to that inquiry that the cost of linking Tasmania and Victoria would be only some $230m? Is the Minister aware that this is considerably less than the Tasmanian Government proposes to spend on dams in the south-west of Tasmania? When will the report of the Ziedler Committee be available? Will the Minister ask the Tasmanian Government to await that report before any dams are built in the south-west of Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Townley asks is a significant one.
—It was only last week that--

—The inquiry that was set up to study the feasibility and economics of a power grid for south-eastern Australia is one that could in the longer term bring great benefits to Australia. Initially, the inquiry was directed to South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales. It could readily have included a State further north, Queensland. It is sometimes said that neither New South Wales nor Victoria has any interest in a further grid. As I think an interjector said, last week, had the inquiry gone much further, it could well have disproven that point.

ANSWER.PARA: There is considerable thought about and benefit in, first of all, extending the grid to South Australia. I hope that South Australia will be able to find workable quantities of good coal so as to have in the decades ahead coal powered stations operating in areas where there is likely to be very big industrial development in the future.

I am aware of the report of the Institution of Engineers. I have in mind that figure of roughly $230m as the estimated cost of a cable going under Bass Strait. Indeed, the Institution of Engineers went on to say that the overall savings by using peaks and base loads properly and by using the hydro-electrics of both Tasmania and the Snowy Mountains properly would be the equivalent of something in the order of two or more new power stations, that is to say, several billion dollars in real money.

I know that the Ziedler Committee has seen that report. I know that it has studied it. The Ziedler Committee is, I think, to bring down a report-it may be an interim or the full report-in the very near future-in a matter, I think, of weeks. I cannot say until I have seen the report what its basic recommendations would be, but I will be happy to provide the Premier of Tasmania with a copy of that report. I have no doubt he will study it intensely.

The Commonwealth Government is very keen, if it is humanly possible, to find ways of getting economic electric power supply to Tasmania without doing damage in any extensive way to the environment. It is a big job to do, but I have no doubt in my own mind that in the decades ahead integrated power grids will become a familiar pattern of Australian life.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The situation is that aircraft are programmed on a monthly basis by the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre to overfly the coastline daily between Karratha in Western Australia north about to the Roper River in the Northern Territory and from Weipa north about to Cairns, including the Torres Strait.
