STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS: REPORT ON THE ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE, AUGUST 1979
Ministerial Statement

TALK.START.PARA: —I am making a statement in relation to the August 1979 Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations entitled 'Advance to the Minister for Finance', which was tabled by the Chairman on 11 October 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that the Government's response to the Report has taken longer than expected; consultative processes extending for longer than anticipated. But some of the recommendations have already been implemented.

In essence, the Committee concluded that a centrally controlled contingency fund for urgent expenditure, as provided by the Advances, is a proper tool of Government. Although satisfied that there had been no misuse of the advances, the Committee went on to suggest certain changes to the operation of the system. The Committee largely directed its attention to the use made of the Advances available under Appropriation Acts 1 and 2 and Supply Acts 1 and 2:
to supplement existing appropriations; and
to fund new services for which no prior specific appropriation has been made.
While accepting that contingency funding arrangements are necessary for both these purposes, the Committee was concerned that:

existing criteria for determing issues from the Advances are 'too vague and subjective' and that, with the criteria being laid down only in the Finance Directions-which apply only to officials-Ministers are not necessarily bound by them:
there was no limit on the amount Governments could seek under the Advance appropriations; and
the degree of disclosure of funding from the Advance was insufficient.

The Government has given careful and sympathetic consideration to the recommendations of the Committee. Where it has not been able to adopt a specific recommendation, it has endeavoured to find a compromise that met the spirit of the Committee's thinking. In so doing, the Government records its recognition of the important contribution made by the Committee in further development of procedures for ensuring the continued proper use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.
I now announce the Government's response to each individual recommendation of the Committee.
RECOMMENDATION 1 'Expenditure from the Advance in addition to items already appropriated for, or new items, be permitted only in ''urgent and unforeseen'' circumstances.'

The Government accepts that the issue of funds from the Advance be on the basis that the contemplated expenditure is deemed to be 'urgent and unforeseen' at the time of preparing the relevant Appropriation Bills and cannot reasonably await the passage of an Appropriation Bill.

The Government also accepts that, in general, issues from the Advance should be for expenditures which were unforeseen at the time of preparation of previously introduced or enacted Appropriation Bills, but notes that there are occasions on which foreseen expenditures become urgent (that is, in effect, the urgency is unforeseen and payment is required to be made before an Appropriation Bill under consideration by the Parliament is enacted).

The Government also points out that whether or not an expenditure is foreseen is dependent in part on the accepted rules of estimating amounts to be provided in the Appropriation Bills, namely that estimates for all items of expenditure shall represent a realistic assessment of the sum that is expected to be spent having regard to the information available to the Government and the prices prevailing at the time of preparation.
RECOMMENDATION 2 'The above criteria be set out in the Finance Regulations made under the Audit Act.'

The Government has noted the terms of a legal advising to the effect that practical legal difficulties would arise in dealing with requests for the issue of funds from the Advance if the words 'urgent and unforeseen' were to be included in legislation. It also noted that the making of a regulation for this purpose under the Audit Act would not be a valid exercise of the regulation making power under the Act.

The Government has considered whether it should seek power to enable such a regulation to be made but has decided not to pursue that course in view of the administrative difficulties outlined in the legal advising.

However, the Government recognises the Committee's desire to see some form of legislative provision constraining the use of the Advances of supplementing existing appropriations for specified purposes, and for new services for which no specific appropriation has been made. In these cases, the Government is prepared to include in the Schedules to the Appropriation and Supply Acts a clause which provides for the Minister for Finance to be satisfied that expenditure from the Advances is urgent and unforeseen; such a clause was introduced in the Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1980-81.

RECOMMENDATION 3 'The amount appropriated to the Advance in Appropriation Acts No. 1 and No. 2 be limited to 2.3 per cent of the total of the previous year's general Appropriation Acts. If the amount is exceeded, then the matter should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure.'

The Government does not agree that the amounts to be appropriated for the Advances in the Appropriation Acts Nos 1 and 2 should be limited to 2.3 per cent of the total of the previous year's general Appropriation Acts. The Government believes that the level of the Advances to be sought in a particular year is dependent on a number of factors, including past experience, the need for restraint in public expenditures, and Parliamentary attitudes. The Government considers that the current practice under which the Minister for Finance gives careful consideration to the amount to be sought, consulting, as necessary, other senior Ministers, is appropriate and less arbitrary. It should be noted that since 1977-78 the percentage of the Advance to the total of the Appropriation Acts has fallen from 2.4 per cent to 2.0 per cent and the Government would wish to see no undue increase in this relativity other than in exceptional circumstances.
The Government is not therefore disposed to accept this recommendation.

RECOMMENDATION 4 'The explanations accompanying the Appropriation Bills, which are examined by Senate Estimates Committees, be accompanied by a separate section for each Department showing the funds which have already been provided from the Advance.'

The Government agrees that it would assist the Parliament in its examination of Appropriation Bills if departmental explanatory notes were to be accompanied by a section showing funds which have already been provided from the Advances. The Government notes, however, that issues continue to be made from the Advances after the date on which the explanatory notes are prepared and, indeed, may continue to be made until Governor-General's Warrant is obtained following the enactment of the Bills. However, the Government will direct departments to supply up to date lists of issues to the Chairman of the appropriate Estimates Committee at the commencement of the examination of each department's estimates; such a procedure was implemented in respect of the Estimates Committee hearings for the 1980-81 Budget estimates.
RECOMMENDATION 5

'A statement of approvals of expenditure from the Advance be published at the end of each calendar month and then tabled in Parliament at the earliest opportunity. The statement should indicate into which category each item of expenditure falls, i.e. whether it is expenditure to fund payments pending the issue of Governor-General's Warrant, to make advances which will be repaid within the financial year, to make moneys available for supplementation of existing appropriations for specified purposes or to make moneys available for new services for which no specific appropriation has been made. The statement should show all expenditure which requires the creation of a new appropriation item, but only expenditure above $50,000 for the other categories.'

The Government has no objection in principle to this recommendation, but questions whether the cost of both publication and tabling could be justified. Following further correspondence on the matter, the Chairman of the Committee has indicated that tabling of the statement would be sufficient. Accordingly, the Minister for Finance will table a categorised statement of issues from the Advances at the earliest opportunity after the commencement of each Sitting and at approximately monthly intervals thereafter.
MINISTERIAL STATEMENT BY THE HONOURABLE M. J. R. MACKELLAR, M.P., MINISTER FOR HEALTH
Commonwealth Government response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs' Report on Aboriginal Health
'The standard of health of Aboriginals is far lower than that of the majority of Australians and would not be tolerated if it existed in the Australian community as a whole.'
This is the main finding of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, in its Report on Aboriginal Health.

The same message comes through in two other reports now before the Government: The National Trachoma and Eye Health Program and the Government's own Program Effectiveness Review on Aboriginal health. Both show that the health of Aboriginal Australians is unacceptably low.
The Government agrees with this assessment and reaffirms its objective of raising the health status of Aboriginals to that of the rest of the community.

The hard fact is that, while we have channelled many millions of dollars into Aboriginal health and health-related programs, and in spite of all our efforts-and despite some improvements which have occurred-the level of Aboriginal health is still unacceptable.

Whilst there has been some improvement in the health status of Aboriginals, health services alone cannot provide the solution for all the problems. Nor are they the responsibility of any one Government. The problems will have to be overcome by a co-operative and co-ordinated effort involving many arms of both the Commonwealth and State Governments as well as Aboriginals themselves and their representative organisations.

It is important that we look at what we are doing and ensure that we are not just providing services and nothing more. We must evaluate existing programs to ensure that they are directed towards-and actually do result in-an improvement in Aboriginal health and social well-being. To this end, Commonwealth support for Aboriginal health programs will be made conditional upon a set of specific goals and objectives, which include Commonwealth Aboriginal Affairs policy, being drawn up for each program, against which its attainment can be measured.

The Government has received timely offers of assistance from professional health organisations. The Royal Australasian College of Physicians, whose members have undertaken much of the original research on respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, metabolic and paediatric problems among the Aboriginal population, considers that Aboriginal health is a major social issue in which its involvement could be increased. The Australian Medical Association has also expressed its concern and offered assistance. The Government appreciates the interest shown by these and other professional bodies and intends to pursue the offers, particularly in relation to evaluating health services to Aboriginals.
The reportsThere have been numerous reports on Aboriginal health. They have all painted much the same picture. I turn now to the background of the three reports which the Government has considered.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs received references on Aboriginal health from the House of Representatives on 1 December 1976 and 10 March 1977. On 16 March 1978 the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Ian Viner, gave the Committee its terms of reference. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The terms of reference read as follows-
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES STANDINGCOMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS
Terms of Reference-Aboriginal Health
(1) Examine the health problems of Aboriginals with particular attention to-
(a) the prevalence of different types of disease suffered by Aboriginals and Aboriginal communities;
(b) the relationship between Aboriginal health and environmental, social and cultural factors;
(c) the effectiveness of existing health care programs for Aboriginals generally, and the adequacy of Western European-type health services to cope with the health problems of Aboriginals; and
(d) alternative methods of health care delivery that take account of Aboriginals' lifestyles, including camp situations.
(2) That the Committee consider ways and means by which-
(a) persons with appropriate qualifications can be encouraged to assist Aboriginals achieve a better standard of health, and
(b) Aboriginals including traditional healers can participate in the development and delivery of health care services to their own communities, and in any modification of existing services.
(3) That the Committee recommend possible courses of action.
Having taken evidence through submissions, public hearings and community visits, the Parliamentary Committee presented its Report on 20 March 1979.

The Trachoma Report was prepared by the Royal Australian College of Opthalmologists. It describes the most extensive screening, diagnosis and treatment coverage of eye disease ever undertaken in this country. The field teams involved in the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program also detected and arranged treatment for a variety of other illnesses. The Report was presented to the Parliament by me on 1 April 1980.

A Program Effectiveness Review was conducted by Commonwealth officials during 1980 to determine, as far as possible, the health status of Aboriginals and the effectiveness of current Aboriginal health programs and of other programs which affect Aboriginal health.

The review team drew information about the programs from Commonwealth Departments and took into account the findings of the two reports I have already mentioned as well as other related reports. The officials also visited Aboriginal communities and consulted with people directly involved in community-based health care programs.
The Officials' Report was completed during 1980.

Main findings of the Reports These three reports are obviously inter-related, and it is appropriate for the Government to consider them together in its response to the Parliamentary Committee's report. They contain common fundamental concerns and recommendations, but differ considerably in detail. We have therefore felt it necessary to give careful attention to the major themes of each and the various proposals advanced.
The reports all confirm three things:
the unsatisfactory health status of Aboriginals;
the urgent need to improve the enviromental conditions affecting Aboriginal's health; and
the importance of increasing Aboriginal involvement in the design, control and delivery of health care services.

Environmental improvements Each report referred to the need to increase efforts to improve the environmental conditions in which many Aboriginals live. Much of the ill-health experienced by Aboriginals is directly associated with a sub-standard physical environment:
The Parliamentary Committee recommended that 'the highest priority be given and immediate action taken to provide clean and adequate water supplies to all Aboriginal communities' (R. 1 para. 138)

The Trachoma Report found in rural Australia that, when the hygiene of Aboriginals approached that of non-Aboriginals so did the prevalence rate of the diseases measured. So for those people living in unhygienic conditions it recommended that appropriately designed and equipped houses be provided (Trachoma R. 1, para. 180), and that houses should contain a water supply to cater for all necessary uses and should also have efficient water-based sewerage systems and garbage disposal facilities.
The Officials' Report also recommended that greater priority be given to the provision of housing, water supply, sanitation and electricity.

The disruption of Aboriginals' traditional lifestyle has given rise to a number of widespread health problems, especially where Aboriginals have been obliged to live on reserves or settlements, or in camps, or in rural or urban areas, under conditions of poverty. The problems include poor water supplies, dangerous sanitary conditions, overcrowding and limited access to nutritious food. The spread of illness and disease has been facilitated, especially respiratory, ear and skin infections, and intestinal parasite illnesses. The disruption of their society and lifestyles and its effects have also produced despair, chronic disadvantage and alcohol abuse.

The situation is not amenable to short-term solutions, and Government programs over many years have sought to improve services and facilities in such ways as will encourage Aboriginals to assume responsibility for decisions about their lifestyles and their futures. The effort must be maintained and expanded while the problems remain as serious as they are.

Once preventive measures begin to take effect, succeeding generations will not be saddled to the same extent with the wide spectrum of diseases-eye, ear, respiratory, gastro-intestinal, skin etc, that are less frequent in the non-Aboriginal population. Of course, in the meantime, health services play an important role by alleviating distress and improving the quality of life. It is our intention that all children, including Aboriginal children, will have a much better start to life than has been the case for so many in the past and which is so important in the long term for improved health status.
Aboriginals themselves have stressed the prime importance of adequate housing. That priority has been, and continues to be, reflected in the programs of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

For example, since 1975-76, the Government has provided $298.2m for Aboriginal housing, including hostels. During the last full financial year (1979-80), 1632 houses were built or purchased for Aboriginals and 205 home loans provided throughout the States and the Northern Territory with Commonwealth funds totalling $59.9m. The last Budget provided in excess of $72m for Aboriginal housing and accommodation.
These substantial increases in funds for Aboriginal housing show how determined we are to respond to Aboriginals' own priorities.

The figures give the lie to uninformed claims that funds have been cut. The Government has considerably expanded funds for Aboriginal housing and accommodation even while these reports have been under consideration. Those increased funds are flowing into this priority area of need. We have not delayed action-we have accelerated it. Much remains to be done-we do not deny that. But the Government's achievements in Aboriginal housing are substantial and growing each year. In fact, in some States, the time is now within sight when the housing backlog will have been overtaken.

Increasing attention is also being given, within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs' allocation, to programs administered under the general heading of Community Management and Services, for municipal-type services to Aboriginal community organizations, reserves and settlements. Here our role has been essentially a topping-up of State and local government activities.

However the Commonwealth expects the States and the Northern Territory also to honour their responsibilities towards their Aboriginal citizens. Aboriginal people, like other citizens living in a particular State or Territory, are entitled to expect basic municipal services to be provided by State or local government. The Commonwealth has done much to help overcome past neglect, but it is not, and should not be regarded as, the only source of funds for providing services to Aboriginal people.

While we expect the State and Territory Governments to take up this challenge, we understand that a special effort will be needed. That is what the Government had in mind in committing an extra $50m over five years for environmental health improvement.

I mentioned earlier that the efforts which have been made have not always been as effective as we would have liked. The Government is looking to shared funding arrangements under this program in a joint Commonwealth/State effort to eradicate at least the worst of the environmental conditions under which many Aboriginal communities in rural and remote areas live.

Finding, storing and distributing clean water supplies, and installing waste disposal systems are costly exercises. We must get our priorities correct, and make sure that Aboriginal communities' priorities are fully known. The technology used must suit the community environment. Good planning here may take time, but it will pay off.

It will be necessary to co-ordinate planning for the environmental improvements which are needed, so that we can determine which projects should be funded under this program in terms of national as well as community priorities. The Commonwealth intends to discuss these matters with relevant State Ministers and with Aboriginal representatives. I expect that there will be a range of subsequent discussions involving officers.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has a regular program of consultation and co-ordination with State authorities and with Aboriginal organizations, leading up to the preparation of its program for each financial year. At that Department's request, some proposals have already been identified for additional environmental health projects in the normal budget process for 1981/82. Again, we have not waited, or delayed action. The job is underway and we want to accelerate its progress, in co-operation with State and local authorities and with their financial support.

In considering projects for inclusion under the new program, we will be looking to concentrate the additional funds on those larger-scale water supply and waste disposal projects which have the highest priority of need, but which are difficult for the Commonwealth or the States to accommodate in their normal ongoing budgets.

Special needs arise in the increasing number of small outstation communities in traditional areas. It is not appropriate in these cases to provide permanent major capital works which would disrupt the preferred lifestyle.

We are much encouraged by reports received that the health and well-being of Aboriginals at outstations is, on the whole, an improvement on the health of those people in the past. Nevertheless, the Government believes there should be adequate water supply and waste disposal to supplement the provision of basic services by members of outstation communities.

With major works being undertaken through the Environmental Health Program, relatively minor works which are also of high priority will be able to be accommodated within ongoing programs, where increased emphasis is already being placed on such measures.

Aboriginal involvement in the planning and delivery of services We know that conventional health services have real difficulties in winning the confidence of Aboriginal people. That confidence and familiarity are essential to effective and early use of health services. The reports before us all confirm that services which Aboriginals perceive as remote or impersonal have not been acceptable and therefore not effective in tackling their serious health problems. Because non-Aboriginals share the culture and outlook of most health personnel and have a lifelong familiarity with the institutions and values of mainstream society, we find it difficult to understand the alienation of many Aboriginals. This is particularly true of our health system, which is strongly based on scientific research, institutional care and professional structures. And I have not yet mentioned the daily reality and the historical experience of disadvantage, the evidence of which Aboriginals see all around them. What they see compounds the problems and makes our task in Aboriginal health a uniquely demanding one. We must do everything possible to strengthen Aboriginal responsibility and participation.

The Government therefore wishes to see, and will actively work towards, a marked increase in the degree of Aboriginal involvement in the control, management, design, delivery and evaluation of health care programs affecting Aboriginal people.
The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has been involved in supporting Aboriginal health care services through two channels:
assistance to the States to provide an adapted general service more appropriate to Aboriginal needs and more accessible by Aboriginals; and
the funding of Aboriginal organizations to provide health services run and controlled by Aboriginals for Aboriginals.
More recently, my own Department has also assisted some established Aboriginal Medical Services by payment of Health Program Grants designed to meet salary costs of clinical staff.
These services have tried to close the gap between the general medical services and the health needs of Aboriginals.

While we want to encourage the development of programs which serve the whole community, rather than segregated services, our fundamental objective is the improvement of Aboriginal health, using the most effective means available. We will need to monitor carefully the impact of the Government's proposals on the effectiveness of the various means of service provision.

There is not only a need for Aboriginals to be better informed about the availability of health services, to understand the services, to feel confident in approaching them and to feel at ease in using them. There is also a very real need to improve the understanding and empathy of non-Aboriginal staff who supply the health services and control the facilities. Finally, the services must modify and adapt themselves to Aboriginal values and needs-we must not make the assumption that only Aboriginals must change.

The Parliamentary Committee recommended that 'Aboriginal cultural beliefs and practices which affect their health and their use of health services . . . be fully taken into account in the design and implementation of health care programs' (R.6, para. 193). The Government supports this view.

The people best equipped to advise on relevant cultural beliefs and practices and the appropriate adaptation of health services are Aboriginals themselves. They are also best equipped to undertake important bridging roles in health service delivery. Their responsibilities in the health care services which they use must be rapidly expanded.
In supporting Aboriginal health programs, the Commonwealth will require greatly increased Aboriginal involvement in the design, control, management, delivery and evaluation of services.

There is a need for the States and the Northern Territory to provide greater opportunities for Aboriginals to play significant and expanded roles. To achieve this goal, increasing numbers of Aboriginals will have to be trained for, and employed at, all levels. Aboriginals must also take a real and decisive part in policy and program decision-making. The way each State Government meets this goal may be different. We are firmly committed, however, to ensuring that the goal is met, and we will be taking these questions up with State Ministers.

In the same spirit I should like to mention that some State colleagues with responsibilities in Aboriginal affairs have in the past expressed their concern that, in administering programs on behalf of the Commonwealth, they may not have enough flexibility. For example, they may wish to reallocate funds to reflect changing circumstances. The Commonwealth would be prepared to examine this problem with any of the States which wish to redirect priorities towards mutually-acceptable policy goals, and especially Aboriginal involvement.

It is unacceptable that, at the present time, there are no qualified medical practitioners of Aboriginal descent, and insufficient numbers of Aboriginal people qualified for other professional and para-professional roles. We propose to have discussions on a number of fronts to make sure Aboriginals have greater opportunities in these areas.
It is vital that Aboriginal doctors, nurses, administrators, nurses' aides, and other health care staff should be available. We acknowledge that the necessary education and training will take time.

In the short-term, however, we can also look at redefining existing practical responsibilities of Aboriginals presently employed in health care. Both the States and the Aboriginal Medical Services need to be involved in the provision of opportunities through the National Employment and Training System and other programs. Nor should the role of traditional healers, who are intimately involved in services in traditional communities, be overlooked. Opportunities must be found to make use of their particular skills, which can be built on or adapted according to circumstances.
We shall continue to give strong support to the employment of Aboriginal health workers, who have important preventive and primary care roles to perform, now and in the foreseeable future.

Availability and awareness of choices Most of us would take it for granted that we can choose the kind of health care we think appropriate. The Parliamentary Report makes it clear that more needs to be done to make a range of choices known and available to Aboriginal people.

One difference between Aboriginals and other groups in Australia is that Aboriginal people are not fully aware of the range of health care options availabe. The Parliamentary Committee recommended that 'Aboriginal communities be given the opportunity to determine the type of health service that will best suit their needs and available resources . . .' (R. 10, para. 314).

We endorse this view and commend it to State Governments. The Government will propose to the States and the Northern Territory discussions between officials, and with Aboriginal people, on this matter of choice. These discussions will be looking for a co-operative basis for increasing Aboriginals' awareness of the health service options and expanding the opportunities for Aboriginal communities to influence the types of services provided to them. This is a fundamental commitment and one which is supported by each of the reports on Aboriginal health to which I have referred.
In fact the Commonwealth and Victoria and Aboriginal organizations are now co-operating in a State Government working party which has these very objectives.
There is also scope for improving the relationship between general practitioners and Aboriginals, and increasing the use of primary care services by Aboriginals.

I mentioned before Commonwealth grants to Aboriginal Medical Services. These organizations provide primary health care services which are acceptable and accessible. Some of them have also begun to provide preventive services and ancillary programs in response to community needs, expressed through the close involvement of many Aboriginals in the Services.

The Aboriginal Medical Services are a fine example of Aboriginal initiative and of readiness to assume responsibility to improve their own health status. The Government endorses their valuable role in this field and commends also professional co-operation between Aboriginal Medical Services and State services so that their work is complementary. The Aboriginal and Islander Medical Service in Darwin, which is funded jointly by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory Governments and works in closely with existing health services, is a good example of what can be achieved through co-operation. The Government will be prepared to consider provision of assistance to similarly innovative approaches elsewhere.

We shall, of course, continue our existing support to Aboriginal Medical Services. We shall also consider, together with the States and Aboriginal people, the expansion of complementary community-based services where they offer the most effective form of health care, and work towards an expanded range of options for primary medical care.

Aboriginals must be involved to the fullest possible extent in selecting the most appropriate health care options. This policy is consistent, the Government believes, with a cardinal principle of the Government's health policy, that people should have freedom of choice in an integrated and comprehensive system. That is something the Government wishes to see for all Australians, not the least of whom are the Aboriginal people.

The Officials' Report had proposed that future funding arrangements should be focussed away from State Programs to Aboriginal Medical Services. The proposal evisaged this being done at a predetermined rate or by reference to a set formula. The Government looked carefully at the proposal. We considered these issues when we were drawing up the new arrangements for general health care funding and administration. Conscious of the fact that many Aboriginals are dependent, to some extent, upon the States' general health care systems, we took the view that we should direct more effort into encouraging the States to involve Aboriginals in the planning and provision of all health services to their people. In the case of Aboriginal Medical Services, of course, this is already a settled matter.

Aboriginal advisory body The Commonwealth, for its part, in demonstrating that Aboriginal involvement is so central to Government policy and so crucial to improving Aboriginal health, will seek ways of ensuring that it receives the best possible advice from Aboriginals in relation to Aboriginal health matters. We acknowledge the advice that has been provided from time to time by the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, a federation of Aboriginal Medical Services. However, we also wish to have a more formal arrangement for advice on the whole range of health and health-related problems and needs, including medical needs. We shall therefore discuss, with the National Aboriginal Conference, arrangements to ensure that the Government receives appropriate and comprehensive advice about Aboriginal health, through the Conference. It would be fitting for the National Aboriginal Conference, as an all-Aboriginal elected body, charged with that responsibility of transmitting the views and advice of Aboriginals to the Government, to undertake this special task.

The Parliamentary Report recommended that a new unit be established in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It was proposed that a group of experts on middle level technology should be set up to advise on, amongst other things, the most practical means of providing communal and household facilities in Aboriginal communities.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs is essentially a policy co-ordination and funding body. It does not have specific functional expertise but rather draws on the resources of other departments or agencies when professional advice is needed. The same is true at the State and local levels. Where necessary, private consultants may be engaged.
The Government considers, therefore, that it would not be appropriate or necessary for the proposed special group to be located within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

A second proposal was for an evaluation team to have responsibility for maintaining a check on the effectiveness of Aboriginal health care services and programs, and for the provision of standardised statistics on Aboriginal health.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has in its Central Office structure an Evaluation Branch, which conducts evaluations as an entity distinct from the rest of the Department. That Branch will be able to participate, as it has in the past, in evaluation of programs and projects, in close consultation with Aboriginal people. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs will continue to draw on resources already available, including those in other specialist departments as the need arises in undertaking evaluations against defined objectives. It will be seen, therefore, that the objective of the Standing Committee is capable of achievement under present arrangements.

Aboriginal health statistics The Officials' Report recommended that a national system of Aboriginal health statistics be developed along the lines proposed by Dr L. R. Smith. It recommended that the Department of Health allocate, as a matter of priority, the necessary resources for the system's implementation. The lack of a uniform, national data colletion system, to provide an accurate measure of Aboriginal health status, is a deficiency which cannot be allowed to continue. In order to assess the effectiveness of Aboriginal health programs, including those which will take into account the measures I have outlined, it is essential that we measure Aboriginal health status on a uniform basis. As a matter of priority, I propose to implement a uniform system of national Aboriginal health statistics through the Department of Health. Such a system is absolutely essential for monitoring and evaluation of effectiveness. There have been discussions with State and Northern Territory authorities on this matter in recent years and the co-operation of the States and the Territory will lead to its speedy achievement.

Special national programs Finally, mention must be made of the valuable work done by the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program, undertaken by the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists. The Report highlights many adverse conditions suffered by Aboriginals which both Commonwealth and State Governments must rectify. It also graphicaly illustrates the relationship between environmental and other conditions suffered by Aboriginals and their health status. The Government supports the recommendations from the Report for the continuation of the work commenced by the Trachoma Program and recognises that, without follow-up through both therapeutic and preventive intervention, much of the effort to date may be lost. We are, therefore, taking steps to ensure that the improvements in Aboriginal eye health achieved by the Trachoma program are consolidated by means of effective follow-up and regular reporting.

Commonwealth officials and representatives of the College have met with Northern Territory and Western Australian authorities and the College is hopeful that a re-screening and minor surgery program will be commenced in the Northern Territory shortly. Similar meetings are proposed with other State authorities.

This program, supported by the Commonwealth to the extent of some $2m, has shown us how much improvement can be made, given a concentrated effort. The three reports highlighted prevalent illnesses to which this approach would be suitable. A further group of illnesses, because of their chronic nature, e.g. diabetes, would need to be the subject of long-term care programs. The Government will investigate the need for additional funds for national programs which will have a special focus on prevalent illnesses. We wish to have the advice of Aboriginal people and of the States in determining the needs, appropriate programs and priorities.

Conclusion The matters I have touched on represent the Government's general reactions to the many points made in the three reports. We are determined to play our part in bringing about a substantial improvement in the health of all Aboriginal Australians. As I said earlier, our long-term objective is to raise the level of their health to that of the Australian community generally.

This aim requires the co-operation of the State and Northern Territory Governments, with whom much of the responsibility lies. Of equal importance is the co-operation of the Aboriginal people themselves. Action must be taken now to provide the training needed for Aboriginals to assume wider professional and semi-professional responsibilities in health services and also to expand the roles and skills of existing health workers. This is in addition to the contribution which Aboriginals can and now should make to the planning, administration and evaluation of such services.
We will be reporting to the Government in mid-1982.

Therefore we propose immediately to open discussions with the States and Aboriginal organisations to explore ways of getting on with the job. While not denying the achievements to date, much still remains to be done. We are ready to play our part.

I present a statement showing in detail the Government's responses to the House of Representatives Standing Committee's Report on Aboriginal Health. I ask for leave for it to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs
Report: 'Aboriginal Health'
Recommendations
Response/comment
The Physical Environment-
1. 'The highest priority be given and immediate action taken to provide clean and adequate water supplies to all Aboriginal communities.'

Endorsed. In addition to the ongoing programs of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs which provide housing, water, sanitation and other community services, the Prime Minister announced in his election policy speech a commitment to provide an additional $50m over 5 years to meet highest priority needs for water supplies, sanitation and other environmental improvements.
2. 'A determined effort be undertaken to eliminate as soon as possible the unhygienic sanitary pan system in Aboriginal communities.'
Endorsed. There is a need to provide sewerage systems where these do not exist, and to ensure that the system provided matches the needs of the Aboriginal community.

3. 'An advisory group within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs comprising experts in middle level technology be established, and in consultation with relevant departments and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies to research various options for the provision of community and household facilities; consult with Aboriginal communities to assess their needs; advise them on the most appropriate facilities that best suit their needs; monitor implementation of its advice to communities; facilitate employment of technical advisors by Aboriginal communities; and report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.'

Professional advice on appropriate technology is available to Aboriginal communities and organisations from relevant Government departments and, where appropriate, private consultants. As far as possible, these arrangements are decentralised, to ensure their responsiveness to communities. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs does not itself provide professional expertise and would therefore be an inappropriate location for an advisory body on technology.
4. 'Priority for Aboriginals living in towns and moving into towns away from the fringes, be given to the provision of funds for meeting and upgrading their housing needs.'

Housing accommodation or shelter is a high priority for Aboriginals, not only for those moving into or living in towns. Existing policy affirms the importance of Aboriginal involvement in decisions regarding the number, location, design and arrangement of housing projects. Priority is currently given to the provision of housing for Aboriginals living on reserves.

5. 'The Department of Aboriginal Affairs consult relevant Commonwealth and State departments, local authorities and Aboriginal communities and organisations to define responsibility for safe water, public hygiene services, housing standards and inspection of premises in Aboriginal settlements and communities, particularly fringe camps.'

Endorsed. Such consultations will be part of developing a program for the expenditure of the additional funds committed by the Commonwealth for improvement of the physical environment of Aboriginal communities, as referred to in the comment in recommendation 1 above.
Cultural Factors-

6. 'Aboriginal cultural beliefs and practices which affect their health and their use of health services such as their fear of hospitalisation, their attitudes to pain and surgery, the role of traditional healers and the differing needs and roles of Aboriginal men and women be fully taken into account in the design and implementation of health care programs.'

Endorsed. Current policy supports the adaptation of services and programs to meet adequately the cultural beliefs and lifestyles of Aboriginals. The Government believes that the Standing Committee has correctly identified the major cultural factors affecting Aboriginal health. These will be specifically drawn to the notice of States and the Territory in the course of discussions on Aboriginal health program funding arrangements.
On Health Care Programs-
7. 'Savings to the State-funded health services which result from the Commonwealth-funded State Aboriginal preventive health programs be directed to the further development of preventive programs.'

The Committee's concern that State authorities should accept some financial responsibility for improving the health of Aboriginals is endorsed. The States have already been informed that the Commonwealth expects State Governments to provide at least a pro-rata share of general revenues for Aboriginals in their own programs and those supported by the Commonwealth, and to apply the 'priority of need' principle in all such programs. In the negotiations referred to in comments on recommendations 5 and 6, the matter of joint Commonwealth/State funding will be thoroughly discussed.

8. 'An independent evaluation team responsible to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs be established to evaluate the effectiveness of all Aboriginal health care services and programs in accordance with the World Health Organisation's definition of health and the principles of self-determination, and to establish suitable criteria so that standardised information can be collated and that funds be provided for the purpose where programs are funded by the Government.'

It is agreed that there is a need to standardise criteria for evaluation and to collate information. The Government supports reviews and assessments of Aboriginal health programs, and expects that their conclusions will be used in the modification of existing services and the development of new Aboriginal health services.

The idea of conducting evaluations against the World Health Organisation's definition of health and the principle of self-management is acceptable to the Government as a broad principle. The Government has reservations, however, about the usefulness of evaluations which are conducted without more specific terms of reference or criteria. These only provide evaluation criteria that are very broad and difficult to relate to the very large number of projects which may comprise 'all Aboriginal health care services and programs'.

A structure already exists within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to develop and co-ordinate assessments and program reviews. The Department has within its Central Office an Evaluation Branch which conducts evaluations as an entity distinct from the rest of the Department. The Committee's objective-the establishment of an independent evaluation team-is, therefore, capable of achievement under present arrangements. Aboriginals are to be involved in any evaluation.
9. 'The full range of choice of the various types of programs delivering health care to Aboriginals are maintained and, where appropriate, support increased.'
Endorsed. The degree of increased support will of course depend on available resources and on competing priorities in Aboriginal programs generally.

10. 'Aboriginal communities be given the opportunity to determine the type of health service that will best suit their needs and available resources and that a Task Force be established to place the full range of alternative health care services before them.'

The Government is committed to expansion of Aboriginals' involvement in all aspects of health services affecting them, including in the design, control, management, delivery and evaluation of health services for Aboriginal people. The Government supports the development or expansion of Aboriginal responsibility in relation to State Aboriginal health programs. The recent initiatives of the South Australian and New South Wales Governments in these aspects are examples. In the context of these developments, there is no need for a 'Task Force' approach. Nor does the Government see a centralised body as necessarily the best means of ensuring what the Standing Committee has in mind.
11. 'An inquiry be held into the implementation of the policy of self-determination as it affects community development.'

Not endorsed. The Government's policies aim at Aboriginal self-management and self-sufficiency. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs assesses, on a continual review basis, the impact of the Government's policies and programs in Aboriginal affairs on community development.

12. 'Aboriginals be involved to the fullest possible extent in all stages of the provision of health care services and that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs assess the number of Aboriginals required, the time it will take to train them to assume responsibility for the health of their own people and, to this end, develop, in consultation with relevant Ministers, suitable training programs.'

The principle that Aboriginals should be involved to the fullest possible extent in the provision of health care services for them is strongly supported. The Government also supports the provision of suitable training, whether academic or on-the-job, to ensure the greatest possible Aboriginal participation in health care for Aboriginal people. The Commonwealth has funded training programs for Aboriginal health workers in State Health authorities and stands ready to discuss new initiatives.

The Government is particularly concerned to see the development of Aboriginal health professionals-doctors, dentists, nurses and para-professionals. Special measures may be needed to encourage Aboriginal students to go on such training and Commonwealth Departments will take what steps appear appropriate.

Beyond the measures needed to train and employ suitably qualified Aboriginal people as health professionals, there is also a need to employ Aboriginal people in administrative and clerical positions, at all levels in Commonwealth and State authorities which have responsibilities in relation to Aboriginal health. The Commonwealth Government has taken several steps to ensure these objectives are met and will commend a similar approach to the States.

13. 'Training hospitals for nurses, university medical faculties and other tertiary institutions introduce into their curricula, both at undergraduate and graduate level, a component which deals with Aboriginal health.'

Endorsed. Whilst some hospitals and medical faculties already provide courses or segments on Aboriginal health, there needs to be a concerted effort to ensure that Aboriginal health and related matters are adequately dealt with in medical training institutions. These proposals will be taken up and actively pursued with the Tertiary Education Commission and with appropriate medical learned societies.

14. 'Comprehensive orientation courses be conducted for all non-Aboriginal staff recruited to serve in Aboriginal communities before commencing duty, that they receive regular inservice training, and that a formal diploma or certificate be provided by a tertiary institution for professionals actively involved in providing health care to Aboriginals.'

Orientation and inservice training courses are already provided by most State and some Aboriginal organizations, but there is a need for more comprehensive and more regular training courses for non-Aboriginal staff. The proposal for a formal diploma or certificate course will be pursued in the discussions envisaged in relation to Recommendation 13.

15. 'Governments introduce special allowances and entitlements which recognise the unusual working conditions and the geographical, social and professional isolation experienced by personnel working in predominantly Aboriginal communities in remote areas.'

Health personnel already receive the general standard allowances paid in recognition of isolation and residence in a tropical climate, but they do not receive, in their conditions of service, acknowledgement of the special difficulties they experience. Consultation with the States, Northern Territory and non-government organisations will be necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report documents the numbers of students receiving tertiary assistance, the numbers of appeals being heard, rejected or succeeding, and so on. The overall importance or significance of this report is that it is an illustration of how totally inadequate student assistance is under the Fraser Government and how that inadequacy has been growing worse for the six years that the Fraser Government has been in office. I wish to draw attention to some of the major inadequacies of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme from the point of view of the Federal Opposition. The most significant problems associated with the current operation of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme are the inadequacy of the allowance, the failure to index the allowance, the inappropriate means test cut-off point, the anomalies of the scheme and the rigidities inherent in the regulations.

With regard to the inadequacy of the allowance, I point out that the maximum allowance payable under the scheme is $45.15 a week and is payable only to those students who are classified as independent or who, though classified as dependent, are forced to live away from home and whose parents' combined income does not exceed $9,400 per annum. Even this maximum allowance is grossly inadequate for the basic needs of a student. The inadequacy of the overall amount becomes obvious when it is recognised that the dole-that is, the unemployment benefit-for single adults is $51.45 a week. I think this is a very important point: The Government, through its Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, is virtually forcing students out of the universities and other tertiary institutions and on to the dole. It simply makes no economic sense depriving students of an adequate level of tertiary support to undertake tertiary studies and offering them a positive incentive to drop their tertiary studies and take up the dole. I think that while this positive financial incentive to go on the dole exists the Government's claims that it is really serious about reducing youth unemployment are shown to be absolutely hypocritical. There ought not to be such a positive financial incentive.

As I have said, the policy does not make economic sense. Of course, when we look at the effects of the policy on the skills and resources available within our economy it makes no sense at all in terms of long term manpower planning and economic planning. As I have had cause to point out several times recently in this place, we have a very low level of tertiary skills in the community. We have one of the lowest levels of people engaged in post-secondary education or vocational training of any member country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. That fact alone goes a long way towards explaining the current economic problems that we are experiencing. Similarly, we have one of the lowest levels of student participation of any OECD country. We have one of the lowest ratios of people in the 15 to 25-year age group engaged in education or post-secondary training. Of course, this ratio is significantly lower than the ratio in such countries as Austria, Germany, Japan, Switzerland and Sweden. Again, it explains in a structural way why we have such high levels of youth unemployment.

We have such high levels of youth unemployment simply because the Government is intent on preventing young people from undertaking post-secondary studies. It does this in a variety of ways, but it does it most particularly and most effectively by denying an appropriate level of student assistance. When it makes more economic sense for a young person to go on the dole than to undertake tertiary studies, it can be seen that the Government is actually creating youth unemployment in this country. Then, of course, it has the hypocrisy to condemn the young unemployed for their idleness, slothfulness and so on.

There are other very disturbing features of the current Tertiary Education Allowance Scheme. One is that the TEAS allowance has declined markedly in value since the inception of the scheme in 1974. I will not take the time of the Senate now to document that claim but it will be very clear to honourable senators who compare the maximum TEAS rates with the consumer price index adjustments since 1974 that the current maximum TEAS allowance is $8 below real 1974 levels. Again, that is a demonstration that it is the effect of the Government's policy and the intention of the Government's policy to force young people out of our tertiary institutions and on to the dole. Another problem is the means test cut-off point. In keeping with the basic intention of the scheme, TEAS allowances are means tested on the basis of either the parents' income or, in cases where a student is classified as independent, the student's income. However, the allowance payable subject to the means test has declined under the Fraser Government to such an extent that many genuinely needy students are no longer eligible for the TEAS allowance. If we look at the changes over the past few years relating to the means test of parents' income, we find that the gap between the means test cut-off point and the average male wage is rapidly widening with the result that the number of students eligible under TEAS is systematically decreasing. For example, between July 1974 and July 1975, 53 per cent of TEAS recipients received a maximum allowance compared with only 34.9 per cent in 1978. The figures relating to the means test on a student's income demonstrate that since the scheme's inception an independent student has been able to earn up to $1,500 and still receive the maximum allowance. However, this amount has not been raised since 1974 despite inflation. Furthermore, income earned during the long vacation used to be disregarded but is now included in this $1,500 maximum. The independent rate means test is particularly onerous for mature age students with dependants.

There are many anomalies in the operation of the scheme. Recent surveys have indicated this and have shown that there are many injustices in the scheme as it now operates. Such anomalies are extremely significant insofar as they prevent the scheme from achieving its fundamental goal which is to provide living allowances to all full time tertiary students in financial need. As a result, many students are prevented from undertaking tertiary study while others are studying under conditions of grave financial hardship. On the other hand, there are some students-a very small number-who receive the TEAS allowance and who do not in fact need it. The sorts of areas in which there are very serious anomalies in the current operation of the scheme are the independent status conditions, the regulations relating to the means test and the regulations governing the progress rules of the scheme. All of these, I suggest, require investigation. What needs to be done with regard to the chaos that the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme is in now is an overall reassessment of the scheme. Specifically what needs to be done is the raising of the level of the allowance, the indexation of the allowance, a liberalisation of the means test and, of course, the carrying out of an immediate inquiry into the anomalies and injustices of the scheme. There also needs to be an investigation of the ways of reducing the administrative problems associated with the scheme and an examination of the extent to which the Student Assistance Review Tribunals' discretionary powers should be increased.

These are all specific comments but I would like to make this general comment. The report which has just been tabled needs to be read and studied in the light of the decisions of the Lynch Committee with regard to the Government's intentions to tighten even further the eligibility for the TEAS allowance and to introduce a student loan scheme. I would like to place on record yet again the opposition of the Australian Labor Party to a loan scheme. First of all, it will create a great deal of bureaucracy and administrative red tape in its operation. But more particularly, the students who need the loan scheme are the ones least able to take on the burden of a loan at this particular time of their studies. Such students fall into two categories. They are either students from poor families or families with modest incomes who cannot support them, pay their fees and provide all the back-up expenses for full time student living or they are mature age students-in particular, mature age women who are taking up the option of tertiary education at a later stage in life, who have family responsibilities and who simply cannot add to their existing family responsibilities the burden of a loan. The only people who could confidently take up a loan with no worries at all about how to pay it back are the students from wealthy families who do not need it.

The Opposition is entirely opposed to the introduction of a loan scheme. We are entirely opposed to the further restrictions of eligibility for TEAS and we are opposed to the whole situation which is now being created in our tertiary institutions of the destabilisation of the research programs of all of these universities, of the destabilisation of the teaching program, because many courses will have to be dropped. At Deakin University, for example, the whole faculty of engineering is to be dismantled, and we can repeat that example if we look around tertiary institutions in this country. The availability of education and training to young people entering tertiary institutions will be drastically reduced as a result of the various recommendations of the Lynch review. It is a time when Australia needs all the expertise it can get in terms of technological advance, economic restructuring, the restructuring of adequate social and welfare policies for the 1980s and so forth. I have made these points recently and I do not intend to labour them now. At the very time when Australia's need for expertise is so great, the idiocy of imposing new and greater obstacles to young people and people of mature age undertaking tertiary studies ought to be exposed and condemned.

In conclusion, the Opposition notes the tabling of the 1980 report on the operation of the Student Assistance Act. I repeat that we find that Act and its operation totally inadequate and we call on the Government to take immediate steps to follow the recommendations for increasing and improving the student assistance scheme which I have enumerated.

I have a number of comments to make about the report. Whilst it contains a considerable amount of important data and statistics which relate to the problems of road construction in different areas of constitutional responsibility in Australia, nevertheless when one examines the report in more detail one can only come to the conclusion that it has become not just a report on our roads system but, in fact, an ideological document. So many of the conclusions reached and statements made in the report seek to justify the Fraser Government's whole philosophical concept of returning matters of responsibility to State and local governments and allowing them to determine completely the rate of growth and development of our road system. The Fraser Government seeks to maintain its interest only in a national road system. It is rather alarming to consider the implications of that.

The Commonwealth seeks to change the established practice and procedures upon which Commonwealth funding and responsibilities have existed in the past. One can only draw the conclusion that the Commonwealth is abdicating its responsibilities and leadership in national planning. Parliament has not yet been able to debate properly the recent report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions or, as it is more commonly known, the razor gang report. This report of the Council seeks to justify the Governments philosophical position in these areas by seeking to change the whole process by which road funding has hitherto existed in this country. Whilst it correctly points out that financial responsibility for road construction and maintenance is vested legally with State and local governments and that the Commonwealth has no legal or specific constitutional responsibility to provide financial assistance for roads in the States, nevertheless the report draws attention to the fact that the States are unable properly to fund road construction in this country. Therefore, since 1922 the Commonwealth has accepted the responsibility of providing both tied and untied grants for our road system.

In more recent years the Government has been quite specific about the sorts of roads and classifications of roads, determined as a result of consultations with the States, which ought to have greater priority than in the early days when the Commonwealth accepted financial responsibility for some sectors of road construction works in Australia. The Commonwealth did this because it became very apparent in post-war years that the States used Commonwealth funds in a pork-barrelling and most unsatisfactory way, in a way which enabled State Ministers to aid their cronies in State cabinets and State jurisdictions to respond to pressures to build roads in areas which did not have the priority or the need that would give them preference over other areas.

Of course we all recognise the importance of a road system and we want to see the day when all our roads in Australia are properly constructed, tar sealed and able to perform a proper function in the whole transportation and communication system. But to reach that point surely we must have some system of priorities, some system which operates to the best advantage in terms of trade and population. To that extent obviously urban arterial roads would assume a greater degree of importance than some arterial roads that otherwise might be so classified by the States. Experience in that area prompted the Federal Government to be more specific about responsibility for the expenditure of Commonwealth funds. This report seeks to put back the clock. This report is a change for the worse. The report states that responsibility for the expenditure of Commonwealth funds for road purposes should be left entirely to the States. As the report correctly points out in another section, there is even disputation between the State governments and the local government authorities so far as the provision of funds by the States for local government needs is concerned. If we accept the fact that disputation exists at that level surely we can understand there is a need for a priority system. After all, Commonwealth policies largely determine population growth, for example, immigration policy and the policy on the development of new towns and decentralisation. These are matters in which the Commonwealth has a vested and a vocal interest. I think an error has been made in a philosophical and ideological sense in dealing with this aspect. The report in paragraph 348 states:

The cessation of tied Commonwealth road funding grants would make the States fully responsible for the development of the road system in Australia. It would enable each State to determine its own priorities for roads and to allocate resources accordingly. The Commonwealth's withdrawal from responsibility for national highways would remove any dispute between the Commonwealth and the States as to which roads should be included as national roads.
The report is taking on board the Government's own view, that is, that these matters should best be dealt with by giving the responsibility back to the States. To prove that point the report states:
Such a move would be consistent with the concept of functions being provided by the sphere of government as close as possible to the people.

Nobody would disagree that these sorts of functions should be provided at the State level. In relation to functions which involve large sums of money such as the thousands of millions of dollars that are involved in this five-year program surely the Commonwealth is entitled to say to the States that there is a need for a classification and system of priorities instead of just leaving the decisions to be made on the basis of narrow parochialism or concepts even though they rightfully may appear to belong to State jurisdictions because State concepts bear no relationship to national government concepts.

As has been pointed out, motorist organisations and other groups are concerned about this whole question of inadequate Commonwealth road grants for the improvement of the whole of the Australian transport system. In correspondence sent to me, and I presume to other honourable senators, by the Australian Automobile Association as recently as 22 May this year, attention was drawn to the fact that between 1955 and 1973 Commonwealth road grants to the States averaged 2.73 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays; in 1973 the grants averaged 2.59 per cent; they dropped to 1.78 per cent in the 1979-80 Budget and a further drop of 1.74 per cent is estimated in the Budget for the current financial year. As the Association pointed out, the Commonwealth's contribution to the national road program has declined from 32.2 per cent in 1974-75-during the Whitlam Government period-to 27.3 per cent in 1978-79. It has declined in real terms over that period and at a time when the Commonwealth has dramatically increased Commonwealth revenue as a result of the oil levy-in excess of $2,000m in the current Budget. Whilst the report represents Commonwealth, State and local government interests, it finishes up adopting this so-called concept of small government, that is, the Commonwealth abdicating responsibility in the matter of road construction nationally by handing responsibility over to the States.

It is no wonder that motorist organisations are saying that they are particularly concerned at the paucity of Commonwealth funding for roads especially in view of the very large sums of additional revenue arising from the Government's crude oil pricing policy being appropriated to Consolidated Revenue. The Commonwealth has reduced the level of funds for roads, as the Association points out. The projected increase in funds over the five-year period drops from 11.2 per cent in the Budget period 1980-81 to only 6 per cent in the Budget period proposed in the five-year program to 1984-85-a period in which we know that inflation and road costs will rise quite considerably. One is entitled to draw the conclusion that the report in no way properly appreciates the need for a planned development of our road systems. The Commonwealth still accepts its responsibilities in respect of a national roads system, but I ask honourable senators to look at the number of fatalities and accidents that occur on our roads. We know the cost in human resources and energy that is brought about by having an inadequate roads system. I fail to see how this report deals with these sorts of problems.

The report ignores completely the Commonwealth's responsibility for urban arterial roads. Therefore in that sense it is a very inadequate report even though so much of its general collection of information is very valuable. Whilst the report deals with the differences between the States as to the way in which their road funding systems operate the report came to, I believe, quite inadequate conclusions that the Advisory Council, which is the body that brought down the report, considers that the Commonwealth should be involved in road funding in one form or another. Is the Commonwealth to be interested only in a national roads system? Will it be concerned about our main and our urban arterial roads? Will not it be concerned about our substantial secondary road systems? The report did not come to any conclusion in respect of those questions. To that extent the Opposition would say the report is totally inadequate in terms of the problems of road construction in a period when road construction costs are increasing dramatically and in a period when inflation is not being taken into account in the allocation of funds. Whilst we of the Opposition recognise that the Commonwealth will be bringing down legislation to implement a number of the recommendations of this Council, probably during this session, we will have much more to say at that time about the matter. In the meantime, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
