DEBATE.TITLE: THIRD UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE LAW OF THE SEA-NINTH SESSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

In moving this motion I remind the Senate that the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea has undoubtedly been one of the most important international negotiating ventures ever undertaken, certainly in the history of the United Nations. Perhaps it has been one of the most important diplomatic excercises ever, in the sense of the importance of the issues involved, the number of state parties that have been involved in it, and the productiveness of the enterprise that has so far resulted, or at least had resulted up until the conclusion of the Ninth Session, which is documented in part of the papers before us today. As a result of more than 10 years of negotiations, the last seven of which have been largely occupied in a series of Conference sessions, we have seen the emergence of a treaty, supported by Australia, which would recognise that the resources of the sea, at least outside the 320-kilometre economic zone, were 'the common heritage of mankind'.

We had an agreement, in the penultimate draft text of the treaty, whereby an international authority would impose a royalty on companies mining the potentially rich nodules of nickle, cobalt, manganese and copper on the ocean floor, with the proceeds of the royalty, expected to run into many billions of dollars, then being distributed to developing countries. The treaty was to provide for, amongst other things, the establishment of rules of passage through and over waters of other nations and through straits used for international navigation. They are just some of the features of it. It is an enormously complex document in the draft form in which it has emerged. So far, so good.

It was indeed expected that in the tenth session of the Conference due to start in New York in March all those enormous labours by so many people over so long a period would in fact have borne fruit in a properly adopted final treaty. But that is, of course, where the United States stepped in under the new Reagan Administration. The ministerial statement which accompanies the report before us today describes in a straight-faced kind of a way-indeed it might even be said to be a po-faced kind of a way-what has undoubtedly been one of the most outrageous, and also underreported, bits of international misbehaviour ever perpetrated by any country. I refer to the behaviour of the United States after all these years of treaty negotiations in simply turning its back on the Conference, refusing to take any further part in it until it conducted a full review of its own domestic position, at the same time, incidentally, sacking the team of seven diplomats who had been working professionally on this treaty for a very long period. The reaction that was created by that United States' reaction can scarcely be underestimated in its intensity so far as the rest of the nations of the world are concerned. The whole atmosphere was rather colourfully described in an article in the Melbourne Herald by Bruce Wilson on 10 March 1981. He wrote:
After nine years of planning and seven years of interminable diplomatic manoeuvres, the International Law of the Sea Conference has been suddenly torpedoed by President Ronald Reagan.
Referring to the exercise over the years, he went on:
This had been basically the foreplay to a final act of consummation to have resumed today--
That is 10 March, 1981-
at the United Nations in New York.
Now, the six-week-long final act-as solemn and cumbrous as the lovemaking of a great sea turtle-has been cruelly interrupted by Mr Reagan.

That puts it colourfully but it certainly does not put it inaccurately. The interruption of the developing consensus around the whole law of the sea issue was a very spectacular interruption indeed because this is not a treaty which it was ever anyone's intention to adopt other than by consensus. It was not simply a matter of a majority vote in the United Nations. It was from the outset to be a matter to be resolved from consensus and that laboriously patched together consensus has now, as I said, been cruelly interrupted by the behaviour of the United States. The motives for the United States behaviour are not very difficult to fathom. The reason is simply that the United States seems not prepared under its new administration-although it certainly was under previous administrations-to accede to the notion that the seabed resources are the common heritage of mankind. Rather, the view is taken, apparently, that they amount to the heritage of the United States, and that they are there to be exploited not in the interests of mankind but rather in the interests of those major deep sea mining multinationals, four of the five of whom which presently operate in a significant way world wide are in fact wholly or substantially American owned. The Reagan Administration has come under acute pressure from those United States mining interests to do more to protect their interests in the exploitation of the seabed resources. It is on that crude, parochial basis, taking no account of the larger interests of mankind, that this action has been taken. I note that the Australian reaction has been pointed when this act of spectacular international misbehaviour, as I have described it, was perpetrated. The Australian position was put by Mr Keith Brennan, the ambassador who has played such a central role in the development of the whole Law of the Sea Conference for so many years, in a masterly understatement when he said that the United States attitude was 'potentially unsettling'.

Indeed it is a very understated reaction that appears in the ministerial statement before us today. But at least the terms of that statement leave in no doubt, I believe, the Government's attitude to the United States behaviour. I indicate that the Government has the full support of the Opposition in the further steps that it may take to restore some sanity and some credibility to what presently is the United States response, which lacks both of those characteristics. I cannot spend any more time on this matter at this stage. A number of other points, however, could and perhaps should be made about this very important issue. I think many of them were very admirably made in an editorial in the Canberra Times of 14 May 1981. LAW OF THE SEA

President Reagan's administration, having flexed its muscles to delay finalisation of the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference, is expected to face concerted attempts by the Third World and some developed nations to get it to adhere to the negotiated text. The stakes are high, as it is the final division of the finite resources of this globe.

The convention was laboriously negotiated between 150 nations over the past eight years and arrived at by consensus, an illustration of international co-operation and good faith. The 10th session of the conference, which was due to be the penultimate, has ended inconclusively in New York and will be resumed in Geneva in August; but the United States has stated that it will not regard it as the final session. The US decision has seriously disrupted the work of delegates and is a most unfortunate unilateral abrogation of the achievements of the negotiations.

The virtually completed draft of the convention sets out the rules to govern exploitation of the fishing and mineral riches of the sea and seabed and the rights of navigation and overflights. It provides also for a massive transfer of technology from the developed to the developing nations. This technology is concerned with deep-sea oil and gas exploitation and seabed mining. The provision in the convention for compulsory transfer of this technology to an international authority and its further transfer to competing countries is one of the sticking points for the US, which has most of the technology.

The US is unhappy also about the provision for limits on production of the minerals on the seabed-manganese, cobalt, copper and zinc. This provision went in as a result of pressure by land-based producers of these minerals, particularly Canada, which feared a glut on the world market. The US is in a vulnerable situation with most of these minerals, which are essential to its industry and arms. It imports 82 per cent of its cobalt needs from Zaire, and jet engines cannot be manufactured without cobalt. It imports 72 per cent of its manganese from nations such as Gabon and South Africa, and manganese is an essential ingredient of steel. It imports 77 per cent of its nickel, mostly from Canada, and Canada strongly supports the present text of the convention.
Developing nations

At present the world supply of all the minerals involved is adequate, so the profitability of seabed mining is problematical. Nevertheless, the resources are finite, and present exploitation of the seabed would give the US an alternative to politically vulnerable sourcues and would help its balance of payments.

In the background to the US action against the law of the sea convention is the pressure of the mining and manufacturing companies which stand to benefit most from free, unshared access to the seabed resources and lack of artificial ceilings on production.

It was in this context that Australia not so long ago suddenly switched from support for the Canadian position of production ceilings to protect land-based producers to the position favoured by the US. The Australian position was changed after direct representation by CRA and other mining interests. Australia is less happy though about the US delay to the convention, which the Federal Government still regards as an equitable approach to the sharing of resources and development of the Third World.

The developing nations are reluctant to see this transfer of technology and resources slip away from them and already the Singaporean president of the law of the sea assembly, Mr Koh, who has just assumed the office, has made these objections plain. He expressed what is probably the prevailing view outside the US administration, that the US had all along willingly taken part in the negotiations under different administrations and had not dissented to such concepts as the riches of the sea being the heritage of all men.

Mr Koh justly pointed out that the convention, which reached its final form entirely by consent, without votes having to be taken, had achieved important targets, of great benefit to the big maritime nations such as the US. These included a system of control and regulation of the ''creeping jurisdiction'' which was formerly pushing out territorial limits and sea zones in a haphazard fashion and the guaranteed rights to overflight and to passage through straits.

Large fishing nations such as Japan, while perhaps initially very worried about possible damage to their distant fishing, have come to appreciate the benefits of access under licence and joint projects.

Commodity-dependent, technology-oriented nations such as those in Western Europe, particularly West Germany and Britain, look with particular concern at what has happened to the convention. They are very aware that the US has already put through unilateral legislation to allow seabed mining and it would not be surprising if they followed suit. What this would mean would be a greedy grab by those best equipped technically for the difficult task. While this would agree with President Reagan's philosophy of free market forces deciding economic issues, one certain result would be to push the weakest-the developing nations-even further to the wall. There would be high human and political costs in such a course and the US should exert its known good sense to get the administration of President Reagan back on course and steering for an early approval of the present draft of the convention. The rule of law, the cornerstone of American freedoms and of international life, demands no less.

SPEECH.PARA: The Advance to the Minister for Finance is a centrally controlled contingency fund which is available for use by the Government for emergency purposes. Although the total amount for the Advance is appropriated, a government may spend amounts from the Advance where there has been no specific prior parliamentary appropriation. The principle of prior parliamentary appropriation of government expenditure is, of course, enshrined in section 83 of the Constitution and is of considerable concern to honourable senators.

The Committee found that the criteria given for the use of the Advance varied in several ways in ministerial statements, the Finance Directions and other relevant sources. We recommend that these confusing criteria be clarified by adopting one set of criteria only, that is, that the use of the Advance be permitted in 'urgent and unforeseen circumstances'. We believe the adoption of this set of criteria will on the one hand give the Government the flexibility to use the Advance for emergencies where necessary but on the other hand protect the principle of prior parliamentary appropriation. I therefore welcome the Government's acceptance of our recommendation.

The Committee also welcomes the inclusion, in the Schedules to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) of 1980-81, of a clause which provides that the expenditure be urgent and unforseen, thereby putting these criteria on a legislative footing.

One of the Committee's major worries was the ability of a government to commence major new expenditure programs from the Advance and then present the Parliament with a fait accompli at appropriation time. We concluded that the best way to prevent this would be to improve the disclosure of expenditure from the Advance so that the Parliament could learn earlier and in greater detail where the money was being spent.

Disclosure has been improved in two ways. Firstly, the funds which have already been provided from the Advance will be shown more clearly in the appropriation Bills explanations. The procedure has already been implemented in relation to the 1980-81 Budget Estimates. Secondly, a statement of approvals of expenditure from the Advance will be published more regularly than in the past. This statement will show all expenditure which requires the creation of a new appropriation item and expenditure above $50,000 in other cases. The publication of this information at approximately monthly intervals during parliamentary sittings can only enhance the Parliament's scrutiny of the expenditure from the Advance.

Finally, the Committee notes that the Government did not accept its recommendation for a limit to be placed on the amount appropriated for the Advance. Nevertheless the Committee will continue to keep a close watch on the total amount appropriated to the Advance and if it exceeds the levels suggested in our report as appropriate, the Committee will draw this to the attention of the Parliament and consider what further action may be necessary as a result. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make the statement and thank the Minister for the Government's response and acceptance of almost all of our recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-A number of recent reports of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances have considered different aspects of the disallowance provisions in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and other Acts. This is a technical area of the law, but one of importance. The Government recognises the important role which the Committee plays in monitoring the more technical aspects of delegated legislation and acknowledges the important contribution made to the development of this area of the law by the Committee's recent reports. I am, therefore, pleased to be able to announce that the Government intends to take action to give effect to a number of the Committee's recommendations on matters relating to parliamentary disallowance of delegated legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In its 66th report the Committee recommended that the common law rule of revival should, by statute, be applied to the parliamentary disallowance of all instruments. The common law rule of revival is that the repeal of an Act, which has repealed an earlier Act, has the effect of reviving the earlier repealed Act. The common law rule has been reversed by the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. There is, however, some doubt as to the application of the Acts Interpretation Act provisions to parliamentary disallowance of a repealing regulation.

There is a clear distinction between statutory repeal of legislation and parliamentary disallowance. In the case of statutory repeal, appropriate transitional or consequential provisions may be made, whereas a House of the Parliament that disallows a regulation may do no more than nullify the provision tabled before it. In the absence of a revival rule, disallowance can create a legislative void. As the Committee has pointed out, absence of a revival rule also means that a House of the Parliament is effectively unable to prevent the repeal of an instrument which that House may not wish to have repealed. The Committee's recommendation has drawn attention to an uncertainty which should be removed. Accordingly, the Government has decided to introduce amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to implement the Committee's recommendation.

In its 68th report, the Committee recommended that, for the effective parliamentary control of delegated legislation, certain provisions found in Part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 should be incorporated in all disallowance provisions, unless there were good reasons for variation. The provisions to which the Committee addressed its attention are those which provide that-
(a) a regulation must be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of its making;
(b) a motion for disallowance must be dealt with within 15 sitting days or the regulation is deemed to be disallowed;
(c) where a motion for disallowance is unresolved at the end of a session, the regulation in question is deemed to be laid before the House concerned on the first day of the next session; and
(d) regulations the same in substance as disallowed regulations cannot be made within six months after disallowance without the approval of the disallowing House.

An increasing number of Acts of the Parliament now include provisions for the making of instruments of a legislative character which are subject to disallowance. There is also a growing diversity amongst such instruments. There are, for example, statements of the principles in accordance with which quotas are to be determined under the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977, orders approving administrative procedures for the purpose of achieving the objects of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and zoning plans under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Part Act 1975.

The Government is committed to the principle that these instruments of delegated legislation should be subject to review by the Parliament. In accordance with that commitment, it has been willing to take steps to refine the review and disallowance procedures when this has proved necessary. With the increasing number and diversity of provisions relating to statutory instruments, there is a need to take stock of the position and assess whether a uniform approach is possible and practicable. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that the Government accepts the substance of the Committee's recommendations.

Future provisions for the disallowance of statutory instruments will, unless there are good reasons for variation, incorporate the substance of the four principles recommended by the Committee. The Government additionally proposes that, unless there are good reasons for variation, the two other requirements in Part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 will also be incorporated in future disallowance provisions. These two requirements are that regulations be notified in the Gazette and that they do not have a retrospective operation which adversely affects the rights of a person other than the Commonwealth. The Government will also be making a careful study of existing disallowance provisions to bring those into line with the commitment I have made today. I hope that it will be possible to bring forward amendments to do this at the same time as the other amendments announced in this Statement.

Last year the Committee drew my attention to the suggestion it made in its 50th report concerning the status of a notice of motion for disallowance which remains on the Senate Notice Paper when the House of Representatives only is dissolved. Sub-section 48 (5A) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that, where a notice of motion for the disallowance of regulations has not been disposed of at the end of a session of the Parliament, the regulations in question are deemed to be laid before the relevant House on the first sitting day of the next session. The sub-section operates in relation to the Senate only where the Parliament is prorogued or the Senate is dissolved and does not deal with the case where such a notice is pending before the Senate when the House of Representatives only is dissolved. There is accordingly some doubt as to the status of a notice in such a case. A similar problem exists in relation to disallowance provisions in other legislation.

The Government has decided to introduce amendments of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, and the disallowance provisions of other Acts, to provide that where a notice of motion for disallowance of a regulation is pending before the Senate when the House of Representatives is dissolved, the regulation in question shall be deemed to have been tabled in the Senate on the first sitting day of the Senate after the dissolution of the House of Representatives. The amendments, which are long overdue, will ensure that the powers of the Senate in respect of disallowance are properly protected. The necessary legislation to give effect to the Government's decisions that I have announced in this statement will be introduced as soon as the legislative timetable permits.

However, there are one or two points which I should like to bring to the notice of honourable senators. Although it is responding to the House of Representative's Standing Committee's report, the Government has also had before it two other important reports on Aboriginal health. The other reports are the trachoma report and an internal report on the program effectiveness review of Aboriginal health. All these reports show that Aboriginal health is unacceptably low. We must do more to bring about the improvements that are so urgently needed. My colleague' statement gives details of the measures we propose and I shall mention them only briefly.

Firstly, there is general agreement that the environment in which Aboriginal people live must be improved. My Department has funded programs over a number of years in housing and community management and services. We will continue with these programs. The Government's election commitment to a five-year program to improve environmental health will be vigorously pursued. Indeed, in the short time available, my Department has developed projects totalling $10m which will begin in 1981-82. These are urgently needed projects throughout Australia. The special environmental health program represents the Government's basic commitment to the provision of at least clean water and waste disposal facilities for Aboriginal communities still needing them.

We recognise that improvements in Aboriginal health flowing from environmental improvements will take some time. Therefore, we have also closely examined the effectiveness of present programs for Aboriginal health care. Our fundamental concern here has been to improve the acceptability of the present range of services in the eyes of Aboriginal people themselves. It is not much good saying that a health care service is available if Aboriginal people do not feel able to make use of it. Therefore we are seeking discussions with the States and the Northern Territory to redefine objectives for the provision of health care to Aboriginal people. We are seeking increased Aboriginal involvement in the design, control, management, delivery and evaluation of health services affecting them.

The reports before us all make it clear that Aboriginal medical services have been very acceptable to Aboriginal people themselves. Their role is increasing in importance and we shall be holding discussions with the States against this background. The Government, for its part, wishes to have the benefit of Aboriginal advice on matters relating to Aboriginal health. Therefore I shall be asking the National Aboriginal Conference to discuss with me ways in which, through it, the Government receives appropriate advice on Aboriginal health.

I should also mention briefly the announcement last week of Professor Hollows's resignation from the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program. He gave as his reason the supposed Commonwealth handover of responsibility for Aboriginal health. He too has been misinformed. I acknowledge the excellent work Professor Hollows and his team have done. I hope he will now reconsider his position. I commend the statement of the Minister for Health to the Senate. I particularly invite honourable senators to give consideration to the Government's detailed response to each of the specific recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee's report.

The Government's response, statistics apart, states only what is being done, which has been proved inadequate. About the long term health of Aboriginal people, Mr MacKellar stated:
Once preventive measures begin to take effect, succeeding generations will not be saddled to the same extent with the wide spectrum of diseases . . .

This statement assumes that preventive measures are now being taken-something which I hasten to inform the Minister is not happening in many places. For example, in February I visited the Northern Territory and spoke to the Director of Health, Dr Charles Gurd. I was disturbed to find that nobody in the Northern Territory Health Department was specifically employed in preventive health programs. Similarly I recently visited most remote Aboriginal communities in the Kimberleys area. I was informed by medical people working in that area and, indeed, by Aboriginal health workers themselves that there is no preventive health program operating in the Kimberleys. For example, there are no properly trained Aboriginal health workers to take preventive health measures in remote Aboriginal communities. Certainly, there are Aboriginal people in these communities who are called Aboriginal health workers. They have received in some cases three weeks training and are supposed to go back into their communities and run an Aboriginal health program. So in Western Australia and the Northern Territory no adequate preventive health program is in progress. I very much doubt whether there is such a program in any other part of Australia.

In Mr MacKellar's response it is stated that the government wishes to encourage the development of programs which serve the whole community rather than segregating services. I think this is a false argument and a rather weak way of attacking the Aboriginal controlled health services. My information is that most services will treat non-Aboriginal patients and that in many places they are more popular than institutionalised services. In Broome, on the north-west coast of Australia, a large number of white people go to the Aboriginal-run health service because the nature of the service-it is community controlled and so on-makes it more acceptable than the State bureaucracy with which the people would otherwise have to deal. It would seem that the Government could learn a lesson from this. I think the entire population is happier and more comfortable dealing with community-run health services, for primary health care at least, than with the State bureaucracies or private practitioners who are, of course, very insensitive on these matters. The MacKellar statement, in dealing with the professional qualifications of Aboriginal people, provides:
We propose to have discussions on a number of fronts to make sure that Aboriginals have greater opportunities in those areas.

Given the various education decisions that have been made in recent times the opportunities for Aboriginal people to get into formal and conventional medical training are disappearing rapidly. Australia does not have one trained Aboriginal doctor. Not one person of Aboriginal descent is a doctor.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a final year medical student, or two.
—I am glad to hear that there are medical students. I have met one.
—They are at the end of their training. It is just an interesting point.

—I am glad to hear that, but I hope that the Minister is not putting it forward as a panacea for the problem I have just enunciated. The Government states that it will hold discussions. Surely the existence of four major reports documenting health problems, the lack of trained workers and the inadequacies of various State services is enough. Surely it is time to spend some money and to develop some programs if we are to come to terms with this problem. The Government has had the Ruddock report for 18 months. Its only response to some of the major recommendations is that it will hold discussions.

SPEECH.PARA: On the major issue identified by the Program Effectiveness Review-it stated that future funding arrangements should be focused away from State programs to Aboriginal medical services-the Government has refused to take the action recommended. This has happened despite the fact that the review clearly identifies State Aboriginal health programs as the major area where money is wasted. The results are poor. The review identified areas of policy difference which exist between the Commonwealth and the States and referred to State policies conflicting with the Commonwealth view that self-management can be pursued concurrently with the training of Aboriginal people in health care.

When we look at funding for Aboriginal health we understand why we have such a serious situation. Total funding in 1979-80 was $205m. The Aboriginal usage of health related programs amounted to $123m. Aboriginal usage of general health programs was $62m. That figure compares with $2,667m for the whole population. Aboriginal usage of general health programs is only 2.3 per cent of that total. Expenditure on specific Aboriginal health programs amounts to $20m. Of the $62m spent on general health programs most is transferred to State health authorities, hospitals and doctors through bulk billing arrangements. Special Aboriginal health programs operating through State authorities were allocated $13.4m in State grants in the last financial year. In the last financial year 17 Aboriginal medical services received financial support. During that year medical services extended access to an estimated 40 per cent-that is 72,500-of the Aboriginal population. This involved an estimated 120,000 patient contacts. Department of Aboriginal Affairs grants-in-aid to Aboriginal medical services in 1979-80 were $2.9m. Surely those figures demonstrate the cost effectiveness of the Aboriginal medical services. A mere $2.9m goes from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the Aboriginal health services which have a very high patient usage and, by all reports, a very effective delivery of service. We must compare this with the millions of dollars which go to State agencies which are failing.

Surely the message to the Federal Government ought to be clear. Another extraordinary and anomalous situation concerns the employment of Aboriginal personnel in Aboriginal health services. Of the 659 staff employed in State grants programs there were 26 non-Aboriginal doctors, three non-Aboriginal dentists, 241 non-Aboriginal nurses and five Aboriginal nurses. Some 40 per cent of staff are Aboriginal. Of these, 90 per cent were employed as health workers and operational and field support staff of various kinds, that is, non-professional services. If the Government is serious about creating employment opportunities for Aboriginal people it is clear that health funding should be directed to Aboriginal medical services. If the Government is serious about taking effective steps to deal with the crisis in Aboriginal health, surely it should act on the one basic and clear structural recommendation of the Program Effectiveness Review which was that where State agencies are failing, as they clearly are, federal money should be withdrawn from them and redirected to the one kind of health program which we know is working, and that is the directly federal funded Aboriginal controlled health services. That really is my concluding point.

I was very concerned and distressed to note that in the statement which has just been tabled the Minister took the opportunity, I believe, to be unfairly critical of the Fitzroy Aboriginal Health Service. I am very well aware that there have been problems in the administration of that service. Of course there will be problems in a service which is attempting a virtually impossible task with few resources. I feel that it is not in the interests of developing effective Aboriginal health services for the Minister to criticise in such terms a service which is doing what all of the reports say ought to be done, and that is attempting to develop Aboriginal participation and control in effective Aboriginal health services. I think the Minister has revealed himself and his Government in their true light and has shown hostility to Aboriginal-controlled health services by his absolutely inflammatory comments on the Fitzroy Aboriginal Health Service. I condemn the Minister for doing so. I repeat that the statement is weak and inadequate. It contains no specific details and does not address the basic problem. Until such time as the Federal Government is prepared to act according to its constitutional responsibility and to take direct steps to improve Aboriginal health in this country, surely the problem will continue to be a national and international scandal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise to support my colleague Senator Ryan in her comments on the statement by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). As she said, the statement is very short on detail. I say, as my colleague did not, that it is very long on rhetoric. This statement has been awaited avidly by members of parliament and the Press in the last couple of weeks because of the resignations, as Senator Baume, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, pointed out, of Professor Hollows and Mr Gordon Briscoe from the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program. This development created a stir because Professor Hollows said that he was concerned that the Federal Government was handing over to what he described as racist States, the very people who nearly succeeded in the genocide of Aboriginals throughout Australia, too much of the health programs concerned with improving the lot of these people throughout our nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Hollows was described by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs as acting in a crazy way. He questioned whether Professor Hollows was fair dealing or stunting and described his actions as irresponsible and political. Apart from the irony-I do not quite know what it is-of a professional politican referring in a perjurative sense to someone acting in a political way, I think Professor Hollows has been badly treated by Senator Baume in his remarks. Professor Hollows expressed the concerns of many people in this community. Nothing in the Minister's statement in this place or in the statement by the Minister for Health in another place leads us to believe that Professor Hollows has done anything but the responsible thing in this matter. Professor Hollows described several problems in his Press statement and Press conferences last week. He expressed concern about the lack of support for Aboriginal controlled health services in the community and drew attention to the low level of Commonwealth funding of these services compared with other health services. Secondly, he expressed concern over the inadequacy of the support for and the hostility to such Aboriginal controlled and community controlled schemes by State governments, in particular the State governments of Western Australia and Queensland.

He drew attention to the inadequacy of existing State health departments in handling the affairs of Aboriginal health. Thirdly, he expressed concern about the attitudes of the States, again in particular the States of Western Australia and Queensland, to the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program in which he played such an important part. He pointed out that he had no intention of abandoning the Aborigines under these circumstances and that he would continue to work as best he could with the Aboriginal health services where they were effective and relevant to the Aboriginals' problems. Yet this honourable man who has taken such an interest in this matter in recent years has been described as taking part in the craziest action that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has ever seen. He is described by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs as taking part in a stunting exercise.

No one in this place needs to be reminded that the situation of Aboriginal health in this community is a disgrace. In particular the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs need not be reminded of this. After all, he is on the record in his statement today and in repeated speeches in this and other places as describing the situation of Aboriginal health in this community as being in a deplorable state. Indeed, he quite rightly takes some responsibility for the setting up of the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program. When this program was set up, and when the report on the program came down giving the appalling results of its survey of Aboriginal affairs in the community, Senator Baume, like everyone else in this place, expressed considerable concern at the appalling situation which exists not only as far as trachoma is concerned but also as far as syphillis, leprosy, nutritional disorders, middle ear disorders in children and nasal and respiratory disorders in children are concerned. No one needs to be reminded that in some areas in fact the incidence of trachoma reaches as much as 90 per cent to 100 per cent, and in the best areas 20 per cent to 30 per cent of the community is affected.

After the trachoma survey team carried out surveys on some 100,000 patients in the community, after it treated some tens of thousands of them with chemotherapy and some lesser number with surgery, the report came out. Everyone in this place was appalled. Every newspaper in this country was appalled. Senator Baume expressed his concern and has continued to express his concern since that time. But the reaction of what Professor Hollows describes as some racist governments was different from the reaction of honourable senators in this place. In Queensland we know that Mr Bjelke-Petersen and his colleagues severely criticised the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program and demanded the resignation of some members of the staff of that program, against the protest of Professor Hollows and others, and loudly proclaimed that Professor Hollows was telling us nothing new and that in fact the States had the program in hand. In Western Australia the program came under considerable attack and we had the first indication that Senator Baume may not agree with Professor Hollows and his colleagues when he said, as recorded in the Hansard of 2 December 1980:
I do not think anyone would want to argue with the observations of the College . . .
That is, the Royal College of Ophthalmologists. He continued:

If I read its report correctly it was actually on my suggestion that it did this. The argument that emerges is whether its proposal for implementing a program of treatment is the one that should be followed, or whether alternative proposals within the systems of health care of the State governments could do the job equally well.
One can imagine Professor Hollows' and his colleagues' concern at that statement-a concern that was expressed by other people in this place.

The deplorable situation of Aboriginal health in this country, which is related not only to the organisms which cause the diseases, but also to the nutrition, to the adequacy of their health services, their education housing and everything else, is the direct responsibility of the neglect of the State governments of this country in the past. In 1967 everyone in this community believed that the passing of the referendum at that time meant that there would be a new deal for Aboriginals, particularly as far as health was concerned, because it was going to be the responsibility of the Commonwealth, it was going to be a national responsibility, and the Commonwealth was going to introduce programs which were special programs, because the position of Aboriginal health is a very special case. When a group in the community has seven times the incidence of blindness, when a group in the community has many times the incidence of respiratory and nutritional diseases as does the Aboriginal community, it needs a very special program to combat these things. It needs a program which is directed by people who are not involved in local parochial or racist views; it needs the sort of program which was suggested by Professor Hollows and his colleagues in the report of the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program which we examined in this place last year.

All through the statement of the Minister for Health, even when he is mouthing words of support about increasing Aboriginal involvement in health affairs in this country, he refers to the way in which we must induce the States to co-operate, the way in which we must encourage the States. I refer to page 9 of the statement which reads:
To achieve this goal-
That is, to provide greater opportunities for Aborigines to play a significant role in this area-
increasing numbers of Aboriginals will have to be trained for, and employed at, all levels . . . The way each State government meets this goal may be different.

Time and time again in this statement we go back to the situation about which Professor Hollows complained in the past, namely, that we are going to do this by encouraging the States to spend money and co-operate with the Federal Government. They have failed to do this in the past and at present they are hostile to this approach, with the exception of probably New South Wales and Victoria. There is no indication that they will change their attitude. There is no indication that we will have an effective trachoma treatment plan in Western Australia in view of the critical words of the Western Australian Minister for Health about Professor Hollows, about the Federal Government, about the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs and about his colleagues. We cannot expect them to do any better and they will not do any better because they are philosophically opposed to this sort of approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. They don't like blacks, obviously.

—As Senator Walsh says-I will not repeat his words-they are racist in their attitude to their own citizens. What the Minister for Health is saying to us in this statement-this is what Professor Hollows is complaining about-is 'We recognise that we have a special responsibility for Aborigines but we cannot do anything because we are hamstrung by the States, because we must co-operate with the States, we must co-operate with the Queensland Government which is against the outstation movement, we must co-operate with the Western Australian Government which is against the national trachoma program and which considers its own trachoma program'-it is demonstrated by this statement to be an abysmal failure-'has been a successful program'. What he is saying is that we must have more of the same again. The 'same again' means a continuation of the deplorable state of health of the Aborigines in this community. The 'same again' means in fact a deterioration of the health of Aborigines; it means no correction of the causes of their ill health, which are pointed out in this and the other reports mentioned by Senator Ryan. Therefore, we are disappointed, and share the disappointment of Professor Hollows and Mr Briscoe, with the attitude of this Government. I believe every Aboriginal and every knowing and thoughtful white person in this community will be equally disappointed.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There is little indication in the two statements, from the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), that the Commonwealth Government proposes to tackle the overall problem of Aboriginal health any better now than it has done in the past. Professor Hollows expressed fears of a shuffling off of responsibility to the States. That seems to me, on an initial reading of these statements, especially that of the Minister for Health, to be only too well founded. It is a fact that many people who work in this whole area are disillusioned. I have spoken with some of them. Those people feel that our disgraceful record in regard to our treatment of the whole Aboriginal problem-it is a problem of great proportions-will continue. That problem-particularly concerning health-is known internationally and has been for some time, to this country's discredit. From these statements it appears that that situation will continue into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course Aboriginal health can be improved. It does not need the high sounding objective which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs gave at the bottom of page 2 of his statement. He stated:
Therefore we are seeking discussions with the States and the Northern Territory to re-define objectives for the provision of health care to Aboriginal people.

Those objectives do not need to be redefined. Heaven knows, the problems are clear and stark enough. I suggest that the solutions are quite obvious-more money, more expertise and more effort. When one talks to those dedicated public servants-State government and Commonwealth officers who are working in this area-that is the story one gets. From time to time I have had occasion to raise a matter which, to my great distress, is not mentioned at all as far as I can see in any of the statements and that is the problem of continued leprosy in Australia among our Aboriginal people, particularly in West Australia. The Northern Territory and Queensland to their credit I think have made some efforts to deal with this problem, although in Queensland a great deal more money could be spent. I suggest it is ridiculous and absurd that in the 20th century a country which describes itself as a modern, enlightened, Western society should still have this mediaeval disease. I suggest that this is unnecessary when a little more effort and a little more money would eliminate the problem. That epitomises the problem. The top of page 3 of Senator Baume's statement reads:
We are seeking increased Aboriginal involvement in the design, control, management, delivery and evaluation of health services affecting them.

Of course he means affecting Aborigines. I really hope that that is the case. Last week Miss Val Bryant and Mr Jim Carroll from the Bennelong Haven movement in New South Wales came to see me. For honourable senators who do not know about this facility, these people have worked exceedingly successfully in the field of controlling alcoholism among Aborigines. The Sydney Morning Herald of 13 May states:
Val Bryant has produced statistics showing that 300 of those 1,200 treated are still sober-a spectacularly high success rate.
Now, because of lack of funds from the Federal Government, she plans to close one of three Sydney houses and half of the largest operation, in a farm setting at Kinchela, near Kempsey.
'It breaks my heart to have to do this. But we have no alternative,' she said yesterday.
'We've been trying to get the Federal authorities to realise the value of our work, but they just won't give us enough money.'
The article states further:
The low level of funding from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs will nearly halve the number who can be treated.
The Federal Health Department is said to be very impressed by the group's work, and so is the Australian Foundation for Treatment of Drug and Alcoholism.

The results are outstanding, especially for a depressed group such as the Aborigines, who have to contend with lack of jobs, colour bar and prejudice, the foundation's executive director Pierre Stolz said yesterday.
'Among derelict whites the recovery rate is less than 10 per cent and 25 per cent is very good in this difficult area.'

He was referring to Aboriginal alcoholism. That is quite an accolade. This is obviously a very efficient organisation. Last week when Miss Val Bryant came to see me she certainly left me in no doubt of that and also of her needs. The largest single operation of the country haven at Kinchela near Kempsey has had 50 people under treatment. It has done excellent work but it is virtually crippled through lack of funds for capital development. In simple terms it has been allowed to run down and nothing will be replaced there. So eventually it will be forced into the situation where it can no longer do the work it has done so well. The furniture is poor and transport facilities are rapidly wearing out. I commend to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs a session with Miss Val Bryant and Jim Carroll who I think will be known to him. Perhaps he will see that his Department and the Department of Administrative Services get their act together to the extent that they give this place the support that it deserves. Only then will the Australian Democrats give some credit to the Government for providing some practical backing for this commendable collection of cliches and aspirations which we see in these two statements. The proof of the pudding is in the eating and I suggest that so far we have not had that proof.

I believe that the Bennelong Haven group, which has certainly convinced me, has established a principle of some importance in treating Aboriginal alcoholism, a very important problem in this country; that is, that community oriented programs may not be very effective. All the people who have been treated by this organisation have come from other areas. It has been essential for them to get away from their environment, away from their relatives, and away from the people who told them to keep on with the booze. They had to go to a separate place away from that community. I think that if the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Health pretend to sensitivity and flexibility they should look at the work that has been done by Aboriginal people for their own people that has achieved results and be guided by that. So far there is no evidence that that has happened.

On the question of leprosy, I have placed in the Minister's hands a basic study paper which the Australian Democrats have got together. I do not want to raise the matter in a large way because I feel that the Minister should have time to consider the matter properly. However, some very interesting new approaches might be used in this whole area. I believe that it is proper for this country, for the sake of our national pride and prestige, to get rid of leprosy. After all, most other societies got rid of it at least a century ago. The means are there for treatment; it is only a matter for a little more application, a little more sincerity and a little more desire if the governments of this country really want to do something for the people whom they have dispossessed and who were treated so badly by this country earlier in their history. I believe that most Australians agree that we have a social debt in this area. If any government wants to pay that debt off I believe that most Australians will be glad enough to help in that process. I turn briefly to the ministerial statement of the Minister for Health. Page 1 states:
Whilst there has been some improvement in the health status of Aboriginals, health services alone cannot provide the solution for all the problems.

The Minister for Health has really said something there. I would have thought that a total Aboriginal policy-including education and housing; it is noted on page 4 of the Minister's statement that housing is important-has yet to be devised in Australia. It has not happened yet. After all the centuries and decades of problems this has still not happened. I cannot see this being done properly in a piecemeal fashion by State governments. Let us acknowledge that it must be a substantially national responsibility and let us get away from this idea, which goes right through the statement like punctuation marks, of a sidling away from the national responsibility, that the States will be encouraged to do things and somehow or other this encouragement will achieve results. I do not believe that that would happen. On page 2 of the statement of the Minister for Health he said:

. . . Commonwealth support for Aboriginal health programs will be made conditional upon a set of specific goals and objectives, which include Commonwealth Aboriginal Affairs policy, being drawn up for each program, against which its attainment can be measured.

That is a fair enough principle and a respectable enough point of view so long as it is not made an excuse for doing less or to decline to help innovative or perhaps even controversial programs which will be of value. I am thinking of the high vitamin C dosages given by Dr Archie Kalokerinos, which have undoubtedly improved Aboriginal child health. Yet the medical profession would say that this cannot happen. I suggest to honourable senators that this is something we have to support. If it works and if it achieves results let us go along with it for a while and see where we get. On the same page the Minister mentions how he has the support of the Royal Australasian College of Physicians and he says the Australian Medical Association has expressed its concern and offered assistance. Good luck to those organisations. I am glad they are doing that. I suggest this is not a matter for organisations but rather we are going to get results in this field, as we have done in the past, through the idealistic enthusiasm of individuals. I think we should see that to be of great value and that process should be encouraged. On page 4 the Minister outlined the problems. I do think it is worth reading, if the Senate will forgive me for taking the time. The statement reads:

. . . the disruption of Aboriginals' traditional lifestyle has given rise to a number of widespread health problems, especially where Aboriginals have been obliged to live on reserves or settlements, or in camps, or in rural or urban areas, under conditions of poverty. The problems include poor water supplies, dangerous sanitary conditions, overcrowding, and limited access to nutritious food.
That is a fine euphemism I must say, 'limited access to nutritious food'! There is another way I can put that. The Minister went on:

The spread of illness and disease has been facilitated, especially respiratory, ear and skin infections, and intestinal parasite illnesses. The disruption of their society and lifestyles and its effects have also produced despair, chronic disadvantage and alcohol abuse.

If I were some kind of space traveller looking from outside in a thoroughly objective way at this planet and I saw that statement I would think that was the grossest indictment of a national society that one could possibly imagine. To list such a thing in a government document and then not to say that every reasonable measure should be taken urgently to ameliorate those conditions seems to me to be quite absurd. It is that degree of absurdity that I am trying to convey to honourable senators. We have a problem of dimensions so great that perhaps we have become blase about it, but to any reasonable outside observer it would display the utmost culpability on our part and demonstrate something which, I believe, we must cope with and soon. On page 5 of the statement the Minister talks about Aboriginal housing and his remarks take into account that statement I have just read. Any of us who have travelled around my own State, especially the country towns, will know that this is a dreadful problem. The Minister stated:
The last Budget provided in excess of $72m for Aboriginal housing and accommodation.

The statement is made almost as something which deserves praise. Far from it. It is much too meagre an amount to solve this problem. One only has to look around Australia to see that that is the position. It does not solve anything. I believe if we have any conscience and any desire to help this country in the future we will ensure that that position changes. We can well afford that in this country. Of course we can well afford it. I trust too that the Aboriginal people themselves will be consulted in the type of accommodation they want because those people I have discussed this with have got ideas about it. They do not want a Western style Blacktown house. They would like probably a hamlet type of village area, even with shared communal facilities, but something which is much more tied to their own way of life and their own, I suggest, wholly laudable extended family traditions from which, I believe, the European people in this country might benefit. I trust when we go on to the question of Aboriginal housing those things might be considered a little more than they have been in the past.
On page 6 of the statement there is another extraordinary statement which reads:

Finding, storing and distributing clean water supplies, and installing waste disposal systems are costly exercises. We must get our priorities correct, and make sure that Aboriginal communities' priorities are fully known.

I find that a quite staggering statement. After all, we are not talking about Africa in the seventeenth century. We are talking about Australia in the twentieth century. Yet a Minister is actually able to make those kinds of statements which suggest that there might even be some question of priorities over whether clean water supplies and reasonable waste disposal systems should be provided to Australian citizens. But no, that is not it. It is put forward as some sort of option which has to be considered against other priorities. The Australian Democrats are very pleased to see on page 7 the comments which indicate that the Government appears to see value in outstation communities. I have visited one or two of these recently. I can assure honourable senators that these are the places where Aboriginal people really feel they are finding their feet again. They feel their dignity and self-respect and their way of life can succeed. I believe amongst some of these communities there is a great incentive to succeed. They want to be successful. It is of value to our country that they should have the chance to be successful. We do not want to have them turn into little Anglo-Saxons. Let us see that what they have is of value. Believe me, they have the things of value and I think it is in the outstations that we are going to see them.
On page 9 of the statement we get some of this tricky stuff about the States. The statement reads:

There is a need for the States and the Northern Territory to provide greater opportunities for Aboriginals to play significant and expanded roles. To achieve this goal, increasing numbers of Aboriginals will have to be trained for, and employed at, all levels. Aboriginals must also take a real and decisive part in policy and program decision-making. The way each State Government meets this goal may be different. We are firmly committed, however, to ensuring that the goal is met, and we will be taking these questions up with State Ministers.

That worries me. Is this not what Professor Hollows is worried about? It is all very well for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to say in this place that Professor Hollows is wrong when he says that the Government is virtually shuffling off the responsibilities to the States. I suggest that in this statement the Government is coming very close to doing that. All the indications are that this is where the initiative is going to be. On page 10 of the statement the Minister said:
It is vital that Aboriginal doctors, nurses, administrators, nurses' aides, and other health care staff should be available.
Great, I agree with that. The sooner the better. The Minister went on to say:
We acknowledge that the necessary education and training will take time.

How much time-five, seven, 10, 15 or 20 years while people suffer and die from starvation; with children dying at an enormous rate in the meantime? I would have liked to have seen somewhere in this statement a concession that the Government in its wisdom might look at the Chinese example, and we might have some paramedical people like the barefoot doctors, a quickly trained people-perhaps Aboriginal people-who might go to work in these communities and cut back the amount of time in which these people are suffering, are ill and are dying. I think it should not be put at any lower level than that. On page 11 of the statement the Minister said:
The Government will be prepared to consider provision of assistance to similarly innovative approaches elsewhere.

The Minister was referring to Aboriginal medical services. That is great. I predict to the Government that it will be getting approaches quite soon from people who have quite interesting and innovative ideas. I and the Australian Democrats who know of some of these approaches will be watching closely to see whether the Government really means that or whether the statement was put in as a kind of pious hope.

We find on page 12 one of the greatest causes for unease. The Minister referred to a discussion on the officials' report which proposed that future funding arrangements should be focused away from State programs to Aboriginal medical services-in other words, a kind of central point of view. This is rational. Let us face it. It is much cheaper to run one overall service than it is to run six or seven. Therefore, why not do it? But, oh no! The statement says:

Conscious of the fact that many Aboriginals are dependent, to some extent, upon the States' general health care systems, we took the view that we should direct more effort into encouraging the States--
I stress the word 'encouraging'-
to involve Aboriginals in the planning and provision of all health services to their people.

On this question of encouraging, there has not been much success in encouraging the State to do things in the past. I suggest that this is again an indication of an opting out. On page 13 of the statement there is a definitive statement on the status of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs which I find most interesting. It reads:

The parliamentary report recommended that a new unit be established in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It was proposed that a group of experts on middle level technology should be set up to advise on, amongst other things, the most practical means of providing communal and household facilities in Aboriginal communities.

An excellent concept, if I might say so, enlightened even and something which a reasonable society would do. No, we are not going to do it. We are not going to do it although it has been suggested we might. We are told that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is essentially a policy co-ordination and funding body. That is a categorical statement. Of course it is not true. What is really said is that the Government wants the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to be essentially a policy co-ordination and funding body, regardless of the fact that other people who are expert, enlightened, reasonable and decent have said that it should not. I think that is how we should read that. I will be most interested in the Minister's statements on that point. I shall quote again from the Health Minister's statement. He said:
The Government considers, therefore, that it would not be appropriate or necessary for the proposed special group to be located within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

It does not say, of course, where that group would be. If it ever does exist, we understand that it would be in some kind of limbo. The Australian Democrats indict these statements. The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wool Industry Act 1972. Honourable senators will recall that previous amendments which became law on 23 May 1980 provided for wool grower levies in the Market Support Fund to be progressively refunded to wool growers as the credit balance in the Fund reached agreed satisfactory levels. The Market Support Fund was established in September 1974 to provide funds to operate the Wool Reserve Price Scheme. Since that time wool growers contributed to the Fund through a 5 per cent levy on their gross sales value of shorn wool.

The 1980 amendments to the Act were introduced after the Government acceded to strong requests from the Wool Council of Australia to revolve the Fund. The views of all sectors of the industry were canvassed at the time and not all agreed with the Council's proposals. However, contributions to the Fund are made by wool growers and it is only right that the views of growers should be given primary consideration. Revolving the Fund means that repayments will be made to the wool growers who contributed the money on a first-in-first-out basis after the Fund has reached an agreed satisfactory level. The Act provides that the Minister for Primary Industry will, with the written agreement of the Wool Council of Australia, make a declaration specifying a period of contributions to be returned to wool growers.

The level of the Fund currently stands well above $400m. This is in excess of requirements to operate the Reserve Price Scheme and it is realistic at this stage to consider refunding levies collected during the first year of the Fund's operation. The continued collection of the 5 per cent levy will enable the Fund to be maintained at the desired level, for its primary role of market support.

Development of the administrative procedures has been a complex task and has however revealed a number of aspects of the Act which need to be modified to remove certain difficulties and anomalies before the refund scheme is implemented. While the overall administration of the refund scheme is to be in the hands of the Australian Wool Corporation, much of the detailed work will be performed by wool brokers and wool merchants who are registered with the Commissioner of Taxation as agents for the collection of wool tax. These firms are referred to in the Act as 'registered persons'. It is clearly undesirable for the Corporation, which does not hold the necessary wool transaction records, to be burdened with the task of making refunds to individual growers where this task could otherwise be undertaken more simply and less expensively by registered persons.

Wool growers who sold their wool to or through a registered person will normally receive their refunds through that same person; that is, the firm which collected the 5 per cent levy. The Act as it stands provides that where a registered person ceases to be registered the Corporation will pay the refunds direct to the wool growers clients. To cater for the situation where the firm concerned has since gone out of business, it was provided that refunds to clients of that firm were to be made by the Corporation. Some firms have ceased to be registered persons for the purposes of refunds because they are absorbed in take-overs or because they became registered under a different name. It now appears that many successor firms are capable of making these refunds, but are precluded from doing so by the provisions of section 42K (7) of the Act, which requires the Wool Corporation to make refunds in situations of this nature. Again, it is undesirable that the Corporation be burdened with the cost intensive task of making refunds to individual growers where this work could be performed automatically by firms which have 'inherited' these growers as clients. Accordingly, clause 7 of this Bill amends the Act to remedy this situation.

A further proposed amendment removes an anomaly created by wool growers entering into certain types of forward selling transactions. Under the Act, as it stands at present, a decision to refund 1974-75 Market Support Fund levy payments would mean that some growers who sold wool forward before shearing prior to 1974-75, and eventually paid the levy during 1974-75 after shearing, would not be eligible for a refund. Other growers, however, who sold forward in 1974-75 but did not pay the levy until the following year would be eligible for a refund in respect of 1974-75. This situation is inequitable and not consistent with the first-in-first-out principle for revolving the Fund. Clause 5 of the Bill corrects the anomaly by deeming the time of sale of wool to be that time when payment for the wool is made.

An amendment proposed by clause 4 of the Bill will enable the Corporation, and registered persons assisting the Corporation, to be reimbursed for administrative costs incurred before the formal declaration of a refund period. The Bill amends the Act to enable these costs, which could not otherwise be recouped until after the declaration had been made, to be charged to the Market Support Fund.

A number of other amendments of the principal Act are considered desirable and timely and it is opportune to introduce them now. I will refer to each of them briefly. The Bill provides in clause 10 that a statement given to a wool grower claiming a refund, should set out the findings of the Corporation regarding the facts of the claim, as well as the reasons for the Corporation's decision. The Bill also provides for an increase in the membership, and in the quorum for a meeting, of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. Since a significant proportion of the wool clip is tested in stores controlled by private treaty merchants it is appropriate that their organisation be represented on the AWTA. Additionally, the Wool Council of Australia is of the view that, as growers pay for the bulk of wool testing, the Council should be directly represented on the Authority.

Honourable senators will be aware that the Government has made a separate decision to sell the AWTA, but no time scale has yet been set. Nevertheless, it is still appropriate for the Government to provide for the Authority's continued administration. Accordingly, clause 14 of the Bill provides for representation by both the Wool Council and private treaty merchants. As a result of this amendment, all major industry organisations will be represented on the Australian Wool Testing Authority. They will thus have an input in consideration of the future sale of the Authority and a first hand association with the shaping of ongoing testing and certification of wool. Clause 16 of the Bill revises the provision regarding decoration of pecuniary interests by Corporation members. The revision is in harmony with the conclusions and recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry on Public Duty and Private Interest. All members of the Corporation are required to declare any pecuniary interests in matters being discussed or considered by a meeting of the Corporation, and for that declaration to be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
