The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1981 now before the Senate proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. The Bill, which contains 18 Schedules, is necessary to enact tariff changes which have been introduced into the House of Representatives at various times since May 1980, by Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 8-20 (1980) and Proposals Nos. 1-5 (1981).

In the main, the amendments give effect to decisions by the Government in respect of the following reports by the Industries Assistance Commission and the Temporary Assistance Authority: Apples and Pears; Certain Goods Made From Carbon and Graphite; Certain Soft Sided Containers; Certain Works Trucks and Stackers; Cheese; Chemical Products (Part B); Continuation of Assistance for Insulators; Crushing or Grinding Machines; Electric Motors, Generators and Rotary Converters; Fluorescent and Filament Lamps; Gearboxes, Gears and Shaft Couplings; Iron and Steel Industry; Manufactured Tobacco, Metal Cans and Canisters of Iron or Steel; Musical Instruments and Parts and Accessories Therefor; Polymeric Plasticisers and Certain Polyester Polyols; Tanned and Finished Leather; Dressed Fur, and Textiles, Clothing and Footwear. On each occasion when the Tariff Proposals were introduced, a comprehensive account of the IAC's recommendations and Government decisions was outlined.

Other amendments contained in the Bill provide for: Amended tariff preference rates for certain goods from developing countries; changes arising from Australia's commitment to the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement-SPARTECA; and the addition of certain goods to Schedule A of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. The only amendments not already included in Proposals make provisions for the removal of all remaining preferential rates for goods from the United Kingdom and Ireland with effect from 1 July 1981 and for some changes of an administrative nature. A summary of amendments for each Schedule setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and copies are available from the Records Office. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill represents a retrospective validation of a quite familiar kind of some 20 customs tariff proposals which have been introduced over the last year. The tariff changes in question encompass such things as textiles, clothing and footwear, products of the chemical industry, carpets, metal products and rural products of various kinds. They range from items as prosaic as cheese and gearboxes to items as exotic as polymeric plasticisers and certain polyester polyols. The Bill also embodies a number of changes involving preferential rates of tariff, which are to apply to certain goods from developing countries, changes to the New Zealand-Australian Free Trade Agreement and changes involving closer trading relationships with several Pacific island countries under the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement, which is known as SPARTECA.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of issues are raised by the Bill and I propose to spend just a few moments on three of them. The first concerns the question of South Pacific trade, a rather under-debated matter in this Parliament but one that is assuming increasing importance. There is emerging in the South Pacific a growing concern that Australia is by no means as generous as it might be in trade and tariff arrangements, especially when its position is compared with that of the European Economic Community. That concern is built upon a number of different elements which might briefly be described as follows: Under the first Lome convention the EEC has been, at least in the case of Fiji, far and away that country's most lucrative sugar market. Again, Pacific countries generally receive far better access to EEC markets-duty free and unrestricted-than the forum regional trade agreement or SPARTECA provide for in respect of Australian and New Zealand markets. The Lome convention provides assistance for investment, trade promotion and natural disaster situations in a way that is not seen in any agreement in which Australia is involved.

The second Lome convention, which involves Pacific, African and Caribbean countries, provides for bilateral aid to island countries being given in the form of grants, not loans. Again, that is something in which Australia has been reluctant to participate, much to the disappointment of the Pacific countries concerned. Generally speaking, I am advised that Australia's attitude overall has been one, not of encouraging-despite some rhetoric to the contrary-genuine regional co-operation, but rather the perpetration of quite a number of divisive colonial distinctions which are certainly felt quite deeply by a number of countries in the area in question.

Thus the point is made by a number of these countries in the Pacific area that the EEC gives direct bilateral and regional aid, thereby encouraging a regional approach, whereas neither Australia, nor New Zealand for that matter, gives regional aid. Also, it is said and felt that Pacific countries are attempting to take the Lome-sponsored regionalism concept further with a Pacific islands development conference but that Australia has expressed only very lukewarm support for it, as compared with the much more vigorous support that seems to be expressed in many places these days for the larger concept of a Pacific Basin community. Again, it has been said that the Lome convention treats all Pacific countries as equals and does not discriminate in favour of former colonies as Australia, particularly by way of the South Pacific Forum, does; that Australia's and New Zealand's trade and aid policies, generally speaking, in a whole variety of ways-I will not stop to spell them out now-have perpetuated the division of Pacific island countries between those that historically have been within, and those that historically have been outside colonial control, whereas the Lome convention, by contrast has not done that.

A number of large and difficult questions are raised by these kinds of contentions which are part of the common currency of political and economic debate within the South Pacific area. I do not seek nor am I in a position to judge here tonight the merits of the particular points or claims that are there being made. I simply take the opportunity afforded by this debate, since the Bill does embody questions of preferential trade arrangements with the South Pacific, to make the point that these sorts of considerations ought to loom very much larger than apparently has previously been the case in our trade and tariff negotiations with these countries.

The second matter I want to raise arising out of this Bill is that the Bill reveals evidence-not that evidence has been lacking in the past-of a general incoherence in the Government's industry policy. This is a very large question and again I propose to deal with it in a matter of only a few moments. The Bill raises some tariff rates and decreases others, in each case without explanation or logic and, indeed, certainly not always in accorcance with the terms of the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations which are relevant to the industries in question. The honourable member for Adelaide, Mr Hurford, in speaking to this Bill in the other place, gave a number of examples with respect to recent experience so far as carpets are concerned and also to a whole course of erratic treatment in relation to the steel industry which is felt very deeply in that industrial context. Proposals of this tariff kind tend to emerge in splendid isolation in each case with no evident understanding of where and when Australia's industry should in fact be developed. Again, as Mr Hurford put it very nicely in the other place, the Government's approach here represents 'a shaky marriage between free-market fundamentalism on the one hand and political expediency on the other hand'. Mr Howe, the honourable member for Batman in the other place, in the course of what I think was an excellent speech, the substance of which I do not stop to repeat here, made the point that the basis of our protectionist policy can best be described as 'sophisticated political opportunism'. The point is-there is ample evidence for it; this just happens to be one very detailed Bill, and even passing scrutiny of which will necessarily draw one to this conclusion-that the Government in this whole industry policy area staggers from one ad hoc decision to another.

One particularly good recent example of this sort of attitude which runs in parallel with the particular subject matter of this Bill concerns the razor gang changes that have been made to investment and depreciation allowances whereby investment allowances have been reduced from 20 per cent to 18 per cent and depreciation allowances by a similar proportion. That reduction may or may not have been acceptable to the industries concerned. Certainly it was not very satisfactorily argued for, but then nor was anything else in the razor gang report. What was manifestly unacceptable to the industries concerned was the curious ad hoc, erratic way in which this change was introduced and they were obliged to live with it. Mr Eric Risstrom, the Secretary of the Taxpayers Association, put it rather effectively in a letter which all honourable senators will have received, when he said that with the depreciation change in particular scheduled to commence from 30 April rather than from the new financial year, this means that businesses will have to produce not just one but two depreciation schedules in respect of all their plant and equipment, one of them applying in respect of ten-twelfths of the year and the other in respect of two-twelfths. So much point can be made of this Government's obsession with efficiency and productivity and the minimisation of red tape and so on in industrial performance.

Symptomatic again of the whole of the Government's approach to industry policy generally, especially manufacturing industry, is this kind of state of mind, this unplanned ad hockery which is evident in this legislation before us tonight. The situation of manufacturing industry could, of course, be the subject of a very much lengthier contribution than that which I propose to make at the moment. I simply make the point that it is evident to every commentator in the country that, although the outlook for manufacturing industry is not quite as desperately alarming now as seemed likely to be the case only a short time ago, it is continuing to limp along in a persistently retarded growth pattern despite all the attentions and the apparent profitability that is being given these days to manufacturing by transnational corporations.

By contrast, and I think this is a point that must be made whenever Bills of this kind come before the Parliament, the Opposition, the Australian Labor Party, does have a coherent approach to industry policy, one which does offer an excellent prospect for generating the extra 1.5 million jobs that we need to create, that we must create, during the 1980s. It is a policy which follows quite naturally from our intellectual commitment, our principled commitment to co-operative economic planning, a commitment which, of course, puts us right in the mainstream of the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, all of which, whether they have a primarily socialist or primarily non-socialist mode of political operation, without exception adopt a far more rigorous approach to the desirability of planning than seems to be within the contemplation of this Government.

The elements of our approach and how it is distinguished from that of the Government were set out in the course of a lengthy and substantial and excellent speech by the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Hurford, when he spoke to this Bill in the House of Representatives on 14 May. Again, I do no more than, in a sentence or two, summarise the gist of Labor's approach in this respect which can be put in the form of three propositions. First of all, we very strongly advocate and acknowledge the need for long term planning; the need, that is, to set objectives for industry and to try to create agreement about shared objectives between the public and the private sectors and, of course, between Federal and State governments, noting as we do-again this should be evident to any impartial observer-that our rejection of planning has been a manifest disaster creating particular strains and stresses in regional areas and that without an overall approach to planning we will never be able to solve these fundamental problems associated with the maintenance of a manifestly unsatisfactory protectionist approach.

The second element in our approach, and what distinguishes us from our political opponents, is our very strong belief in the need for a co-operative approach, particularly involving both sides of industry, labour as well as management and capital. The third element in our approach, which again distinguishes us very obviously from our opponents, is our very strong held view that market forces alone are inadequate to produce a rational industry policy situation in this country. There is a need for leadership by government for regulation where regulation is necessary and for government incentives where they are necessary in order to ensure effective small business development and everything else that goes with the development of a viable industry policy generally based on a strong manufacturing sector. Unless the Government can rid itself of the present free market nonsense which so obviously permeates everything it does, it will tend to blunder on in the present ad hoc backwards and forwards industry policy fashion which this Bill so obviously represents.

The final matter to which I wish to advert, and again it will be much more briefly than one could advert to it in these circumstances, is the matter of the procedures by which we in this Parliament deal with Customs tariff proposals and the legislation of the kind which we have tonight which follows on from it. The way it works at the moment is that there are introduced from time to time, following government decisions to alter tariff rates upwards or downwards in respect of imported goods, Customs proposals so labelled. They are tabled in the House of Representatives, usually accompanied by a short and not very informative explanation from the Minister and the debate on that statement is invariably adjourned and never brought back on for proper discussion by the Government. The only opportunity that ever arises to discuss the legitimacy of the particular protective arrangements involved comes some six months later, or even sometimes 12 months later, with a kind of catch-all tariff Bill of the kind before us tonight which retrospectively validates all those piecemeal Customs tariff proposals. That is at least the situation as far as the House of Representatives is concerned.

As far as the Senate is concerned, the situation is even worse because the Customs tariff proposals are not even tabled, for legal reasons which are clear but for policy reasons which remain to me utterly obscure. So there are not even the beginnings of a formal opportunity, other than by leave, for them to be debated at the time of their introduction when the change in question is relevant and is subject to legitimate public attention. I believe the Senate should consider very seriously-I do not propose to move it now as an amendment although it is a position that could have been taken-the merits of the kind of proposal that was advanced in the other place by the shadow Minister, Mr Hurford, as indeed he has advanced it on previous occasions, to the effect that this Parliament ought to establish a parliamentary standing committee on Customs and excise tariffs to examine each change in Customs and excise tariffs following the gazettal of proposals or their being introduced into the Parliament and before related Bills are subsequently introduced into the House.

The point being made is the obvious one that if parliamentary consideration of these things is to amount to anything, if it is to be relevant and if it is to contribute rationally to the process of policy formulation which is limping along on such a manifestly unsatisfactory and ad hoc basis at the moment, some institutional vehicle of this kind ought to be created within Parliament. We have roughly analogous mechanisms already in existence, notably in the form of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee which routinely scrutinises proposals for changes in delegated legislation. Of course, that does not have a policy examination function in the way that perhaps would be contemplated here, but it is an indication of the kind of machinery possible. The point simply is that unless we begin in one way or another to devise machinery that will allow a more rational and systematic consideration of these protective arrangements as they are devised and introduced we will never get a semblance of the kind of planned development and rational growth of our industry that is so obviously necessary.

They are the sorts of issues which are raised by this legislation. There are many others, but in deference to the obvious pressures of business I do no more than take the matter that far and I do not proceed to move the amendment to the motion for the second reading that was moved in the other place. I think I have given to the Senate ample indication of the substance of the proposal. We would certainly welcome a response to that proposal from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) if she is minded to give one. But it is more a matter of putting it into the pot in the hope that one of these days it is an idea that will take root.

It was certainly a subject that would be worthy of some discussion at an appropriate time. DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first of the razor gang Bills. The Opposition opposes it straight out, absolutely and unequivocally, not for the kind of reflex ideological reasons that no doubt motivated its creation but rather for quite systematic and rational reasons which I hope I will be able to articulate to the Senate. The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Act, the legislation which is being emasculated by this Bill, has been on the statute book only since 1977. It must be acknowledged at the outset that when it was introduced by the present Government it was not exactly to universal acclaim, least of all from the Opposition. In the first place, the Opposition was concerned-as indeed it still is-about the dismantling of the Australian Legal Aid Office, a creation of the Whitlam Government and in particular of a former Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy, which was part and parcel of the concept of the creation of the new national commission, although we acknowledged that there were obvious constitutional and jurisdictional difficulties involved, given Australia's constitutional structure, in the continuation of the divided system of delivery of Federal and State legal aid.

SPEECH.PARA: The second consideration was that the Opposition was concerned in 1977 at the rejection of the proposal-a proposal which is still Australian Labor Party policy-to establish a joint Federal-State commission which, among other things, would allow the Commonwealth to play a continuing direct role in the provision of legal aid within the States. We were concerned further at the lack of any power retained under the proposed new set-up by the Commonwealth, despite the proposed extent of Commonwealth funding, to play anything other than an advisory role in determining how the new State commissions were to allocate their resources. Further again, we were concerned that the Commonwealth Commission might not have the muscle in the form in which it was created to exercise an effective independent role and that it might be reduced to peripheral advisory functions with all the actual funding and such decisions being made by the Commonwealth Government for reasons of its own which might not necessarily be very good reasons in terms of proper legal aid policy.

Finally, we were concerned about a number of aspects of the composition of the Commission that was established in 1977. We were concerned in particular at its potential for dominance by private legal practitioners with all the narrowness and the self-interest that tends to be part of the practice of law privately. We were concerned at the dominance that was possible for the private profession, with the prospect being that the representatives of salaried and community legal services would have an insufficient voice on the Commission and insufficient opportunity as a result for creative, imaginative and sensitive input into the formulation of legal aid delivery policy. Despite all those various reservations, qualifications and arguments of one kind or another with varying degrees of force against the establishment of the Commission, the Bill, as inevitably seems to happen in this Parliament, went through.

Our feelings were assuaged a little by the then Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, who told us that the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission thus created in 1977 was 'a basic element' in the development of a comprehensive legal aid scheme in Australia. He was saying in effect that the introduction of the Commission, with all its powers and functions there set out, was an indispensable linchpin for the new era of legal aid and that it was heralding in a new dawn of Federal-State co-operation and, indeed, of continuing Commonwealth financial commitment. So the Commission was established.

Despite the fact that it has not, during its life since 1977, always acted as sensitively or energetically as many people would have liked, it has undoubtedly come to play a central role in researching, advising, evaluating, co-ordinating and monitoring the funding and the general delivery of legal aid services. On its advice Commonwealth funding has been maintained at more or less the real levels originally established by the Labor Government between 1972 and 1975, although there have been recurring crises in particular areas, especially in Victoria, and although, of course, there has been a perennial concern that the means and needs tests being applied under the advice of the Commission are being applied to stringently so as to exclude everyone except those in dire poverty and, indeed, not even all those.

The State commissions which have come into operation in all but two States, where they are about to come into operation, have been, on all the evidence, working reasonably well, subject inevitably to reservations of one kind or another. Overall, that is not an inaccurate conclusion. The Commission has set in operation at least one major research project designed to settle once and for all the central and enormously important question as to the comparative cost of delivering legal aid via salaried professionals on the one hand or private legal practitioners on the other.

The Commission by its statute in 1977 was given a very large number of specific functions to perform. Despite the disposition of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his second reading speech to down-play the actual role that the Commission has performed in recent months, and indeed recent years, the Opposition takes the view that the Commission has been performing most of its statutory functions very effectively indeed and certainly to the maximum extent possible, given the kinds of resources available to it. Rather than waxing any more lyrical or lengthily on this subject I shall simply seek leave to incorporate in Hansard at this point a list of activities of the Commission in its heyday rather than in its somewhat attenuated form of recent months. Notwithstanding, I believe it to be an accurate list of what it has indeed been up to. The document in question is not dated, but I think it is acknowledged by the Attorney to bear the marks of verisimilitude. Accordingly, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard as a description of what the Commission at the height of its operations had, in fact, been up to.

SUMMARY OF MAJOR OPERATIONAL ACTIVITIES
1. 'Legal Aid in Australia: An Annotated Bibliography'

(a) Activity Description: The Commission is collecting, annotating, indexing and publishing the only national bibliography of materials on legal aid and legal needs in Australia. The bibliography also includes overseas material.

(b) Relevance of Activity: The bibliography allows all interested organisations and individuals to keep abreast of what is happening in legal aid and provides an information base for further research. This information will be of great assistance in planning new initiatives in legal aid.
(c) Future Developments: The bibliography will include a more detailed classification and, in particular, categorizes overseas materials in the same manner as existing Australian entries.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into function 6 (a), (e), (j) and (f).
2. 'Legal Aid News'

(a) Activity Description: 'Legal Aid News' is a topical news sheet containing serious articles on legal aid as well as jottings on current events affecting legal aid. 'Legal Aid News' is widely distributed throughout Australia.

(b) Relevance of Activity: 'Legal Aid News' brings together in one publication those matters that affect legal aid in Australia. It is a useful forum for raising issues and discussing topics of interest and concern.

(c) Future Developments: 'Legal Aid News' can be used by the legal aid agencies themselves for notifying development advertising staff positions and providing a means of raising issues of office management and relevant legal developments.
(d) Statutory Function: 'Legal Aid News' falls into function 6 (f).

3. Evaluating Legal Aid: 'Framework for Accountability and Accessibility Review'; 'Evalu- ating the Effectiveness of Legal Aid Programs: A Description of Issues, Options and Problems'; and 'Handbook for the Self-Evaluation of Legal Aid Agencies'.
(a) Activity Description: The Commission has already produced two publications:
(i) 'Framework for Accountability and Accessibility Review'; and
(ii) 'Evaluating the Effectiveness of Legal Aid Problems'

which deal with theoretical and practical issues in the evaluation of legal aid agencies. The Commission is in the process of producing the 'Handbook for the Self-Evaluation of Legal Aid Agencies' which may be used by all legal aid agencies for their self-evaluation. This Handbook will be easy to follow and offer practical suggestions to legal aid agencies in self-evaluation.

(b) Relevance of Activity: These publications and the proposed publication are applicable to all legal aid agencies. They will assist agencies in their management and setting of goals and objectives. The results of the self-evaluation undertaken by legal aid agencies will allow them to approach funders with hard evidence of program needs and data on the agencies' effectiveness.

(c) Future Developments: With the production of the Self-Evaluation Handbook the Commission will be involved in encouraging legal aid agencies to adopt a process of self-evaluation. One advantage of having agencies being involved in self-evaluation is that statistics and other information can be available for not only the agency itself, but others for formulating legal aid policy.
(d) Statutory Function: The evaluation of legal aid falls into function 6 (a), (b) (i), (b) (ii) and (b) (iv) and, particularly, 6 (d).
4. Evaluating Eligibility Criteria

(a) Activity Description: The project is being carried out at the request of the South Australian Legal Services Commission and is evaluating the criteria used to accept and reject legal aid applicants. It is ascertaining what happens to those rejected, how they resolve their legal problems, and whether such people will create barriers in the access of legal aid for others. The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission has acted in this project as a consultant to the South Australian Legal Services Commission. It has worked closely with the South Australian Commission obtaining material from its files and records and with the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which has conducted the surveys.

(b) Relevance of Activity: The results of the study will allow the South Australian Commission to review and assess the criteria it uses in granting legal aid. The results will also be applicable to other legal aid agencies, including other State Commissions, that use similar criteria.
(c) Future Developments: At the moment the study is merely a pilot project and it is anticipated that the more detailed study will be undertaken later this year.
5. Interstate Cost Comparison

(a) Activity Description: This project is being co-ordinated by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission and involves all State legal aid commissions and the Australian Legal Aid Office. Joint discussions were held with the Directors of those offices to facilitate the implementation of the project. Initially the study is restricted to family law because of uniform procedures. In some instances members of this Commission's research staff have been given access to files and records to collect the relevant data. The project will establish which jurisdiction has the cheapest and which has the most expensive cost structures in the area of Family Law.
(b) Relevance of Activity: The results of the project will be useful for not only this Commission but also State legal aid commissions in claiming the nature of the legal services they provide.
(c) Future Developments: On the completion of this project other areas of law will be considered.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into Section 6 (a), (b) (i) and (f).
6. Cost Comparison between Private and Salaried Lawyers
(a) Activity Description: The object of this project is to see to determine which method of delivering legal aid is the most cost effective: private or salaried lawyers.

(b) Relevance of Activity: With the results of this project this Commission will be able to advise both the Commonwealth and State Attorneys-General and the State legal aid commissions of the most effective and economical method of providing legal aid.

(c) Future Developments: The project at the moment is limited to a cost comparison, though later it may be developed into a comparison of the different quality of the legal services provided by each method of delivery.
(d) Statutory Function: This project falls into functions 6 (a), 6 (b) (i) and 6 (b) (iii).
7. Statistics

(a) Activity Description: The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission is developing national legal aid statistics. This will take time to complete, though considerable progress has been made. There have been discussions with State legal aid commissions, Bureaux of Crime Statistics and the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Already, the Commission has obtained from the Australian Bureau of Statistics an undertaking that 'legal representation' will be a data item in their National Court Statistics.
(b) Relevance of Activity: With national legal aid statistics both this Commission and State legal aid commissions will be able to more efficiently and economically plan the delivery of legal aid.
(c) Future Developments: It is hoped that legal aid statistics will be available in published form once problems involving the collection of statistics have been resolved.
(d) Statutory Function: This function falls into Section 6 (c), though statistics are also relevant to Section 6 (a) and 6 (g).
8. Alternative Sources of Funding Conference

(a) Activity Description: The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission is organising a conference on the topic of 'Alternative Sources of Legal Aid Funding'. In the Conference different methods of funding legal aid will be canvassed and examined.
(b) Relevance of Activity: With the results from the Conference, this Commission will be able to advise the Commonwealth Attorney-General on initiatives in the area of legal aid funding.
(c) Future Developments: The Conference may suggest new sources of funding that will require more detailed examination by this Commission.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into Section 6 (b) (iii), 6 (b) (iv), 6 (f) and 6 (g).
9. Legal Aid Research Conference

(a) Activity Description: This Conference will draw together researchers in the area of legal aid. It will be an opportunity for the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission to explain its research program and also obtain information about other research being undertaken in the area.

(b) Relevance of Activity: The Conference will be useful for the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission to set its own research program and priorities. It will also encourage co-operation between researchers and Legal Aid Commissions at the local level.
(c) Future Developments: It is anticipated that a legal aid research conference be held at regular intervals, possibly once every two years.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into Section 6(g).
10. Examination of the Relationship Between Legal Aid Agencies and Social Agencies

(a) Activity Description: This research project examines the relationship between legal aid agencies and social agencies and will determine the extent to which legal aid agencies can use social agencies in their work. It will consider practical, social and economical factors that arise in this relationship.
(b) Relevance of Activity: The results of this project may be used by State legal aid commissions in determining their relationship with various social agencies.

(c) Future Developments: With the results of this project the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission may be involved in community legal education in implementing any proposals and with coordinating any national effect.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into functions 6(a), 6(g) and 6(h).
11. Examination of Group Legal Services
(a) Activity Description: The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission is examining the feasibility of group legal services in Australia. The focus of the project is on Victoria.

(b) Relevance of Activity: The project will determine whether group legal services are feasible and the relevance of this new method of delivering legal services to legal aid. This information will be useful to all legal aid commissions in their planning of new initiatives.
(c) Future Developments: Depending on the results of this project, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission may be actively involved in implementing this new method of delivering legal services.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into Section 6(a), (e) and (g).
12. 'Clearinghouse'.

(a) Activity Description: The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission is developing a clearinghouse function for legal aid agencies and interested individuals. It is collecting together not only its own publications but also a wide range of information that relates to legal aid, which will be available on request.

(b) Relevance of Activity: This service provided by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission is an assistance to all legal aid agencies in Australia. It may be used for reviewing existing programs or planning new initiatives.
(c) Future Developments: At the moment the Clearinghouse has only a limited operation, although it is anticipated it will broaden its scope, as demand increases.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into Sections 6(e) and (f).
13. Assistance with New Programs

(a) Activity Description: The policy of the Government is that any new program or any major variation to an existing program requires Cabinet approval the Commission helps legal aid commissions to gather material in support of the program and prepares submissions to the Attorney-General on the feasibility and essentiality.

(b) Relevance of Activity: With this assistance the State commissions can ensure proposals with all supporting evidence are properly presented and the Attorney-General can be satisfied that the proposal has been thoroughly investigated and its need found.

(c) Future Development: As well as programs raised by State legal aid commissions it is envisaged that a ''package'' will be developed by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission for programs which would assist State commissions (for example self-evaluation program or quality control program). Acceptance in principle at Federal level will facilitate program implementation and funding.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into function 6(b) and provisions of the Commonwealth/State agreement.
14. Liaison with the Commonwealth Government

(a) Activity Description: Many aspects of Government administration and legal administration are restricted to the Federal sphere. The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission being a Federal body, has developed a particular relationship with Federal authorities in matters that relate to legal aid. For example, the Commission is involved with:
Implementation of the Galbally Report, being on the Galbally working party
Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-particularly in relation to its post arrival information program
Institute of Family Studies (involvement in determining the direction of research program)
Australian Bureau of Statistics (inclusion of ''legal representation'' as a data item in national statistics) and development of uniform statistics
Administrative Review Council (appeal structures in legal aid and Social Security appeals)
Australian Law Reform Commission (the relevance of legal aid to substantive law issues)
Family Law Council (advisor to the Legal Aid Committee)
Parliamentary Committees (e.g. enquiry into Aboriginal legal aid).

(b) Relevance of Activity: The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission, in these above activities, is an obvious reference point for the many Federal authorities that operate in the areas of Government and legal administration. Approaches to and by Federal bodies are best made on a Federal level. This ensures that legal aid is always taken into account when those authorities are planning programs which are relevant.

(c) Future Developments: The liaison and co-operation already being undertaken should continue and develop. Gradually the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission will become recognised as 'experts' in policy issues affecting legal aid.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into Section 6 (f).
15. Financial Assistance

(a) Activity Description: Liaise with and provide advice to State legal aid commissions in the preparation of estimates programs and prepare them in a form for consideration by the Commonwealth Commission. Negotiates, on Commission's behalf, with the Departments of Attorney-General and Finance for an adequate level of Commonwealth funding for legal aid.

(b) Relevance of Activity: The role of the Commonwealth Commission is to recommend to the Attorney-General the level of legal aid funding. The staff of the Commssion perform the role of advocate at discussions with the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Finance when those two bodies are considering the bud for legal aid. Without that intervention commissions would perhaps have their estimates considered less favourably.

(c) Future Developments: Commission staff are working in cooperation with the ALAO and legal aid commission on a system of data processing using mini-computers with the aim of compiling more meaningful information quickly. It is hoped that this step will allow commissioners to be in a better position to consider programs and estimates from legal aid commissions.
(d) Statutory Function: These activities fall into functions 6 (b), (f), (j) and (k).
16. Evaluation
(a) Activity Description: In co-operation with commissions information is collected as to their operations, especially in the Federal area and these programs are discussed and evaluated.

(b) Relevance of Activity: Assessment is made of programs on legal aid either in operation or yet to be commenced in legal aid commissions. This allows for an evaluation of these programs in terms of the most efficient use of existing resources.

(c) Future Developments: The evaluation stage has relevance on all legal aid bodies in Australia. It is proposed therefore that experience gained in assessing the merits of legal aid programs will be passed on to these bodies so that it can be put to more efficient use to their existing resources.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into function 6 (d), (e), (f), (k) and (l).
17. Assistance to Voluntary and Community Legal Services

(a) Activity Description: The Commission recommends on funding from the Commonwealth to voluntary or community legal services and provides liasion, some advice and assistance to these bodies through visits, personal contact, inclusion of such services in conferences/seminars, and the 'Clearinghouse' function. The role of the voluntary services is also relevant to issues of concern to the Commissioner, e.g. funding evaluation and research project.

(b) Relevance of Activity: The voluntary and community legal services carry out an important role in the overall delivery of legal aid. Their innovative, community devised and directed nature has led not only to innovative ways of meeting legal needs but also to their filling gaps in the current system. The work of such services is therefore a necessary part of the Commission's overview of legal aid in Australia.

(c) Future Developments: Liaison with these services can be developed, in conjunction with the Commission's concern with community legal education programs, some research topics and the services' continuing need for financial subsidy.
(d) Statutory Function: Relevant areas of the Act are mainly 6 (e) but also 6 (a), 6 (c), 6 (f), 6 (g) and 6 (h).
18. Consultancy and Resource Role

(a) Activity Description: As well as providing information for all legal aid agencies, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission can provide expertise in the area of legal aid policy. In this role it may even act as a 'consultant' for State legal aid commissions. This is what has occurred in the recent study being undertaken by the South Australian Legal Services Commission in its evaluation of eligibility criteria for legal aid and to an extent in the interstate cost comparison.
(b) Relevance of Activity: This expertise in the Commonwealth Commission is of great use to State legal aid commissions and other legal aid agencies.

(c) Future Developments: In time the expertise of the Commonwealth Commission may be used by the various legal aid agencies in a more formalized method than at the moment. The development of the 'Clearinghouse' is an example of the direction in which the Commission may move.
(d) Statutory Function: This activity falls into Sections 6 (f) and (g).
16. Future Research Projects
It should be briefly noted that the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission is undertaking to perform other projects. Some of the projects anticipated are:
An examination of the impact of legal aid on the administration of justice and the legal system.
Issues on community legal education, with particular reference to migrants.
The legal needs of various groups of Australians e.g. rural poor, migrants, prisoners etc.

Also, the Commission is interested in the quality of legal services that are provided to clients of legal aid commissions. Following the lead of the Legal Services Corporation in the United States, it could consider issues of 'quality control' and 'peer review'.

The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission could also become involved, and to a certain extent it has already done so, in important issues of office management, e.g., word processing and the creation of 'systems' in a legal aid office.

SPEECH.PARA: A further general point relates to the general role of the Commonwealth, which I think is crucial to the background of this legislation and to the Opposition's response to it. It is proper that the Commonwealth should be playing a major role here, not only because it is providing funds for legal aid out of its own Treasury but also because the role of the Commonwealth is crucial in the development of legal aid policy and the co-ordination of legal aid delivery. We ought to remember, if we have already forgotten, the bad old days which existed before the Labor Government introduced the Australian Legal Aid Office and simultaneously engaged in some very substantial funding of the existing State legal aid services. Those were the days-before the Labor Government came into the picture in this way-when legal aid was wholly in the hands of voluntary law society schemes supplemented in some States by funding derived from the trust account interest which was required to be separately collected and, in some other States, supplemented also by very small subventions from the State Treasury. It resulted in the situation in which the concept of equal access to the law and to legal procedures was no better than a joke. It was a pitiful and bad joke, but a joke notwithstanding. Legal aid for all practical purposes simply did not exist. It is clear that it would be disastrous for the Commonwealth to abandon any of its role in this field.

The States have not traditionally had any inclination to play any kind of significant financial role in funding legal aid. Even if they had had that inclination, as one or two of them have had in a very small way, they simply have not had the resources to translate that inclination into the viable levels of financial assistance. Nothing has happened since the early 1970s to change that situation. If anything, the financial situation of the States is becoming undeniably more constrained as a result of the razor gang ideology and the insistance of this Government on vesting unwanted functions back in that level of government.

Against that background, it is with real apprehension that we in the Opposition approach the present Bill. It is with very real, genuine trepidation that we contemplate the implications of this Bill. It is with considerable alarm that we have to approach a Bill that abolishes, as this one does, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission with its existing staff of around 20 officers and replaces it with a part time advisory council with no staff at all working to an already manifestly overstretched Attorney-General's Department. It is with alarm that we see that the composition of the new advisory Council abandons even the pretence of independence in respect of the interests that are represented on it. Appointees are now to be nominated, not by outside organisations of relevant kinds but by the Attorney-General, albeit after consultation. It is still his appointment.

It must be with alarm that we see that the functions of the advisory Council now created have been stripped back under this legislation to negligible proportions. I will say something more about these points later. It is with alarm that we see that the advisory Council has no longer in particular any direct advisory role in relation to the States. It has to be with some alarm again that we notice in the Attorney-General's second reading speech that it is not proposed to transfer all the existing staff of the Commission back into the Attorney-General's Department to perform legal aid, or indeed any other functions. That, of course, will create a situation in which there is that much less chance of the kind of the functions that were previously exercised by the Commission now being performed by anyone.

It is with alarm that we note furthermore the context in which this Bill has been presented to us as the first part of the razor gang package, in that context necessarily bearing all the hallmarks of this Government's obsessive preoccupation with winding back the Commonwealth presence in areas of activity in favour of private sector activity, including private sector professional activity, and also with returning Commonwealth functions to the States. Finally, in this list of genuine grounds of alarm, we also note that the Bill has been introduced in the context of a major squeeze currently being applied in legal aid funding, with a manifest attempt being made, as I will explain again in a few moments, to wind back the base level of financial commitment which the Commonwealth is then obliged to offer to the extent that it maintains any role at all in this area in the future.

The demise of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission has been writing on the wall for some considerable time. There has been ample evidence of that, not least the non-replacement of a number of retired commissioners in recent months and, indeed, the operation of the Commission without even a formal quorum, I notice, for that period. There are some people-apparently among their ranks is the present chairman of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission, Mr Justice Else-Mitchell-who will not be heard publicly to be mourning its passing. But the Opposition does mourn the passing of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission. It opposes this Bill. We take this view because we regard the Bill as being important for what it does in itself-that is, as I will go on to explain, substantially limiting the effectiveness of legal aid research, co-ordination, funding and delivery-but also, because of what it presages or foreshadows, perhaps what it forebodes, about the future of Commonwealth involvement in the whole area of legal aid funding. The basis of our opposition to this Bill is perhaps most succinctly embodied in the second reading amendment which has been circulated to honourable senators. I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Senate is of the opinion that-

(A) The Commonwealth has a continuing national responsibility for the funding of legal aid, the States having amply demonstrated in the past that they have neither the resources nor the inclination to ensure equal access to the law;
(B) The Commonwealth has an indispensable national role in the formulation of legal aid policy so as to ensure that legal services are delivered on a co-ordinated, rational and equitable basis;
(C) The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission has a central national role to play in research, evaluating, advising upon, co-ordinating and monitoring the funding and delivery of legal aid services;

(D) The present functions of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission cannot be performed as adequately or effectively by a part time advisory Council and an Attorney-General's Department already subject to severe staffing constraints; and

(E) The proposals to abolish the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission, to curtail the functions and limit the independence of its successor advisory Council, to limit the number of full time officials working on legal aid policy and funding, are all to be deplored as marking the first steps toward the Commonwealth's ultimate abandonment of responsibility for legal aid funding'.

COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION ACT 1977
Functions of Commission

6. The functions of the Commission are- (a) to ascertain, and keep under review, the extent of the need for legal assistance in Australia and, in particular, the need for legal assistance in respect of Commonwealth matters and to make recommendations from time to time to the Attorney-General as to the most effective, economical and desirable means of satisfying that need;

(b) to make recommendations to the Attorney-General and to legal aid commissions of States and Territories concerning the provision of legal assistance by those legal aid commissions in respect of Commonwealth matters and, in particular, to make recommendations as to-
(i) the manner in which legal assistance should be provided in respect of Commonwealth matters;
(ii) the criteria to be applied in determining whether legal assistance should be provided to a person in respect of a Commonwealth matter;
(iii) the extent of any contributions to be required to be paid by a person to whom legal assistance is provided in respect of a Commonwealth matter; and
(iv) the priorities to be observed in the provision of legal assistance in respect of Commonwealth matters as between different classes of persons or different classes of matters;
(c) to collect and publish statistics concerning the operation of schemes for the provision of legal assistance in Australia;

(d) to report to the Attorney-General upon the functioning of legal aid commissions of States and Territories including the accessibility of those commissions to persons requiring legal assistance and the effectiveness and economy of the provision of legal assistance by those commissions;

(e) to furnish to the Attorney-General such reports as the Attorney-General requires concerning the functioning and effectiveness of other schemes for the provision of legal assistance, being schemes that operate, whether wholly or partly, with financial assistance from the Commonwealth;

(f) to liaise and co-operate with, and to make recommendations to, the Attorney-General concerning the co-ordination of the operations of, legal aid commissions of States and Territories and other bodies providing, or interested in the provision of, legal assistance;
(g) to undertake research into all aspects of legal assistance including new methods of financing and providing legal assistance;

(h) to advise the Attorney-General as to the educational programs that would be effective in promoting an understanding by the public, or by sections of the public that have special needs in this respect, of their rights, powers, privileges, and duties under laws in force in Australia;
(j) as requested by the Attorney-General, to report to the Attorney-General as to the provision by the Commonwealth of financial assistance to legal aid commissions of States and Territories;

(k) to determine applications for the provision of legal or financial assistance by the Commonwealth in Commonwealth matters in which the Commission is authorized to do so by an Act other than this Act or is directed to do so by the Attorney-General;
(l) to advise the Attorney-General on the provision of legal assistance or financial assistance in any Commonwealth matter referred by the Attorney-General for advice; and
(m) to advise the Attorney-General as to such other matters relating to the provision of legal assistance as the Attorney-General requests or the Commission considers appropriate.
