(b) to advise, and make recommendations to, the Attorney-General, either of its own motion or upon request made by the Attorney-General, concerning-
(i) the provision by the Commonwealth of financial assistance in respect of the cost of providing legal assistance; and
(ii) the effectiveness of arrangements for the application of financial assistance provided by the Commonwealth in respect of the cost of providing legal assistance; and
(c) to advise, and make recommendations to, the Attorney-General, upon request made by the Attorney-General, concerning any other matter relating to the provision of legal assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second point is that the lack of independence in exercising those functions that are to be retained is again evident when we look at the language in which these functions are described. When we go down the list of functions that are set out in the 1977 Act, we see that the role of the Commission is to advise, to conduct research, to collect information, to act in various ways in each case on its own motion, there being only one exception, in section 6 (j), which states that certain advice about State commissions is to be offered only as requested by the Attorney-General. But overwhelmingly the functions are to be exercised by the Commission itself, whereas by contrast if we look to the relevant clause of the current Bill just incorporated in Hansard, which will go into the Act, we see that advice on the advisory council's own motion can be given only with respect to a quite narrow range of financial questions and that the larger questions as to the appropriateness of particular mechanisms for legal aid delivery and so on can be the subject of attention by the advisory council only if the Attorney-General specifically requests the council to engage in that sort of activity. There is a very real question as to whether an Attorney-General-any Attorney-General-in this particular brand of government would request the advisory council to look at things which might undermine the particular ideological fixations which this Government has.

SPEECH.PARA: Again looking at what this Bill does, the third point is that no advisory function at all is now specifically identified with respect to the funding and delivery of legal aid in the States or through State commissions. Since most legal aid, to the extent that funding is to continue at all, will in fact be delivered via State commissions, this clearly renders quite negligible any residual function the advisory council might have been able to perform in respect of the co-ordination or the rationalisation of legal aid services-the making of a more equitable system of legal aid delivery around the nation. I further make the point that the composition of the new advisory council is not to be such as to encourage any rational belief in the independence of the new council either from the Government or, more importantly perhaps, from the mainstream private legal profession. I think this point is again made most succinctly by incorporating in Hansard the two relevant provisions from the respective pieces of legislation, that is, section 5 of the existing Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Act and what will be the new section 4 of the Act as amended by the present Bill. I seek leave to incorporate those two provisions in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION ACT 1977
Constitution of Commission
5. (1) The Commission shall be constituted by-
(a) a Chairman;
(b) a Deputy Chairman;
(c) 2 Commissioners nominated by the Attorney-General;
(d) 2 Commissioners nominated by the Attorneys-General of the States in which legal aid commissions have been established;
(e) a Commissioner nominated by the Law Council of Australia; and
(f) a Commissioner nominated by the Australian Council of Social Service.

(2) The Chairman, the Deputy Chairman and the other Commissioners shall be appointed by the Governor-General, the Deputy Chairman being appointed to hold office on a full-time basis and the Chairman and the other Commissioners being appointed to hold office on a part-time basis.
(3) The performance of the functions, or the exercise of the powers, of the Commission is not affected by reason of there being a vacancy or vacancies in the membership of the Commission.
COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1981
Establishment and constitution of Council
''4. (1) The Attorney-General may establish a Commonwealth Legal Aid Council.
''(2) The Council shall consist of-
(a) a Chairman;
(b) 2 members appointed after consultation between the Attorney-General and the Attorneys-General of the States in which legal aid commissions have been established;
(c) a member appointed after consultation between the Attorney-General and the Law Council of Australia;
(d) a member appointed after consultation between the Attorney-General and the Australian Council of Social Service; and
(e) 2 other members.
''(3) The Chairman and the other members of the Council shall be appointed by the Attorney-General to hold office on a part-time basis.
''(4) The performance of the functions, or the exercise of the powers, of the Council is not affected by reason of there being a vacancy or vacancies in the membership of the Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we look at the composition proposed for the new Advisory Council, we see that all the nominations for membership of the Commission are now in the hands of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). We have lost the situation of the Australian Council of Social Service being able to nominate its own representatives in its own right. The most distance that its rights extend at the moment is to be on the receiving end of consultation from the Attorney-General as to who the nominees should be. It might be claimed that this is some kind of purely technical provision to accommodate the change in the contemplated structure of the Council from a commission appointed by the Governor-General to simply an advisory body. I simply make the point that the change in the composition of the body in this way has manifestly, on the face of it, created the possibility for less independent voices being part of its operations.
—That would depend on the way it is administered.

—Of course it would depend on the way it was administered. The option is there for it to be administered credibly and sensibly with nominee of ACOSS being given the appointment automatically. But it also has the potential for maladministration, and I think it is proper for the Senate and the Parliament to seek some further and better explanation for why the language has been changed, if indeed it is the intention to proceed in the future by way of there being an express nomination from ACOSS, and indeed, from the other bodies which are subject to these same proceedings, namely, the Law Council of Australia and the State commissions which are to have two representatives, if that is still the right word, on the new council. The Attorney-General retains the right to appoint not only the chairman but also two additional members solely at his own discretion, and again one would hope that he would use that right to appoint persons who have had a background or have current experience in the delivery of legal aid at the work face level, either in community legal services or in the salaried State commissions. But there is absolutely no guarantee that that will in fact happen, that those two residual places will be used up in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the point can obviously be made that with the composition thus being as it is and with the abandonment, incidentally, of the position of deputy chairman, which hitherto has been the sole full time part of the operation, the situation remains that there is a very real possibility-I refer again to the context in which this Bill comes forward; it is very much a part of the razor gang exercise-and, indeed, a probability that excessive deference will be paid in the future operation of legal aid and the operations of this Council to the interests of the private legal profession rather than to the consumers of the services that legal aid lawyers should provide. Certainly, there is ample evidence mounting generally that this Government is all too happy to look after the interests of the private legal profession.

The razor gang report makes explicit reference to the decision of the Commonwealth to make increasing use of private lawyers to perform essential functions on a contract basis. I ask the Government: Has it not heard what the leading lights of the profession have been charging the Commonwealth lately for the exercise of their services? Has it not heard-no doubt the Attorney-General will have heard this because he was sitting in on the Estimates Committee hearing on 27 April when this matter was discussed; it is recorded at page 17 of the Hansard report of Estimates Committee A-that Mr David Rofe, Q.C., is now being paid $1,070 a day as the social security conspiracy case in Sydney moves into its twenty-fifth month? The Attorney will also be aware that Mr Frank Costigan is being paid $1,200 a day for the first nine months of his chairmanship of the Royal Commission into the Federated Painters and Dockers Union of Australia, although here no doubt there is an element of danger money built into this particular commission, as was indeed acknowledged when this matter was discussed in the Senate Estimates Committee on 27 April, as recorded at page 19 of the report.

No doubt he will be aware also-I hope that he is aware also-that Mr Richard Searby, Q.C., is being paid $20,000 for the three months that he spends between attending CRA, Murdoch, Ansett and Shell board meetings as a consultant to the Commonwealth in its current review-what the status of this will be in light of its new proposed review nobody knows-of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, even though Mr Searby's actual experience in the industrial jurisdiction has been 'limited' according to Mr Mick Keogh, the Secretary to the Department of Industrial Relations in his evidence to Senate Estimates Committee A on 27 April. That evidence appears at page 50 of the report, should anyone be minded to look up the saga of Mr Searby.

Those sorts of illustrations can be multiplied-maybe in funny sorts of ways they are one off cases-but the basic point remains that it is an enormously expensive business to deliver effective qualified legal services otherwise than on a salaried basis. That is crucial when one gets to the area of legal aid. It is crucial across the board. No doubt honourable senators will have seen the rather cautiously prepared statement of the Australian Government Lawyers Association in the Press recently as its response to the razor gang statement that I quoted, that the best estimates were that for the general provision of legal services on routine Crown law type matters the proper comparative cost basis was about $20 an hour for the salaried lawyer as compared with much closer to $60 an hour, because of the overhead factors that have to be built in, in the case of work performed by the private legal profession. All the evidence is that, in the context of legal aid, which is the one with which we are concerned in this case, it is at least twice as cheap to deliver legal aid through salaried professionals as it is through the private profession.

Until perhaps further research is done, the most authoritative study is the 1980 report of the research and education section of the South Australian legal services commission-research reported in a recent issue of the Legal Services Bulletin which shows quite beyond doubt that it is three times more expensive to go to private lawyers in criminal cases, and on average twice as expensive to do that in family and civil matters generally. That estimate follows earlier ones which were prepared by the Australian Law Reform Commission in 1975 in its criminal investigation report, and also by the Sackville law and poverty report which suggested again in both cases that salaried lawyers could handle cases at roughly half the cost of them being referred out to private practitioners.

The point is that if the composition of the Advisory Council is to reflect, as it now quite manifestly can should the Attorney-General be minded to appoint its members in this way the dominant concerns of the private legal profession, which the razor gang ideology would have us overtly believe is likely to be the case, then it will be a very much more expensive business to deliver effective legal aid. Either it is going to be more expensive or only half the number of people are likely to benefit from such largesse as the Commonwealth will provide.

I make one further point about comparative costs of these things, and that is that it is crucial that the work which was set in train by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission to establish the cost effectiveness on salaried lawyers delivering legal aid once and for all to put the matter absolutely and unequivocally beyond doubt by a very expensive and thoroughly researched project be brought to completion. Already there has been something like $45,000 of taxpayers money spent to bring that study to its present stage. It will be a most unhappy result if the ideological combination of this Government and the private legal profession, which we can see is all to cosily likely to emerge under the new arrangements if this Bill is carried, killed off that project. I make the point that generally, since we are on the subject of costs, that the costs of the operation of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission, for which the original estimate for this financial year 1980-81 was $700,000 is absolutely negligible when it is set against the total funding provided by the Commonwealth for legal aid-$26.9m in this financial year, and that is excluding Aboriginal legal aid. Of course it became negligible when we take into account the functions that the Commission has been performing and is certainly likely to go on performing if its survival were assured.

Rather more briefly, let me now finally turn to the other ground of opposition of the Australian Labor Party, and I hope of other honourable senators, to this Bill. I have been talking so far solely about the implications of the Bill on the structure of the Commission, now to be the Council, and the implications that that will have for the effectiveness of the research, the co-ordination and the monitoring role that that body has been performing. I have been indicating how unhappy I and the Opposition are about the implications of this change. Let me now talk to the other side of our concern which goes rather beyond that, and that is our concern about what this Bill foreshadows or forebodes so far as the future of Commonwealth funding in this area is concerned. It is the contention of members of the Opposition, as we say in paragraph (E) of the amendment, that the proposal to abolish the Commission, to curtail its functions, to limit the independence of its successor council, to limit the number of full time officials working on legal aid policy and funding all, when read together, do mark the first steps toward the Commonwealth's ultimate abandonment of responsibility for legal aid funding.

The Attorney-General has made various public statements that the Government has no such intention, that it will stay in the field, that the real level of Commonwealth commitment will be maintained. Indeed, he has gone so far-it is unusual for the Attorney in public-as to describe my claims as being absurd. I remind him of what another government Minister said recently of another set of Government commitments of an almost equally precisely formulated kind. I refer to what Mr MacKellar said in the House of Representatives on 5 May as recorded at page 1960 of Hansard. He stated:
. . . no government can be required to continue with policies which bring about results inconsistent with other government policies . . .

In other words, how can we be expected to keep our promises when we change our policies? What I am suggesting here is that what we are witnessing is a very definite change in direction on the part of this Government. It foreshadows as clearly as any signalling could possibly do that the Commonwealth is ultimately getting out of legal aid. It wants to wind back its degree of commitment. It does not want to have a mainstream policy role in the formulation of legal aid policy and determining the way in which legal aid services are delivered. It wants to opt out and stand back from the fray and invest more and more of these sorts of functions in the State commissions which have now been created.

The Attorney talks about the Commonwealth's funding commitment being embodied in agreements-agreements with four States, Western Australia, Queensland, South Australia and Victoria. But in a recent Estimates committee hearing it has emerged-the very same committee hearings that we talked about on 27 April-that the language of these agreements, to the extent that they have been made public, is very rubbery indeed. The Commonwealth's commitment to maintain 'the level of legal aid' means no more or less than what the Government chooses it to mean. To the extent that it does mean anything it does, of course, mean that it is very much in the Commonwealth's interest-at least in the case of Victoria where the agreement comes into effective operation at last on 1 July this year-to wind back its present level of funding to the minimum possible because it is on this year's figures that future funding, if this is to be taken at face value, will be based. As I have suggested, this consideration is the origin of the present crisis in the funding of legal aid in Victoria which as already been the subject of a good deal of attention in recent weeks.

As time is getting on I do not want to retread unnecessarily the ground which has been well covered in various contexts in this Parliament, particularly by Estimates Committee A on 27 April, but I remind the Senate that this year there is a shortfall of $1m in the Federal funds available to the Victorial legal aid office. This means that unless some counter action is taken around 1,800 people who would normally have got aid in the last three months of this financial year will not be able to get it. I remind the Senate that attempts have been made, on the word of the Attorney-General, to cover the extra load by bringing more work back into the office. I advise the Senate that this measure has failed because of the absence of a sufficient number of lawyers and back-up staff to enable the work of that office to proceed effectively. It is a situation which has become so bad that legal aid lawyers in Melbourne-as dedicated as they are-have had to impose work bans in a so far futile attempt to get their message across. I remind the Senate that attempts to use additional lawyers to cover the backlog have proved quite ineffective to the extent that in a number of instances it has been merely a matter of robbing one service in order to provide another. The duty solicitor system in the Family Court of Australia has had to be wound down in order to try desperately to redress the situation in Victoria.

I further advise the Senate that on my advice none of the measures that have been taken so far appears to make any difference whatsover to the circumstances. The Attorney promised that he would review the situation this month-round about now-and determine what, if any, extra assistance would be offered but nothing has emerged so far from the Attorney's lips to tell us what is going on. That is the situation in just one State. I could spend time, but I will not, describing what the situation is in Queensland, which I visited a few days ago. I examined in a lot of detail the legal aid situation on the ground there. What I am simply doing is suggesting that the Commonwealth is no longer providing a proper level of funding for legal aid. The situation, certainly in Victoria, demonstrates that. That in turn demonstrates that the writing is on the wall so far as the future for legal aid is concerned. I make the point that the winding back in Commonwealth finance and in the whole policy that is associated with that is entirely consistent with the razor gang ideology that we have seen emerging to fruition in recent days and weeks.

I make the further point that there is an inexorable connection between a continuing Commonwealth financial commitment to legal aid and the continued existence with significant functions of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission. Finally, I make the point that the abolition of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission is bad in itself but it is absolutely disastrous for what it promises for the future. That is why we oppose the Bill and urge the Senate to support the amendment which makes that concern clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Amendment Bill and support its second reading. I have heard the speech which Senator Evans has just delivered and I readily agree that there are problems and worries associated with legal aid and the future of Commonwealth involvement in this area. However, I recognise the reasons which have been given for introducing this Bill and which can be seen in some detail in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission, which we have had for some years but which will be abolished by this Bill and replaced by a council, has undertaken a role described by the Attorney-General as an advisory, co-ordinating and monitoring role. The functions which are set out in the original legislation include the right and duty of the Commission to perform these various roles. I think that in the last few years the Commission has performed a good service in these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission also has the functions of keeping the need for legal assistance in Australia under review, of making recommendations to the Attorney-General and to the State and Territory commissions, of collecting and publishing statistics, of undertaking research and furnishing an annual report for tabling in Parliament. I believe that it can be said that the changes which are made in this Bill do not fundamentally change those roles although, of course, it will be necessary for us to supervise carefully the way in which the roles are performed by the new council. Senator Evans spoke of it as being a part time operation. The amendment which the Opposition puts forward refers to it in that way. But of course it has been essentially a part time operation. There was a full time vice chairman but most of the officers were part time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty full time staff.

—It had a separate full time staff. I am speaking here of the governing bodies. Of course it will continue to have full time staff but they will be people allocated from the Attorney-General's Department. I understand the reasons that have motivated the Government in feeling that the maintenance of a commission, with the trappings and solemnities which it has and with a separate staff, was an uneconomic and to an extent inefficient method of providing the supervision of legal aid.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Council will be properly appointed. I do not accept the criticisms which Senator Evans has made that somehow it will lack independence-I think that is the word he used-because members are appointed on the recommendation of the Attorney-General. In particular Senator Evans referred to the appointment which will be made under this Bill of a member after consultation between the Attorney-General and the Australian Council of Social Service. I do not see any reason for believing that because that is done after consultation there will not thereby be appointed a person who will have the confidence of ACOSS and who will therefore be able to represent on the new council the views of and problems experienced by ACOSS and similar organisations on the delivery of legal aid in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why the change in terminology?

—The change is actually from a commission to a council. A body is being formed which will not have separate staff or a separate structure. Therefore one imagines that the cost of providing legal aid services will be less. The Attorney-General in his second reading speech gave very clear undertakings that there will not be a reduction in the Commonwealth's responsibility in the legal aid field. Of course, it is up to Parliament to scrutinise carefully and to ensure that reductions do not occur and that the fears which the Opposition has expressed in the last part of its amendment do not come to pass. The amendment, which I do not support, goes well beyond the criticisms that I think can properly be made or the fears that can be held. I refer to the part of the amendment which states that the proposals are to be deplored as marking the first step towards the Commonwealth's ultimate abandonment of responsibility for legal aid funding.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has accepted a considerable responsibility for funding. Members on this side of the House are very conscious of that fact and are personally committed to the continuance of that responsibility. I draw attention to that part of the second reading speech where the Attorney-General referred to a question asked by Senator Evans without notice on 26 March. The Attorney-General said:

. . . there is no intention on the part of the Government to reduce its commitments to the level of legal aid or the commitments it has made in agreements with the States to maintain the level of activity of legal aid.

I remind the Senate of those commitments and ask it to consider the Bill in the light of those statements. The Attorney-General goes on to say that he wants to emphasise that it has always been the policy of the Government that no person should be denied legal aid because of lack of means. This is a continuing aim of the Government and is evident from the annual appropriations for legal aid to which the Attorney-General referred. I am not satisfied at this stage that we have achieved that aim to the extent that we ought in this country. I have long felt that the amount which we spend on legal aid, when compared with the expenditures in other areas of social welfare, is not adequate. Perhaps there is not sufficient demand in the community for it. Nonetheless, I think there has been a considerable lack of legal aid particularly for people who have relatively low means but who are not necessarily pensioners or on the poverty line.
I refer now to the remarks which I made last year in the dissenting report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. At page 209 of the report I said:
After an analysis of the evidence available to the Committee as to the limited availability of legal aid through the Australian Legal Aid Office . . . Kerry A. Peterson, LLM, reached this conclusion:

'On these figures the A.L.A.O. aid is seen to reach only the poorest 10 per cent of the population. It might be thought that all of that group were suffering hardship, but they must all pay a contribution towards costs unless they can show that they suffer real financial hardship.'
I went on to say:

The limitation of legal aid basically to those below the poverty line, and the requirement imposed on litigants to pay fees and contributions have all led to a defeat of expectations about the ready availability of family law services.

Because of the limited guidelines, legal aid is largely confined to pensioners, but the real problem is that other persons of small means are thereby deprived of the opportunity of pursuing their rights. Alternatively, they are, in many cases, forced into disadvantageous settlements because of the lack of availability of legal aid. Legal aid given to one party, and unsupervised, may often lead to the bankruptcy of an unaided party. These problems have not been examined in detail by the Committee, but I believe legal aid inadequacies should be regarded as a key defect limiting the effective operation of the family law system.

I was dealing only with family law, but family law is the consumer of a substantial part of Commonwealth legal aid. I believe that that position continues. We have not debated that report yet; we have not considered the matters raised in it. I believe that we cannot in any way be complacent or satisfied with the extent to which legal aid is being delivered in this country. There are many people who may not be the poorest in this country who cannot afford, in any sensible way, to expend the money that is required for litigation and therefore do not secure justice before our courts. I believe we must not in any way let up on the needs which we have to supervise legal aid. The fact that we have now a number of State commissions-not all States have commissions-does not mean that we should not still be scrutinising the situation. I believe that the new council, despite what Senator Evans has said, has substantial power, under its functions, to investigate certain areas. I remind Senator Evans of proposed new section 5 (a) which states that the functions of the Council are:

to ascertain, and keep under review, the extent of the need for legal assistance in Australia and, in particular, the need for legal assistance in respect of Commonwealth matters and to make recommendations from time to time to the Attorney-General as to the most effective, economical and desirable means of satisfying that need;

That is a very broad function. It is not confined to Commonwealth matters; it is concerned with the whole situation of legal aid in this country. I have listened to what has been said in respect of salaried services. I believe that investigations have to be made constantly in that area to see whether legal aid is being delivered in the most efficient and effective way in this community. I believe that in many respects there are areas where there should be less reliance on the private legal system. In fact, the salaried service in many areas can provide quite effective aid to more people than would be the case with the private service. We must know, as must the council which is being appointed under this Bill, what investigations are being made in this area overseas-a lot of work is being done in the United States on this matter-and also what facts are coming forward in Australia as the State commissions operate. We must know whether they are effectively achieving the best use of the legal aid dollar, as it is described from time to time. Overall, I believe that this country has to spend more on legal aid if it is to provide justice for all before the courts.

Some reference was made to the legal aid position in the State of Victoria, from which I come. I am concerned at some recent indications of the way in which the legal aid position has deteriorated, particularly in that State. I am concerned at the overall general financial position of the Victorian Government. My colleague Senator Hamer in a speech last week and Senator Lewis in statements over the weekend have pointed out the perilous situation in Victoria because of the injustice which is being done to this State by the way in which Commonwealth moneys are provided to it. Leaving aside that overall situation, what has been brought to my attention particularly recently in regard to the legal aid situation in the State of Victoria and about which I have had communications with the Attorney-General, are matters, I think, of considerable concern. I have had brought to my attention a document which is a report made by the Legal Aid Commission in Victoria to the State Attorney-General, the Honourable Haddon Storey, Q.C., concerning the availability of Commonwealth funds for the ALAO in Victoria. In the course of that statement the following references are made:
The Deputy Director of the ALAO has estimated that the most optimistic view is that the staff will carry an extra 50 or 60 cases per month by the end of June.
That is June this year. The letter continues:
This compares with an average shortfall of approximately 600 cases per month.

Senator Durack is correct in stating that the duty lawyer in the Family Court has only been temporarily suspended: Whilst the reallocation of the solicitor will assist capacity, it effectively is a reduction in the level of existing legal aid services immediately prior to the advent of the Commission and would therefore appear to be contrary to the spirit of the Agreement.
On the subject of redefinition of merit, the statement reads:

Whilst Senator Durack states 'no arrangements are in hand to redefine the notion of merit to exclude applications which would otherwise be within the guidelines' it is clear that the guidelines are being applied more stringently so that some persons who would have qualified for legal aid a month ago are now being rejected.
It will be disastrous to the working of the Commission and the provision of legal aid in Victoria if the Commission is forced to commence operations with a backlog.
The Commission is about to commence in Victoria in this situation. Finally the statement reads:

I am informed that the restrictions imposed by the ALAO has resulted in an increased demand for aid to the Legal Aid Committee which if granted will of course increase the State's level of funding for the 12-month period leading up to the commencement of this Commission.

This material was forwarded to me by Mr Richard Alston, who apart from being the President of the Liberal Party of Victoria is an eminent barrister in that State. In the letter which he wrote to me at the beginning of this month in connection with this material he said:

You will note from the enclosed material that the funds made available to the Victorian office have been consumed more quickly than had been anticipated because of an unexpected increase in the number of applications. The end result is there are presently very many persons who are not able to receive Legal Aid not because their applications are unmeritorious but because funds are simply not presently available. The problem is especially criticial in that the formula for future funding will be related to the base figure established for the current year and if such amount does not meet current demands the problem can only be exacerbated.

I am concerned that, as we move into an era in which State commissions are taking their place, as one is in Victoria, there is a backlog of cases. It is not a matter of inefficiency on the part of the ALAO in Victoria because the number of items dealt with by the legal aid staff for each person each year was 524 in Victoria compared with 291 in New South Wales. So it is not a matter of inefficiency on the part of the office in Victoria which has been operating for some time, but it is a problem which obviously will continue to confront legal aid in Victoria in particular. I am concerned that the Commonwealth, which is maintaining its present obligation, should be very concerned about the legal aid situation, particularly in the State of Victoria.

I therefore believe this Bill cannot represent any winding down of the commitment of the Commonwealth. I am sure that we on this side of the chamber will be most vigilant to ensure that nothing like that occurs. I urge the Government to consider the crises which exist at the present time and in particular to keep a very vigilant observance of the obligations which the Liberal and Country Party governments have now accepted for a number of years to ensure that nothing that comes from this Bill, which is a variation of the system of legal aid, shall lead to any running down of the commitment which we have. I trust that the Attorney will in his reply avert to the situation in Victoria which concerns me very much and I also hope that we will see a continued success and an increase in the effective use of legal aid in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the Opposition has seen fit to oppose entirely the Bill which seeks to replace the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission with the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council. I thought from the tenor of the amendment to the second reading motion that the Opposition was attempting simply to put down on the record some of its concerns and its own policy in relation to this matter, but it is obvious from the speech by Senator Evans that the Opposition will oppose the Bill. However, I am heartened by the support of Senator Missen in this matter-I am sure he is speaking on behalf of honourable senators on this side of the chamber-and with that support I am confident the Bill will be given a second reading by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with the points that have been made by Senator Evans as quickly as I can because time is becoming somewhat limited for the debate on this measure. The Commonwealth does recognise that it has a continuing national responsibility in funding legal aid. It is, I think, perhaps a little unfair to describe the States in the language used in one limb of the amendment, but it is a fact that State contributions have not been very significant in this area. I would hope that with the State commissions that are being established the States will in due course will be able to contribute a little more than they have contributed so far. Of course the legal aid effort has varied between the States. Some States have provided significantly more than others and before the Legal Aid Commission was established they traditionally provided more legal aid than the Commonwealth. Broadly I think the picture now is that the Commonwealth has acquired a greater responsibility for funding legal aid than the States.

The structure that we now have to implement, that is, the establishment of State commissions as the bodies which will deliver the legal aid, is, I believe, a very proper one. I have spoken on this matter on other occasions. I believe it is not appropriate to have any Commonwealth department as a vehicle for the actual delivery of legal aid because of conflict of interest problems that emerge. It is better for legal aid to be delivered and to be administered as close to the clients as possible. That is one reason why I am particularly keen to encourage the development of community legal aid centres. I am very pleased that I have been able to get an ongoing program, small and all as it is. But the important thing is that it has been established. I hope that over the years ahead these bodies will grow and that there will be an ability on the part not only of the Commonwealth Government but also the State governments to provide funds for these bodies. I have no doubt that legal aid is better delivered, as I said, the closer one is to the client and to his problems.

The third point of Senator Evans's amendment, which I accept, is that the Commonwealth has a role to play in providing research and in generally evaluating the way in which legal aid is being delivered and the funding that is necessary. Of course, the Commonwealth's role is the vital role of providing the funds. The role of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission was set out in my second reading speech. The priorities which it adopted in this area and the functions that the advisory council will perform are broadly the ones that the Commission, of its own motion, has adopted in recent times. It may have had larger ideas about what it would do if the document that Senator Evans has incorporated was at any time the policy of the Commission. I do not know whether it was, but I do not dispute that the document was a genuine document emanating at some stage from the Commission. I would have just liked to know when it was and who prepared it, but Senator Evans has not been able to provide us with that information. Nevertheless, at some stage an expanded role was certainly entertained for the Commission.

As I said, the Commission had come to accept a more realistic role. I referred in my second reading speech to the priorities which it established. I might say that that is the basic reason this Bill is before the Senate. We do not see in the long term a large bureaucratic body providing purely an administrative and co-ordinating role, which undoubtedly is a most expensive exercise and, in the view of the Government, an unnecessary exercise. I have had some calculations made as to what savings may be anticipated by the change from the Commission, with all the panoply that goes with these independent statutory commissions, to a more modest body such as the proposed legal aid council. I can speak to the estimates only in the broad at this stage as they have not yet been through the Budget process, but we expect a saving next year of approximately $450,000. The present Commission has a staff of 18. Of that 18 only three are lawyers. There are nine clerks and one clerical assistant, together with some steno-secretaries. Really, that shows the sort of thing that happens when these independent statutory bodies are set up with the structure of a commission. They become bloated administrative structures. That is the very thing we are trying to avoid. I might say that $450,000 might go quite a long way at present towards solving the problem in Victoria. I will come back to that in a moment--

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that is where it goes.

—Yes, but I cannot say that at the moment. That is the trouble. We budget from year to year, as the honourable senator well knows. It is intended that research should be continue on a modest scale. It is certainly a role which I think the Commonwealth, as part of its responsibility, should maintain. The exercise that Senator Evans is interested in many-lawyers concerned with legal aid and I would be very interested in-is to evaluate the relative cost of providing legal aid by salaried officers as against the private profession will continue. It has already been assigned to Professor Meredith of the University of New England. The funds will continue to be provided for that purpose, and I have no doubt that other research projects will be embarked upon from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: The structure of the Commission has been mentioned. I have deliberately incorporated in the Bill broadly the same structure for the Council-that is, the representative nature of the council-as was provided for by the Commission. I do not favour-the Government agrees with this proposition-a situation in which one is bound to accept the one nominee of a body. I believe it is much more appropriate that names should be submitted and consultations should take place in relation to a person who is to represent that body's interests. But I can assure the Senate that it is my intention that the representatives of these various bodies would be concerned with the administration of legal aid. That is provided in the structure of the Council. I think I am entitled to expect the Senate to accept my bona fides in this because I am the person who set up the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission. In addition to those who were actually nominated, I appointed to the first commission a representative from community legal aid centres and a professor of social work. At this stage I have not decided upon the final structure of the Commission but I think that the Senate might bear in mind that I have a record of appointing to the Commission people who are concerned broadly with legal aid and I have not confined the Commission simply to those representing the private legal profession.

I think that most of the matters, apart from the Victorian situation, have been mentioned. I have already made a commitment to the continuance of Commonwealth funding for legal aid. I note that Senator Evans has again said that this proposal spells the end or is what he describes as the first steps towards the Commonwealth's abandonment of responsibility for legal aid funding. I can only reiterate the commitments that the Government has entered into, which I have constantly stressed and which I stress again. In fact, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission does not provide the funds. The funds are provided through the Budget process by this Parliament. As responsible Minister my responsibility is to obtain those funds. There is no difference, in obtaining the funds, whether we have the existing Commission or an advisory council. There is absolutely no basis whatever for the proposition contained in the amendment that this is the first step to the Commonwealth's abandonment of responsibility for legal aid.

I did not wish to enter into a debate about the Victorian situation. It is really not relevant to the matter before the Senate. However, Senator Evans has referred to it and Senator Missen, in particular, requested that I mention it. As I have said when I have been asked questions about it, I am keeping the matter under close observation. It is one that causes me concern. It is unfortunate that the demand for legal aid is not always predictable, that with the best planning in the world-it is necessary to have strict planning and commitment levels, financial controls and so on-the actual demand does not always match one's predictions. Certainly it seems now that the demand for legal aid in Victoria and in Tasmania-a State whose needs should not be forgotten-has exceeded the forecasts. That is showing up at the end of the financial year in the problems that are now being experienced. Those problems are not new. They occurred several years ago, but not then in proportions quite as serious as those of the moment.

I would like to give the Senate the figures on the provision of legal aid in both Victoria and Tasmania. When all is said and done, in the end it is a question of how much money can be found for the purpose. In 1979-80 expenditure on legal aid in Victoria totalled $4,845,000. For this year the estimated expenditure will be $6,534,000, which represents an increase of 33.84 per cent over the figure for 1979-80. For Tasmania the respective figures are $1,217,000 and $1,637,000, representing an increase for this year of 34.53 per cent. Thus there have been great increases in expenditure on legal aid in both States and it cannot be said, to use a favourite phrase of many people, in Victoria especially, that the Commonwealth is cutting back.

Certainly there is a problem in that unfortunately those who fall within the guidelines and whose cases render them eligible may not, because making provision for them would be outside the commitment budgeted, be the subject of a reference being made immediately. That is not to say that they will be denied legal aid; it has merely to be deferred. Of course urgent cases are not deferred. If a case should become urgent it will be reviewed. Unfortunately, the problem is compounded because the officers of the Australian Legal Aid Office have then to do a lot more administrative work.

The problem should not be seen in the light that 1,500 or so people are to be denied legal aid, or that the Victorian Legal Aid Commission will be landed with a deficit when it takes over. I hope that ways and means can be found to avoid that prospect happening and that no one whose case makes him eligible, even though a reference may be deferred, will be denied legal aid. Its granting may simply be delayed.

I am not in a position at this stage to say anything further about the Victorian situation except to assure the Senate that it is one which gives me great concern and which I hope we will be able to resolve in due course, without the Victorian Legal Aid Commission beginning its operations with a deficit. As I understand it now, the Commission will not begin to operate on 1 July. I do not know how many such deferments have taken place. The Commission has been set up for some time. Perhaps we would not have had quite such a problem now if the Commission had been in business. It would have been meeting only 80 per cent of the cost of fees, instead of the 90 per cent that must be met by the Australian Legal Aid Office-except in family law matters, in respect of which a special scale applies. Thus, if the Victorian Commission had been in business earlier savings could have been effected this year. Therefore, I am very anxious that the Commission should become operative as soon as possible. I do not want to see it begin its operations with a deficit.

I hope that the Senate will agree that this proposal is a sound one. It will not mean the abandonment or diminution of the Commonwealth's role in providing legal aid. I believe it will result in the saving of administrative costs and will prove a beneficial proposal. I hope that the Senate will agree to it.

ESTIMATES COMMITTEE A
REPORT TO THE SENATE
Estimates Committee A has the honour to report to the Senate.
1. On 2 April 1981, the Senate referred to the Committee the Additional Estimates for the year 1980-81 relating to the following Departments:
Parliament
Attorney-General's
Industrial Relations
Business and Consumer Affairs.

2. The Committee has considered these Additional Estimates, together with the Departmental Explanatory Notes, and has received evidence in relation to them from the Chairman of Committees, Senator Maunsell, the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, and officers of the Departments concerned. Copies of the Minutes of Proceedings and Hansard reports of the evidence taken by the Committee are tabled for the information of the Senate in connection with Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1980-81. Answers to questions which were deferred and subsequently given in writing since the Committee's last hearings will be tabled in the Senate and incorporated in the final Hansard report of the Committee's hearings.
3. The Committee draws the attention of the Senate to the following matters arising from its consideration of the Additional Estimates:
ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT
(a) Counsel's Fees
On 18 September 1980, the Senate adopted a report of the Committee of the Whole which included a resolution affirming:

that the right to privacy of individual counsel accepting a brief on behalf of the Commonwealth for which money is appropriated by Parliament is supervened by such acceptance, subject to the reasons for the information being clearly defined and to the proviso that injudicious or unwarranted invasion of privacy is not the intention of the Parliament or its Committees.

During debate on the Report of Estimates Committee B which gave rise to the affirmation, the Attorney-General indicated in the Senate his reservations concerning the desirability of releasing such information.

This question was again raised during the Committee's most recent hearings. The Attorney-General advised the Committee that he had received representations from Counsel, and from the President of the Bar Council of New South Wales supporting the representations made, concerning the implications of the Committee's request for details of individual counsel's fees.

The Committee, having considered the matter further at a private meeting, concluded that for the purposes of this hearing it must, under the terms of the Senate resolution, continue the established practice. It emphasises the point made in its last Report that, in each case where the information was sought, the specific reason for seeking such information was clearly defined, and that injudicious or unwarranted invasion of privacy was not the Committee's intention or practice.

However, in view of the concern expressed, the Committee has written to the President of the New South Wales Council inviting him to make a submission to the Committee expanding upon the reasons for the Council's objections to the attitude the Committee has taken. Should the Council put forward a compelling case in support of its objections, the Committee could raise the matter for the further consideration of the Senate. In the meantime, the Committee intends to continue the current practice which applies to all consultants and others providing professional services paid for from public moneys.
The decision of the Committee was conveyed to the Attorney-General, who provided the Committee with the outstanding information which had been sought at the public hearings on 27 April 1981.
(b) Payments to Judges

A recurring theme in Estimates Committees' examination of the proposed appropriations for the Attorney-General's Department has been the making of certain payments to judges without legislative authority. The objections raised over a long period were finally met by the passage of appropriate legislation through the Parliament in 1979.

The Additional Estimates for 1980-81, however, revealed that a total of $154,400 had been paid through the Advance to the Minister for Finance to certain Australian judges of the Supreme Court of Justice of Papua New Guinea. It was explained to the Committee that the payments had been made in fulfilment of a long-standing agreement made between the Attorney-General and the judges concerned, at the time when independence was taking place and before the question of legislative backing for such payments was finally determined within Australia. Legislative provision for this agreement was made in Papua New Guinea and upon a basis that Australia would pay any amount not paid by the Government of Papua New Guinea.

It appears to the Committee, following consideration of explanations provided at the hearing, that there is an identifiable difference in principle between payments made without Australian legislative authority in this instance, on the one hand, and payments made to judges within Australia without such authority, on the other. The major difference perceived by the Committee is that the payments made to the judges serving in Papua New Guinea were a form of international aid for which Australia has assumed a responsibility to make payments. This is in contrast to the principle which the Committee has sought to uphold-that the financial arrangements between the government and judiciary of a country should be totally known and made public within that country, to avoid the possibility of a government influencing a judiciary by offering private terms.
DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS
Industrial Relations Bureau

The Committee noted that the Industrial Relations Bureau had been able to absorb all National Wage and work value costs within its existing appropriation for staffing. The Director of the Bureau explained that this had been achieved because certain separations and retirements allowed for in the original estimates had not eventuated. The Committee notes that as a result of the Committee's report to the Senate in September 1980 and the Senate resolutions of 18 September and 4 December 1980, the Department of Finance is conducting an investigation into the Bureau. We await with interest the report of the Department of Finance, which is expected to be tabled shortly, on the financial management of the Bureau.

The Committee also identified two problems experienced by the Bureau in relation to telecommunications costs. The first concerned the Bureau's seeking an increase in Estimates flowing from two-monthly billing in lieu of quarterly billing by Telecom. This problem did not appear to have occurred within other departments examined by the Committee. The second related to the cost of a Telecom installation within the Bureau, which was seriously underestimated at the time the original estimates were prepared. It was not clear to the Committee whether the miscalculation had occurred as the result of inadequate technical advice or of uncertainty as to the requirements of the Bureau. The Committee suggests, however, that both matters might be taken up by the Committee responsible for examining the Telecom and Industrial Relations Bureau Estimates during the Budget Sittings.
General Comments
Departmental Hire Car Charges

The Committee noted, in the course of its hearings, the dependency of all departments and authorities upon the purchasing and hiring practices of the Department of Administrative Services in relation to the provision of cars. For example, following its examination of the Estimates of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs-a substantial full-time user of Commonwealth vehicles with a hiring cost to the Department of more than $1 million annually-the Committee concluded that, with the average cost of hire cars being approximately $4,000 per year, and bearing in mind the sales tax exempt discount buying facility available to the Commonwealth, the Department of Administrative Services must be receiving almost the full purchase price of the average vehicle in annual hiring charges. Officers of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs informed the Committee that the vehicles used by the Department were replaced every 2 to 3 years. Thus, prima facie, the Department of Administrative Services appears to be charging more than double the new-car price over the life of a hire-car.

It was further ascertained that the hire charges were increased in November, with retrospective application to 1 July, and that hapless departments and authorities, with no recourse to other measures such as purchasing their own vehicles, had no alternative but to seek additional estimates or absorb the increased costs.

Estimates Committee B has had occasion in the past to query the high level of hire car charges made by the Department of Administrative Services, and this Committee again draws to the attention of the Senate and the relevant Estimates Committee these latest examples which, in the Committee's view, require further examination.
Departmental Explanatory Notes

The Committee has commented in previous reports on the gradual evolution of Explanatory Notes so that, with some exceptions, departments and authorities are now providing the Committees with invaluable information in a readily-understood form. In the course of the Committee's current examination of the Estimates, two suggestions were made for the improvement of the standardised format, which the Committee commends to the Senate and the Department of Finance for consideration. The first relates to the provision of details of the variation between moneys provided under Appropriation Acts Nos 1 and 2, and the amounts proposed in Bills Nos 3 and 4. The Committee considers that the insertion of such a breakdown in each item would greatly assist in the evaluation of the amounts sought. Secondly, the Committee considers that confusion might be avoided if the headings of the dissection of each item were designated 'Revised' rather than 'Additional' Estimates, or, alternatively, followed the same headings as those used in the general breakdown of the items.
Estimates Committee Hearings

Some discontent was expressed by members of the Committee concerning the circumstances surrounding the holding of the meeting of Estimates Committee A. It was pointed out that, as a consequence of both the airline strike and decisions made in relation to the Committee's hearings, the opportunities for preparation for the meeting were less than adequate.

The Committee was pleased to note, however, the beneficial effects of having a full-time research officer available to it. While, for the reasons mentioned, the Committee was not able to take full advantage of the increased service provided, the Committee has no doubt that its capacity for more effective examination of Estimates at future hearings will be greatly enhanced.

In conclusion, the Committee expresses its appreciation of the assistance given by the Chairman of Committees, the Attorney-General and the officers of the various Departments who assisted the Committee.
P. E. RAE Chairman

Of course, it is widely rumoured at present that Mr Gyngell is to be appointed as a member of the SBS after he has publicly announced that he will go in to a film investment company which will be a private concern of his own. I raise that question because, in view of the Estimates and the evidence given to the Estimates Committee by the SBS, one must have grave doubt about the financial propriety of that organisation, and even greater concern about its financial propriety in the future if someone such as Mr Bruce Gyngell-a person whose creative talents, though not financial skills, I greatly admire-is to be appointed to it.

Another matter relating to communications was the question of the legal fees paid in respect of hearings before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in regard to the application by News Corporation Ltd and associated companies for the licence of Channel 10 in Melbourne. According to the Estimates, Mr Tom Hughes, Q.C. was paid an amount of $7,815 and his junior counsel was paid in excess of $3,000 for an appearance before the High Court when the Labor Party, which was the plaintiff in that action took that matter, and the conduct of the Broadcasting Tribunal therein, to that court. Subsequently Mr Hughes appeared as counsel assisting the Broadcasting Tribunal in a somewhat lengthy hearing in Melbourne. The purpose of that hearing was to determine whether the Murdoch News Corporation was an appropriate licensee of Channel 10 in Melbourne. During the course of the inquiry much information about the nature of Channel 10, as it then was, and of News Corporation's wishes in relation to Channel 10, was tendered. Mr Hughes, as counsel assisting the Tribunal in that matter, was of course privy to that information and to conferences with witnesses who appeared before the Tribunal.

I find it extraordinary that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, having rejected the application for a licence and the applicant having appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, Tom Hughes also should pop up in the appeal-an appeal from a decision in respect of which he assisted the Tribunal in the earlier hearing. In one matter he appeared for the purpose of assisting the Broadcasting Tribunal, yet when an appeal was lodged against the decision of the Tribunal he appeared for the purpose of arguing against it. I am very old-fashioned. I am a Victorian and Mr Hughes comes from the New South Wales Bar, but I find it absolutely extraordinary that a person can earn, as he did, $18,000 in assisting the Broadcasting Tribunal arrive at a decision and then, when someone appeals against that decision, can appear for one of the parties which seeks to overturn it. I hesitate to use words such as 'ethics' or in this case 'absence of ethics' but that is what I am talking about. It is an extraordinary situation which I would hope no tribunal financed and established by this Government and this Parliament would countenance. I only hope that Mr Hughes did not learn that sort of behaviour here, as a parliamentarian. That he should carry it on in the Sydney Bar is a disgrace.

I wish to refer to two other matters. The first relates to the estimates of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I mention those estimates in this context: Officials from the Australian Broadcasting Commission told the Estimates Committee of their concern about the buildings which the ABC occupies. Their concern was expressed in terms of a multiplicity of locations, especially in areas such as Sydney. The report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so-called razor gang report, came out with the fascinating statement that the Australian Broadcasting Commission should take steps as part of government cost saving measures to rationalise its buildings facilities-to rationalise the location of its building facilities particularly in Sydney, one would imagine, because that is where the least rationalisation exists.

The Estimates Committee was informed of this. It was told last year that the Australian Broadcasting Commission was in this difficulty with its buildings. The last three reports of the Commission have stated that it was concerned that its building facilities should be rationalised. In each report it has said to the Government: 'We cannot do that unless you provide us with the money to do it'. Then we had this extraordinarily incompetent report of the so-called razor gang which states, bald faced, as it were, that the ABC should rationalise its building facilities as a cost saving measure. That is an absurd piece of material that came before the Estimates Committee. More particularly, it illustrates the absurdity of the ministerial review committee on Commonwealth Government functions.

Finally, I express my concern about a gentleman called Mr Warby. I think that Senator Martin has mentioned something about him. This matter relates to the estimates for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. Mr Warby is a member of the National Australia Day Committee, a position to which, I suppose, he was appointed because of his transparent virtues. If he has transparent virtues, they are not in the area of finance because Mr Warby also has a motor boat of some kind-I have not been informed about the technical details-which he has been showing around the United States of America. As I recall it, he has now received the benefit of the best part of $200,000 from this Government in order to promote that speed boat around the United States. Senator Martin, as chairman of our Committee, together with other member of the Committee, arranged for the publication in the Committee's report of some comments about the fact that Mr Warby has not accounted for any of the money in any satisfactory way. When he went, as he was required to do, to a firm of accountants in Los Angeles to try to provide some documentary support for his activities in the United States, that firm of accountants had this to say:

Mr Warby has elected to omit substantially all of the disclosures required by generally accepted accounting principles. If the omitted disclosures were included in the statement of cash disbursements, they might influence the user's conclusions about the projects disbursements. Accordingly, this statement of cash disbursements is not designed for those who are not informed about such matters.

What those accountants are saying is that the money spent on them was a waste of money too because Mr Warby has given no account of his expenditure in relation to the speed boat called Spirit of Australia. What is in fact happening in this time of alleged strictures in government expenditure, documented poverty and discontent over low levels of social services in Australia and so on, is that Mr Warby, who is on the National Australia Day Committee-one can only assume for services or something of that kind to the Liberal Party-has been junketing around the United States incurring an expenditure of $200,000 for which he has not been required to account.

How did that come about? It is quite clear from the proceedings of the Estimates committee that no public servant is responsible for that coming about in the way in which it did. It is quite clear that Ministers in this Government-I nominate particularly Mr Ellicott, the former Minister for Home Affairs, and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-were responsible for arranging for Mr Warby to have that money contrary to the rules which normally apply to grants of this kind. All sorts of sportsmen in this country cannot get support for sporting activities. There is one-not a sportsman in the traditional sense-who is showing off a speedboat around America and who can get $200,000 without accountability because the former Minister for Home Affairs and the Prime Minister say so. That is what happened in relation to that person. I do not know whether it is for those reasons, his skill in bamboozling the Prime Minister of this country and the former Minister for Home Affairs, that he is on the National Australia Day Committee. No other reason for his being on it was drawn to the Committee's attention.
I should say, in conclusion, that the National Australia Day Committee also seemed to represent a farcical expenditure of government money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to draw a matter to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). I intended to do so by way of a question today but, as so often happens in this place, I missed the call. The Minister will recall my many requests to him since his appointment to the ministry to visit the Point McLeay Aboriginal settlement in South Australia to have discussions with the residents regarding the problems being experienced by the Ralkon Agricultural Co. In view of the fact that the Minister visited Point McLeay on Friday, 22 May, I ask him now: What action does he intend taking to resolve quickly the problems that have beset the community for a long period? Will he be making a definite statement to the Senate on this matter? It is a very important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the Minister went down to Point McLeay although I was not very pleased with the way I got a message from his Department in Adelaide that he was visiting the area. The message came in on my answering machine in my office some time after my office closed on Thursday night. The message was to the effect that the Minister wished to advise me that he would be visiting Point McLeay the next day. The message came in late on Thursday night advising me that he would be visiting that area the next day.

So, I ask the Minister why the visit was so hurried. Only a few days before, he had written to the people at Point McLeay stating that he had not set time to visit the area. I ask him also whether he will tell the Senate the names of the people he invited to accompany him on this visit. He may not be able to tell me tonight. Perhaps I will raise the matter further when we consider the Estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I will not delay the Senate any later as it is nearly midnight. But I ask the Minister whether he will make a statement on his intentions to help to solve those current and very pertinent problems at Point McLeay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren has asked some questions regarding my visit last week to Point McLeay. I went to Point McLeay, firstly, to honour my promise to him to get down there when I could. But the honourable senator is quite correct. The decision was made hurriedly because I received an urgent request from the Point McLeay community to visit that community. I received that request by way of telex or telegram; I cannot remember which. It was made urgent because there was an imminent decision to be taken by the Aboriginal Development Commission in relation to Bartlett's farm, which has been the subject of Senator McLaren's concern. That decision was to be taken within a few days. In fact it is to be taken some time this week.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal community was very keen to meet me. From an examination of my diary it was quite clear that either I went the day after receiving the telegram or I did not go at all for some time. I made a decision to go and we set about making the arrangements. Among those arrangements was a decision that we should notify Senator McLaren. Obviously that was one of the things that we wanted to do because we knew of his interest. We wanted to make sure that he was informed of the decision. I am sorry if a message was left on Senator McLaren's answering machine when his office was not open, but the instructions were that he was to be informed. It was a fairly rushed set of arrangements. I am not sure at what time the telegram arrived during the day but we made the arrangements on the Thursday to go down on the Friday. I ask Senator McLaren to accept that that was the case.

I was accompanied by my area officer and the acting regional director of my Department. I was accompanied also by the local State member-I think I am correct in saying he is Mr Peter Lewis-and by the Federal member, Mr James Porter. I had hoped, if Senator McLaren had been able to go, that he would have been there as well. I was not accompanied by Mr Randall, the other parliamentarian who had an interest, as I did not have room in the car and could not offer him transport. But I informed him that we were going down there in case he wished to make his own way down.

The matter which concerned the Point McLeay community was some uncertainty of my powers in relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission. Two sets of opinions were going around that community. The first was that, as I had informed the community, I had no power to direct the Aboriginal Development Commission on particular matters. The matter in this case is the disposition of the title deeds to Bartlett's farm. The other view arose from someone's reading of the Act that section 11 of the Act gave me power to direct the Commission. I knew that that was the matter concerning the community so I took a copy of the Act with me. We checked before I went there on what my powers were. I spent some time with the community meeting with the councillors at Point McLeay. Directors of Ralkon Agricultural Co. were present, although I am not certain whether they were all present. I think most of them were present. The community adviser, Mr Colin Probyn, was there, as was Mr Ian Hillock, who is the manager to the Ralkon company. Mr Garnet Wilson, the local National Aboriginal Council member-an elected representative-also accompanied me. I am sorry I did not mention him earlier.

I made it clear to the community, as I think Senator McLaren would agree I should, what my powers were and were not under the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. I made it clear to the meeting which was chaired by Mr Rankin that I had no power to direct the ADC in what it did with Bartlett's farm and the title deeds in the dispute that has been going on between Ralkon and Point McLeay. I think that this cleared the air because at least the communities gained some clear idea of what the options were. One of the options was not that the Minister should intervene to give instructions to the ADC. The whole purpose of the Aboriginal Development Commission is that it should have a capacity to make decisions on behalf of Aboriginal people free from direction on detailed matters by the Minister of the day, generally a non-Aboriginal. I thought the meeting was very useful to that extent and there followed a whole series of discussions. I followed that by getting the permission of Mr Spencer Rigney and driving there to look at Ralkon and some parts of the farm. I made sure that I went on to the property before I came back.

It is not my intention now to make a full statement. The purpose of my visit was to put the community in a position in which it could go on and negotiate what it has to negotiate with the ADC. I am confident that that is what it wants to do. In fact, I am informed that it sent a telex to the ADC either yesterday or today. The ADC is meeting in Canberra and it has informed me that it has received the telex. I cannot say what the state of negotiations between these two bodies is at the moment. I believe it is desirable-I think everyone would agree it is desirable-that some accommodation be reached between the Point McLeay community and the Ralkon Agricultural Co. in a dispute which has been going on for a very considerable time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
